div.head: To the RIGHT HONOURABLE John Lord Brad≈øhawe, Lord Commi≈ø≈øioner of the Great Seal of England, Tho. Lord Fairfax, Maj. Gen. Lambert, Sir Arthur He≈øilrigge, Sir Henry Vane, Sir James Harington, Lieut. Gen. Ludlow, Lord Whitlock, Lieut. Gen. Fleetwood, Jo≈øiah Barners E≈øq. Coll. Morley, Tho. Scot E≈øq. Col. Sydenham, Henry Nevill E≈øq Tho. Chaloner E≈øq. All of them of the mo≈øt honourable Councel of State.
div.p: IT is a curious Art to make a Watch, and he mu≈øt be a skilful Arti≈øt, that exactly ≈øets a broken Bone, God for the ≈øins of this Nation, hath ≈øeveral times in this Age, took the Clock of this Common-wealth in pieces, and many of the pins and wheels have bin and are mi≈øplaced. It now requires great skill, to place and ≈øet every thing in its due order.

Your Honours have a great work to do, God hath broken us in pieces, and divided our Councels, and none can unite us, but he that hath wounded us, he only mu≈øt cure us, and ble≈øs and ≈øanctifie all lawful means, or
el≈øe our disjoynted bones will never be truly knit, or exactly ≈øet.

For this end hath God apointed a ≈øelect number of honourable per≈øons, of which number your Honours are Members, who≈øe heart God hath fixed for this great Work, to revive the ≈øtones out of the heap of rubbi≈øh, and to build the Walls of our Jeru≈øalem, though the Sanballats, Arabians and Ammonites be worth, and con≈øpire altogether to fight again≈øt Jeru≈øalem, to hinder this VVork.

Right Honourable, if you will fini≈øh this good VVork you have begun, you mu≈øt do as Nehemiah did, keep good watch day and night, becau≈øe of your enemies, le≈øt your adver≈øaries ≈øerve you, as they ≈øerved Nehemiah, for they ≈øay you ≈øhall not know nor ≈øee till we come in the mid≈øt among≈øt them, and ≈ølay them, and cau≈øe the work to cea≈øe, if this be not prevented, this Parliament will have a fatal end.

Pre≈øidents in Courts of Ju≈øtice is a great Guide to all ju≈øt Judges, e≈øpecially when they have been made by the Grave and Learned,
and are recorded in the Sacred Bible, the chiefe≈øt Book that every good State≈øman walks by; ≈øuch State≈ømen that walks by Machiavels rules, the wicked Maximes of the≈øe trouble≈øom times, they do as Saul did when he left God, and went to the VVitch of Endor, he pretended to go to ≈øpeak with Samuel, and met with the devil, ≈øo the≈øe times have produced many a Fa≈øt, the pretence hath bin to ≈øeek God and Peace, when the true end hath bin to get to be the Head of a Party and Faction, to make divi≈øion, and to get the Peoples money: The People are now very well acquainted with ≈øuch canting, and as we know after a fla≈øh of lightning, there comes a clap of thunder, ≈øo hath it many times fallen out, after Fa≈øts hath followed an erecting of an High Court of Ju≈øtice, or one remarkable oppre≈ø≈øion or other.

I humbly pre≈øent you here in this Epi≈øtle, with a good Pre≈øident made by a great State≈øman Nehemiah, ≈øuch a one as God hath recorded was a Saviour of his Countrey, a Builder up of Jeru≈øalem, in the like ca≈øe, and
in the like ≈øtraits as it is now, or ≈øuddenly without Gods infinite mercy will be vvith us, he took this cour≈øe. In the fir≈øt place, he ≈øought God, and prayed before the God of Heaven, and did not make a mock-Fa≈øt; then he u≈øed the means, he fell to his VVork, and built up the walls of Jeru≈øalem, and did not only build, but he built wi≈øely and politickly, and had there bin a Sanballat found among≈øt them, the people would have ≈øtoned him.

On the lovver places behind the vvall, and on the higher places, he ≈øet the people after their families, vvith their ≈øvvords, their ≈øpears and their bovves; and vvhen he had ≈øet him≈øelf in a po≈øture of defence, he made the people to be his Guard, and delivered an Oration to the Rulers and People, ≈øaying, Be not afraid of your enemies, remember the Lord which is great and terrible, and fight for your brethren, your ≈øonnes and your daughters, your wives and your hou≈øes.

I ≈øhall humbly de≈øire your Honours to ob≈øerve, vvhat vvas the effect of this orderly
and good po≈øture. Nehemiah and his people did not their work carele≈ø≈øely and by halfes, and ≈øpent their precious time in needle≈ø≈øe que≈øtions, but did all things upon ≈øound advice. For when great things are quietly without Faction di≈øputed, and the Re≈øult concluded; then to u≈øe expedition and re≈øolution is ju≈øt policie.

But all ha≈øty and unadvi≈øed attempts at long running brings the Common-wealth into great danger, and the Actors generally into contempt and mi≈øery, many men in their de≈øignes thinking to catch a great Fi≈øh, but after long angling bring up a Frog; this daily experience hath ≈øhewed, and I can experimentally ≈øay it to be true.

For tho≈øe men that read Machiavel, and make it their Rule to walk by, in ≈øtead of the Bible, becau≈øe they are in great places, to practice Iniquity by a Law, as Ahab did for Naboths Viniard, who did not only cheat him of his Land and Inheritance, but robbed him of his Life, and to ≈øeem holy called a Fa≈øt, the effect of that godly Fa≈øt was to ≈øet two
mens ≈øonns of Belial, to beare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe that Naboth had B≈øa≈øphemed God and the King, ≈øending a warrant for the Execution of innocent Naboth before ever they tryed him, that he ≈øhould be ≈øton'd to death right or wrong, what a ≈øad End the Authors of this murder and robbery come to is well known, how many great and Noble Per≈øons of the eminente≈øt for quality in this Nation, have bin Trappaned and perjured out of their Lifes, Lands and E≈øtates, and ≈øome of the witne≈ø≈øes upon their Death beds with horrour of Con≈øcience, and great Remor≈øe have confe≈ø≈øed the perjury that they were ≈øuborned by others, to the great ≈øcandal of the Ju≈øtice of the Nation by ≈øuch waies to get mens E≈øtates.

This is mo≈øt apparent God is comming to vi≈øit for the≈øe things, and when man cannot bring the Delinquents to Ju≈øtice, he cau≈øeth the guilty Per≈øons one to puni≈øh another, till by the dividing and ≈øubdividing they are ≈øo weak, that as the flood cam upon the old world and de≈øtroyed mankinde, ≈øo by the≈øe divi≈øions
the ≈øtrength of the Nation is disjoynted. Every man upon and again≈øt his Neighbour, making a pa≈ø≈øage and way for the common Enemy to come and ≈øwallovv the Innocent with the guilty, if God be not mercifull.

Mo≈øes divided the Red-Sea, and the Children of I≈ørael pa≈ø≈øed over on dry Land, God hath by nature made a Sea betvveen us and our Neighbours, he hath hedged us in, and made a vvall of ≈øeperation between us and Popery, but our ≈øins at this day are plucking down this wall, the wilde Bore of the Forre≈øt is come in among≈øt us, the Devil and the Je≈øuites have plaid their parts in this Nation, to the ruining of many Body and Soul, and to the admiration of Chri≈øtendom, the Jewes Crucified Chri≈øt thinking to gratifie Cae≈øar, Cae≈øar a few years after paid them to purpo≈øe for Crucifying him.

May it plea≈øe your Honours, The ten Commandements and Fonts for chri≈øtning of children at the beginning of the≈øe Troubles were plucked down; and now comes Pulpits to be beaten in pieces, and frequent tumults in ≈øeveral Churches
within the city of London, as lately at Aldgate pari≈øh hath bin done, which is a corner of the city, where many poor live, and are fit for any In≈øurrection.

p.hi: When I ≈øee children with a candle among≈øt powder or chips, I feare the burning of the hou≈øe, or a blow with powder; when wee ≈øee the buds appeare, the ≈øpring is near: the≈øe are as certaine ≈øignes of a mi≈øchief; as the plague-tokens are to a man that hath the Plague, the be≈øt ≈øymptomes are a purple fever; a ≈øhaking, an earth-quake, if not a di≈ø≈øolution. The pride and vanity of ≈øome Lecturers and Mini≈øters, who in the Nation having ≈øtudyed points of di≈ø≈øention and divi≈øion, in≈øtead of the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt preach them≈øelves, (too much plenty have made them wanton.)

div.p:
No doubt but ≈øome of them do it with the advice of the Ie≈øuits to make a ≈øeparation in Countryes, Cities, Townes, Pari≈øhes and Families, till without Gods infinite mercy, the Ie≈øuits bring a de≈øtruction both on the Churches and hou≈øes of the Nation, and on this Great Citie of London, and ≈øet every man to cut one anothers throats. Would not the end of the≈øe things bring
an unhappy deformation, instead of a ble≈ø≈øed Reformation, when we are expo≈øed to the fury of a forein Enemy by the vilene≈øs of the Ie≈øuits, and folly of our own Divi≈øions?

What a diveli≈øh State trick vvas put upon the late Protector Oliver, and his Secretary Mr. Thurloe, by Sir Kenelm Digby, and ≈øeveral other Per≈øons Je≈øuitically inclined, in ≈øetting the Protector on that fatal bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Hi≈øpaniola and Jamaica, without ever advi≈øing and con≈øulting with many of the Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Planters, who had for many years lived in tho≈øe parts, and had they had the honour to have been con≈øulted with, they could have told them that tho≈øe fiery Regions was not for the con≈øtitution of our bodies.

That Fox and ≈øubtile State≈øman Sir Kenelme Digby, his very name ≈øhould have bin fatall to the Prote≈øtants cau≈øe, if the Lord Protector Oliver and Mr. Thurloe would have bin plea≈øed to remember the Gun-powder trea≈øon.

This fatal de≈øigne of Jamaica co≈øt the Protector and the Commonwealth above tvvo
millions of pounds, be≈øide the lives of above twentie thou≈øand valiant Engli≈øhmen, de≈øtroyed by the unhealthfulne≈øs of the Climate, and want of nece≈ø≈øary Provi≈øions; and when the≈øe valiant men were almo≈øt fami≈øht, (who had they bin in any part of Chri≈øtendom, the Spaniards dur≈øt not have look't them in the face, had they bin twice their number,) yet the≈øe gallant Souldiers were all like ≈øheep led to the ≈ølaughter, and their blood ≈øpilt like water on the ground, by the treachery of ≈øome of their Officers, who no doubt had private in≈øtructions from ≈øome then in power to do what they did, which upon examination was the cau≈øe they kept their heads upon their ≈øhoulders, and e≈øcap't both with lives and e≈øtates.

May it plea≈øe your Honours, I hope your Honours will pardon the≈øe ≈øad and nece≈ø≈øarie truths, proceeding from a loyal heart. I have formerly ventured my life many times to get the Common-wealth two hundred ≈øeventie eight thou≈øand pounds in money, I now venture my ≈øelf in the≈øe dangerous times to ≈øpeak
truth. It is now as it was in the daies of Noah; no man but Noah and his Familie believ'd a flood would come, till it did come and ≈øweep them all away.

And if I be ju≈øtly u≈øed, I may now in your ≈øtreights bring you in pre≈øently as great a ≈øum in money again as I ≈øaved you formerly abov three hundred thou≈øand pounds, fevv of the Council of State when I undertook to di≈øcover the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors fraudulent claim to this Silver, I ≈øay there was but few of that Council did believe that I could ever get the State this Silver, or that I would be ≈øo faithful to refu≈øe ten thou≈øand pounds which was offered me by the Claimers of this Silver, which is certified in this Book by ≈øeverall honourable Per≈øons to be true, ≈øhould I bend my braines as much to ≈øtudy the di≈øturbance of this Common-wealth, as I have ever done the peace and happine≈øs of it, I could Demon≈øtrate to you, a pen and Inkhorne-man as I am can do more ≈øervice or di≈ø≈øervice then many hundreds of Red-coats, I humbly pray my faithfulne≈ø≈øe be not paid with Ingratitude.

As for my own life, I de≈øire to have it no longer pre≈øerv'd then I can ≈øerve and benefit my Countrey. I will wait on God, and ex≈øpect an happie i≈ø≈øue upon this my humble reque≈øt, knowing that if the Reputation and Iu≈øtice of the State, and the Certificates of honorable per≈øons be of any value in your Honours ≈øight, my great expence, pains and faithfulne≈øs, ≈øhall have its due and promi≈øed Reward; con≈øidering that in the≈øe humble Propo≈øals which I have propounded to your Honours for my ≈øatisfaction, I take no money from the publick, but humbly offer to pay in monethly a great Revenue to the maimed Souldiers, to regulate the abu≈øes of the Manufacture of Gold and Silver Thread and Lace, to give a ≈øtop to the Tran≈øportation of Gold and Silver, to keep your Mint con≈øtantly at work to coyn money, great quantities yearly: all which ≈øervices are of very great con≈øequence to the Common-wealth, the con≈øideration of the premi≈ø≈øes I humbly leave to your Honours, and remain

closer.signed: Your Honours dutifull and humble Servant, TH. VIOLET.

div.p:
YOur Petitioner did about the eighth of Decemb. 1652. deliver into the Councel of State a Written Paper, wherein was di≈øcovered, that at that pre≈øent time a Practice and Combination was ≈øet on foot by ≈øeveral Merchants and others, to deceive the
Common-wealth of a great quantity of ≈øilver, above three hundred thou≈øand pounds, which was then aboard the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and St. George, then riding about Black-wall.

Upon Examination of this Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe at the Councel of State, the Councel within few dayes after, commanded and engaged your Petitioner in this ≈øervice, and your Petitioner did faithfully promi≈øe the Councel his uttermo≈øt endeavours, to di≈øcover this fraud, and at his own charge to pro≈øecute this Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the Court of Adm≈øraltie. The Judges of the Court of Admiraltie did appoint the 16. day of Decemb. 1652. to give ≈øentence for clearing the≈øe ≈øhips and ≈øilver, being to the value of about three hundred thou≈øand pounds in ≈øilver, as appears by the Certificate of the Officers of the Mint; Whereupon your Petitioner came into the Court of Admiralty, the very day and houre the Judges were clearing the ≈øaid ≈øilver, and at his own peril made his Prote≈øt in the Admiraltie again≈øt the Judges of that Court, and again≈øt all further Proceedings of theirs, to di≈øcharge this Silver in the afore≈øaid ≈øhips, till your Petitioners Witne≈ø≈øes were examined, and ≈øhewed the Judges many Rea≈øons, being for the advantage and ≈øafety of the Common-wealth, for re≈øpiting for ≈øome dayes their Judgment.

Thereupon the Court of Admiralty adjourned till the next day; and the Judges being very angry with your Petitioner for making the afore≈øaid Prote≈øt, and for what your Petitioner had ≈øaid to the Judges in open Court, the
Judges thereupon command your Petitioner to attend the Council of State that very day in the afternoon, being 16 of December 1652. the Petitioner to an≈øwer before them for his mildemeanor (≈øo the Iudges were plea≈øed to call it) that morning in the Court of Admiralty.

Your Petitioner did accordingly attend the Council of State that day, 16 Dec. in the afternoon, and upon full examination of the Bu≈øine≈øs before them, the Council ≈øtayed the ≈øilver, and blamed the Judges for their complaining of your Petitioner, and your Petitioner had thanks from the Council for what hee had done in his timely and ≈øea≈øonable ≈øtaying this ≈øilver, and commanded to u≈øe what expedition hee could in proving that great quantities of the ≈øilver then aboard the≈øe ≈øhips appertained to the Merchants of Am≈øterdam. Thereupon your Petitioner undertook to the Council of State to di≈øprove the Spani≈øh and Flemi≈øh clamors, and the Spani≈øh Emba≈ø≈øadors pretences to all this ≈øilver in the afore≈øaid ≈øhips. And this di≈øcovery your Petitioner undertook to make to the Council of State at his own charge.

The Council of State upon the con≈øiderations afore≈øaid, and to incourage your Petitioner to proceed, they did faithfully promi≈øe your Petitioner for this his ≈øervice and di≈øcovery, that your Petitioner ≈øhould be paid the ≈øum of eleven thou≈øand pounds out of the ≈øilver that ≈øhould be taken out of the≈øe ≈øhips, and converted to the u≈øe of the Common-wealth, this ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, being the value of your Petitioners E≈øtate, which
the Parliament 1643. upon mis-information again≈øt your Petitioner had ≈øeque≈øtred.

And the Council of State declared unto your Petitioner, That if your Petitioner ≈øhould fail to make good his undertaking in di≈øproving the Spani≈øh and Flemi≈øh Claims to all this ≈øilver, then aboard the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, that the undertaking would undo your Petitioner; for upon your Petitioners failing to make good proof of what he had undertaken, the Councel of State would report your Petitioner to the Parliament to be an Incendiary, therefore it highly concerned your Petitioner to be well a≈ø≈øured of what he had undertaken, and al≈øo to be ju≈øtly dealt withal when he had done this ≈øervice.

Upon the a≈ø≈øurance of the Councel of State upon the afore≈øaid termes, your Petitioner engaged and undertook this great, difficult, and dangerous ≈øervice, wherein your Petitioner employed above ten ≈øeveral per≈øons, for about two years, and laid out of Pur≈øe, be≈øides all his time and hazard, the ≈øumme of above ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds, which he payes intere≈øt for at this very day, as is depo≈øed by ≈øeveral Witne≈ø≈øes whom your Petitioners employed in this ≈øervice, and this is atte≈øted under the hands of ≈øeveral Honourable Per≈øons, to the late Lord Protector Oliver.

May it plea≈øe your Honours, be≈øides this ≈øervice your Petitioner did for the Common-wealth, he di≈øcovered to the Councel of State, in Jan. 1651. That from Augu≈øt.
to December 20. 1652. the Admiralty had di≈øcharged fifty eight ≈øhips, all loaden with rich merchandize, I printed the ≈øeveral daies of the moneth they were cleared out of the Court of Admiralty, the names of the ≈øhips, and the Ma≈øter of the ≈øhips names, and the parties to whom the≈øe ≈øhips and merchandize was delivered at London; and that many of the≈øe ≈øhips after their di≈øcharge from hence, unloaded their merchandize at Am≈øterdam for the account of the Dutch, to the value of many hundred thou≈øand pounds.

Upon examination of this Bu≈øine≈øs, the Council of State had certain intelligence from beyond ≈øea that this information was true, and the≈øe Letters were remaining in Captain Bi≈øheps hands who can te≈øtifie the truth. Whereupon your Petitioner humbly pre≈øented to the Council of State in writing ≈øeveral waies for the preventing this abu≈øe for the future, and the Judges in the Admiraltie was removed, and other Iudges put in their places, with particular in≈øtructions for the prevention of the former frauds put on the Nation.

By which di≈øcovery made by your Petitioner, the Common-wealth got many ≈øcore prizes, which were condemned as Dutch prizes, when they could not bring atte≈øtations from Hamborough under the Parliament Agents hands, viz Mr Brad≈øhaws, that they really and truly belonged to Hamborough. The value of the Ships and goods by your Petitioners means di≈øcovered was amounting to ≈øeveral ≈øcore of thou≈øand pounds, be≈øides all the ≈øilver your Petitioner ≈øtayed, which the Dutch had cozen.
ed us of, had not your Petitioner acquainted the Council in Ianuary 1652 with the former cheats put on the Nation, in printing a li≈øt of 58 Saile of ≈øhips, mo≈øt of them Dutch prize, which the Common-wealth lo≈øt, for want of keeping a good Watch on the Actions of their Judges and Officers in the Admiralty in tho≈øe times 1652. 1653. It was nothing for ordinary Proctors in the Admiralty to get foure of five thou≈øand pounds a yeare, by cozening the State in their prizes, till your Petitioner by his di≈øcovery to the Councel of State, ≈øpoiled their Trade for a great part of it. This di≈øcovery got your Petitioner the envy of many hundred Merchants, and others in the Admiralty.

There was not a motion, nor any Proceedings in the Court of Admiralty, for about three yeares, touching the Silver Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador and George, their ≈øilver and lading, but every day your Petitioner was required to give his attendance therein, at the Court of Admiralty, and forced to employ at his own charge many per≈øons; and your Petitioner was required by Doctor Walker, at his own charge to employ many per≈øons to breviate and have in≈øpection into all the Records, Acts, Bills of lading, Pleas, Extracts, Allegations, and Interrogatories, Witne≈ø≈øes, Depo≈øitions in the Silver bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as will appear under the hands of ≈øeveral per≈øons employed and paid by your Petitioner for that ≈øervice.

Your Petitioner did ≈øeveral times move the Councel of State, in December, January, February, March 1652.
to unload the ≈øilver out of the ≈øhips, to avoid the embezeling thereof, there being above an hundred thou≈øand pounds ≈øtollen out of the≈øe ≈øhips, while the ≈øilver was in the River; there are bills of lading in the Admiralty, for ≈øilver that was never delivered into the Tower, to the value of above a hundred thou≈øand pounds in ≈øilver, which bills appertain to the≈øe ≈øhips, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George.

Your Petitioner pre≈øented to the Councel of State, in 1652. 1653. ≈øeveral frauds and abu≈øes put upon the Common-wealth, in the Sale of their Prizes, Ships, and Merchandize, by the indirect meanes of ≈øome Officers they intru≈øted to ≈øell the ≈øame, ≈øometimes the State hath been cheated fourty in the hundred, to the value of many ≈øcore of thou≈øand pounds in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

Your Petitioner finding the≈øe papers that made this Di≈øcovery, which he delivered to Col. Joanes, and Mr. Thurloe, (by ≈øome bribing means) in the Cu≈øtodie of ≈øome of the parties complained of; and that nothing was done to reform the≈øe abu≈øes, but this bu≈øine≈øs was ≈øtiffed. (And by your Petitioners di≈øcovery of the abu≈øes for the ≈øervice of the State, he had contracted the envie of many guilty per≈øons) Thereupon to ≈øhew to the world, what I had delivered in private to the afore≈øaid per≈øons was true, and that I would ju≈øtifie what I had complained of privately, I printed the ≈øeveral frauds and cheats put upon the Nation by ≈øome of the Commi≈ø≈øioners for prize Goods, and ≈øome of their Officers and Agents, and demon≈øtrated ≈øeveral wayes for the State to
finde it out, which was offered to be proved to be true, by Mr. John Day, and ≈øeveral others at that time, but the fate of the Common-wealth in tho≈øe dayes was to be cozened, that makes the debts of the publick now at this time ≈øo great, and the Publicans of the time ≈øo rich.

Your Petitioner by order of Parliament, as appears by your Records of the Hou≈øe, for ≈øeveral yeares was commanded to follow and ≈øolicite the getting of an Act to pa≈ø≈øe again≈øt tran≈øporting Gold and Silver. And your Petitioner made ≈øeveral overtures both for puni≈øhing and di≈øcovery of the offenders that had tran≈øported Gold and Silver, and melted down the ≈øilver coyn of the Nation; by who≈øe fines many ≈øcore of thou≈øand pounds would have ju≈øtly come to the State.

But the guilty per≈øons were then ≈øo powerfull in the Councills of the Parliament, that though the Parliament made ≈øeveral Committees of the Hou≈øe and Council of State, for the perfecting the Act and for di≈øcovery of the offenders, and referred the matter thereof to the con≈øideration of the Commi≈øsioners of the Navy, Officers of the Mint, and Farmers of the Cu≈øtomes, who all of them have certified the Parliament of the great mi≈øchief and dammage the Common-wealth ≈øuffered by ≈øeveral evil-di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons, who for private lucre and gain daily tran≈øported the Gold and Silver of the Nation, to the un≈øpeakable damage of the Common-wealth. This Bill being twice read in the Hou≈øe, and ≈øeveral times committed, yet by the power of ≈øome guilty Merchants, this good Act was ≈øtopt, ≈ømothered and ≈øtifled,
and never fini≈øht, though your Petitioner attended many yeares at his great expence and charges to have this good Act pa≈øt, (And now at this day it is apparent to all people,) that you cannot receive in the payment of a thou≈øand pounds twenty ≈øhillings in Gold, no Gold being ≈øtirring in the Nation, but in the hands of Game≈øters, Rooks, and Gold≈ømiths, they ≈øelling a twenty ≈øhillings piece in Gold for two ≈øhillings in the pound, more then the price current by Proclamation, which is again≈øt the Statute of the fifth and ≈øixth of Edward the ≈øixth. And to give your Honours an information of the pre≈øent ≈øtock of Silver moneys, now current in this Nation, there is very little left but light and clipt money, the weightie ≈øilver money, being culled, melted down, and tran≈øported, by divers Gold≈ømiths and others, for private lucre and gain, to the un≈øpeakable damage of the Common-wealth, e≈øpecially at this time, now we have War with Spain. This your Petitioner hath often complained of to this Parliament, and hath humbly offered them a remedy, but as yet nothing hath been done by them to prevent this mi≈øchief.

p.hi: There was ≈øeveral Committees appointed to regulate the abu≈øes concerning the coyne, and removing the ob≈øtructions of the Mint the≈øe times, having appointed two Doctors of Phy≈øick to be the chief Officers of the Mint.

body.p:
Your Petitioner was required to give his attendance on this Committee, and commanded by them at his own charge to ≈øend for from beyond ≈øeas all the principal Coyns in Chri≈øtendom, and to procure the Lawes, Orders and Statutes made beyond ≈øeas, for
the due regulating their Mints; and their Policies, how they u≈øed to draw bullion into their Mints: the≈øe Lawes your Petitioner tran≈ølated and printed, and pre≈øented them to the Committee of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, for removing the ob≈øtructions of the Mint.

And your Petitioner made A≈ø≈øayes of all the≈øe forraign Coynes of Gold and Silver, and writ down the ju≈øt weight and ≈øtandard of every ≈øeveral forreign Coyne, what proportion and value they held with the ≈øtandard of our Mint, and what every forreign piece of Gold and Silver, would make to Merchants to be coyn'd in our Mint of London, and cau≈øed all the ≈øeveral ≈øtamps of the Coynes of forreign Gold and Silver to be engraved, for the true information of all our Engli≈øh Merchants, who generally are not ≈øo expert in this my≈øtery as the Dutch Merchants are. The true rea≈øon of this defect is this, viz. In England we have only our own Coynes of Gold and Silver goes currant, which makes our Nation in general never to ≈øtudy the intrin≈øecal value of forreign Coynes of Gold or Silver; whereas in Holland almo≈øt all forreign Coynes of Gold or Silver goes currant by Proclamation, therefore of nece≈ø≈øity all Merchants and others mu≈øt know the intrin≈øecal value of all forreign Coynes, what proportion they hold with their ≈øtandard; and ≈øeveral Books which they call Placarts, are printed by Authority of the States, with the ≈øeveral Figures of the Coynes of forreign Gold and Silver, being marked in the margin at what price the ≈øeveral Coynes ≈øhall go, not being wa≈øhed and clipt, and full weight.

p.hi:
And the Dutch allowing the≈øe forreign Coynes to go currant, having publick banks of trea≈øure, that makes them Ma≈øters
of their Exchange of moneys, the my≈øteries whereof very few of our Engli≈øh Merchants under≈øtand, for the rea≈øons afore≈øaid.

body.p: But had the Figures of all the forreign Coynes bin printed, which was prepared by your Petitioner, by order of the Honourable the Committee of the Mint, in 1652. your Petitioner humbly affirms to your Honours, that the printing thereof would have been a great guide and advantage to our Merchants, and the Nation, had Mr. Secretary Thurloe given your Petitioner back again the≈øe Prints and Papers which was mo≈øt model'd and acted by your Petitioner; but he buried them in Oblivion, as he did many other good Propo≈øals, which your Petitioner pre≈øented to him, for the ≈øervice of the Common-wealth.

p.hi: Your Petitioner humbly offered, to the con≈øideration of the Committee, for removing the ob≈øtructions of the Mint, that if they would ≈øet the Mint a work, they mu≈øt take order to remove their chief Officers of the Mint; the≈øe Gentlemen, the pre≈øent ma≈øter. Worker and Warden, were never brought up to know the my≈øteries of the Mint, nor the private waies of corre≈øpondence with forein mints and merchants, and to make every winde bring grift to their mill, and to know what ≈øhips and merchants bring us in gold and ≈øilver, and to learn the my≈øterie to inforce them to coyn it; al≈øo to know what ≈øhips and merchants tran≈øport gold and ≈øilver without licence from the State, and to keep good intelligence and watch upon their actions, that ≈øo the gold and ≈øilver endeavored to be unlawfully tran≈øported may be ≈øeiz'd and forfeited. For a man to be his Cra≈øts-ma≈øter in this my≈øtery, requires as many years ≈øtudy as to be a Doctor of Phy≈øick, and is never to be learn'd by looking on an ∆≤rinal.

Your Petitioner humbly ≈øaies, The Parliament had made a better bargain to have given the≈øe Doctors of Phy≈øick fortie thou≈øand pounds for a pen≈øion, than to ≈øuffer that dammage they have received by the not imploying of the mint, daily gold and ≈øilver being imported into this Nation, and before ever it be coyned tran≈øported out again without licence, to the great dammage and weakning of the ≈øtock of this Common wealth.

There is ≈øilver and gold va≈øt and great quantities brought daily from beyond the ≈øeas, and landed in this Nation, without paying of Cu≈øtom, and this verie ≈øilver and gold is ≈øtoln out of the Nation again before ever it be coyned without licence or paying of Cu≈øtom; ≈øo here is a Trade to the value of ≈øome hundreds of thou≈øands of pounds by the year, for the particular profit of ≈øome covetous merchants, and the Common-wealth have no profit either by Exci≈øe, Cu≈øtom or Coynadge; and till skilfull men in the≈øe My≈øteries be imployed in the Mint, this mi≈øchief will not be ≈øtopt or removed either by Doctors or Apothecaries.

body.p: Your Petitioner did formerly offer, and now doth humby offer unto your Honours, that he may be impowered and commi≈øsioned to be ma≈øter-Worker and melter of the Mint, to undertake now at this time to ≈øet your Mint to work, notwith≈øtandidg the pre≈øent Warre with Spain, provided your Petitioner may be impowered by your Honours order for the execution of what he ≈øhall humbly propound for the honour of the State and ≈øervice of the Common-wealth in this bu≈øine≈øs.

p.hi:
God ≈øend your Honours to order all the≈øe abu≈øes by mee here pre≈øented, may be prevented for the future, and care taken where corrupt, ignorant and unskilfull per≈øons are got into imploiment for the publick they may be removed, and tru≈øtie skilfull Officers put
in their imploiments. Your Petitioner humbly ≈øaies, This is a ≈øure waie to abate and le≈ø≈øen the great engagements of the Commonwealth, when Drones are di≈øcharged and Bees imploied: for if your Honours take away the cau≈øe, the cure of the di≈øea≈øe followes of cour≈øe.

div.p: OLIVER the late Lord Protector the 20. of April 1653. di≈ømi≈ø≈øes the Parliament, and the ≈øame day put a Guard of ≈øouldiers aboard the afore≈øaid ≈øhips, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and St. George, then riding about Black wall. And ≈øhortly after unloads all the ≈øilver into the Mint, which your Petitioner ≈øtayed for the u≈øe of the Common-wealth: your Petitioner can prove it by the Account of the Mint, that the ≈øilver which was taken out of the ≈øaid ≈øhips, be≈øide what was ≈øtoln and embezeled, amounted to the ≈øumme of two hundred ≈øeventie eight thou≈øand odde hundred pounds, and Mr. Lieut. of the Tower, Col. Bark≈øtead, paid out all this great Trea≈øure.

In reducing the Dutch, paying the Army, and other ≈øervices for the Publick, as will appear by the particulars of his Accompt; and your Petitioner never had farthing, ≈øo that this great Trea≈øure your Petitioner ≈øtayed, was every pennie laid out in defence of the Commonwealth, and ≈øubduing the Dutch. It was a great mercie of God to this Nation, that your Petitioner prevented the Dutch from getting this great Trea≈øure, at that juncture of time, 1652. that ≈øilver would have made work for us el≈øe, had the Dutch had it.

When your Petitioner ≈øee all this money di≈øpo≈øed of
by Col. Bark≈øtead, and not one penny thereof paid unto your Petitioner, according to the promi≈øe of the Councel of State; yet at the ≈øame time your Petitioner to be daily commanded and enjoined by the late Lord Protector Oliver, and by his Councel, and by the Judges of the Admiraltie, and Doctor Walker 1653. 1654. dailie required at his own charge to attend and pro≈øecute this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and to pay about ten other per≈øons for about two yeares, who a≈ø≈øi≈øted your Petitioner in the pro≈øecution of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as appears by the Warrants of the Councel of State, Court of Admiraltie, Doctor Walker, all of them dated after the 20. of April 1653. which Warrants and Orders your Petitioner hath ready to produce to your Honours.

Your Petitioner finding this unmerciful and hard u≈øage in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, to be dailie forced to borrow great ≈øummes of money at intere≈øt, and to expend the ≈øame in pro≈øecuting this bu≈øine≈øs in the Admiraltie to maintain the States claim to this ≈øilver again≈øt the claimers, and your Petitioner never to receive one peny from the States for his ≈øervice, he was enforced to petition the late Lord Protector OLIVER for his reward and ≈øatisfaction, according to the promi≈øe of the Councel of State, his Highne≈øs being one of the Members that had faithfully promi≈øed your Petitioner the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds when your Petitioner fir≈øt undertook this ≈øervice, before Col. Bingham and Mr Sadler.

In his Petition hee ≈øets forth the ≈øeveral ≈øervices, chargeable and dangerous imploiment, together with the
Councel of States engagements and promi≈øe, to pay your Petitioner eleven thou≈øand pounds for this his di≈øcovery and ≈øervice, and named ≈øeveral of the Councel of State which knew this to be a truth, and that your Petitioner wholly relied upon the Councels Promi≈øe as afore≈øaid (which was the true cau≈øe) that engaged your Petitioner, to undertake this difficult, chargeable, and dangerous task and emploiment.

And had not your Petitioner borrowed above ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds, and expended it all in this ≈øervice, which he payes intere≈øt for at this very day, be≈øides your Petitioners daily attendance in the Admiralty, with about ten per≈øons whom he paid and employed in this bu≈øine≈øs to a≈ø≈øi≈øt your Petitioner; had not your Petitioner done this, the Common-wealth had lo≈øt every penny of this great trea≈øure.

The late Lord Protector Oliver, upon your Petitioners addre≈ø≈øes unto him, and after his daily attendance for above two years, with Petitions at Whitehall and Hampton Court, for his dearly earned reward, the rea≈øons wherefore the Protector delayed your Petitioner ≈øo long, before his reference touching this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, was (he knew the Referrees would certifie the debt, and that he knew I could prove his particular Promi≈øe, for the paying of your Petitioner eleven thou≈øand pounds for this ≈øervice which he made me at the Cock pit at Whitehall, before Col. Bingham and Mr. Sadler, who were of the then Councel of State, and brought me to him, to give him a particular Account what your Petitioner had done
in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, your Petitioner by his importunity and daily attendance, following him every day, got his Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver at la≈øt, to referre the afore≈øaid Petition to Col. Bark≈øtead Lieut. of the Tower, Mr. Alderman Vyner, Capt. John Limbery, Doctor Walker Advocate for his Highne≈ø≈øe, Gabriel Beck, Serjeant Dendy, Maurice Thom≈øon Trea≈øurer of the Ea≈øt-India Company, Serjeant Middleton, I≈øaac Dori≈ølawes E≈øquires, or any three or more of them, to take your Petitioners Petition into their con≈øideration, to examine all the premi≈ø≈øes, and thereupon to ≈øtate and certifie your Petitioners ca≈øe, (to his late Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver Lord Protector,) together with their opinions upon the whole matter, touching your Petitioners reward and ≈øatisfaction for this ≈øervice, as appears by the original Petition and Reference.

body.p:
All the aforenamed Referrees upon reading this Petition, and the tran≈øactions thereupon, after many dayes meeting, held it very nece≈ø≈øarie for the clearing of the truth, to acquaint the Lord Brad≈øhaw, Sir James Harrington, Sir George Fleetwood, and Francis Allen E≈øquires, with your Petitioners Petition, and his Highne≈ø≈øe Reference thereupon, in regard your Petitioner had named all the afore≈øaid Honourable perjons in his Petitions and Papers, among≈øt others, who both knew your Petitioners ≈øervices, touching the ≈øtaying this ≈øilver, and were privie to the Councel of States Ingagements and Intentions, to pay your Petitioner eleven thou≈øand pounds, when your Petitioner undertook to di≈øprove the Spani≈øh and Flemi≈øh Claimers. And upon Con≈øideration of the Councels promi≈øe to your Petitioner,
as afore≈øaid, was the cau≈øe that made your Petitioner undertake this difficult, chargeable and dangerous ≈øervice. And the afore≈øaid referrees received Certificates from everie one of the afore≈øaid honorable per≈øons, which Certificates ≈øet forth the great ≈øervice done by your Petitioner, viz. That your Petitioner was upon his fir≈øt undertaking of this Bu≈øine≈øs looked on by the then Councel of State as the Great Wheel that ≈øet all on work, and ≈øet on foot this di≈øcovery in getting the State this great Trea≈øure, or el≈øe the State had lo≈øt it in the Admiraltie, and that the≈øe Actings of your Petitioner, accompanied with great charge, hazzard and trouble, was the Cau≈øe (≈øine qua non) of the after-benefit received by the State upon conver≈øion of this ≈øilver. That the Councel of States Ingagements and intentions to the Petitioner, at his fir≈øt a≈ø≈øuming the imploiment, was not without good rea≈øon uncommitted to writing, for avoiding of mi≈øcon≈øtruction.

p.hi: And the Councel of State did not onely promi≈øe the Petitioner the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate for his particular ≈øervice of ≈øtaying the Silver, but did al≈øo promi≈øe to confer upon the Petitioner an Honorable Memorial, and had not the Petitioner had a real a≈ø≈øurance from the Councel of State in 1652. for the paying of him the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, the whole Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe touching this Silver had been lo≈øt and left undertaken, had not the Petitioner had ≈øuch an in≈øurance and promi≈øe, and al≈øo relied on the ≈øame for a ju≈øt Performance.

body.p: It is true, they certifie that for ≈øome Rea≈øons of State the Petitioners (Thomas Violets) a≈ø≈øurance and reward was not committed to writing, to avoid clamour and lewd tongues, but this omi≈øsion was not to fru≈øtrate the Petitioner of his dearly earn'd Reward, the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, or eleven thou≈øand pounds.

div.p: The≈øe are but the Heads of the afore≈øaid Certificates, the Originals certifie all matters touching this Bu≈øine≈øs at large, under the hands of the Lord Brad≈øhaw, Sir James Harrington, Sir George Fleetwood, Francis Allen E≈øquires, every per≈øon ≈øeverally certifies all the afore≈øaid referrees their particular knowledge of this Bu≈øine≈øs.

Col. Bark≈øtead, Sir Thomas Viner, and all the beforenamed Referrees, upon con≈øideration of the≈øe Certificates, and upon ≈øight of the atte≈øtation of the Officers of the Mint, and ≈øeveral other Witne≈ø≈øes, who depo≈øe, That Thomas Violet was ≈øeveral times offered, and might have received from the Claimers of Silver, (Merchants of Flanders then in London) the ≈øumme of ten thou≈øand pounds to have de≈øi≈øted the pro≈øecution of this Bu≈øine≈øs in the Court of Admiralty, and to have betrayed the tru≈øt which the Councel of State impo≈øed on him, to make a di≈øcovery of Spani≈øh and Flemi≈øh fraudulent Claimes; and al≈øo upon ≈øight of ≈øeveral orders of the Councel of State, the Judges of the Admiralty, and Doctor Walker, and ≈øeveral depo≈øitions taken in the Petitioners ca≈øe, upon the whole matter all the afore≈øaid Referrees certifie his late Highne≈øs Oliver Lord Protector; viz.

That upon Examination of Thomas Violets Petition, they finde that the Petitioner is a per≈øon who not onely de≈øervs the making good of the Councel of States Ingagement and Promi≈øe unto him, for the true paying your Petitioner Tho. Violet, the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, but upon due con≈øideration had of the great Travel, Charge, and Hazard, which your Petitioner hath undergone in
the Pro≈øecution of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and your Petitioners great faithfulne≈øs in refu≈øing to be corrupted, or betray the intere≈øt of the Common-wealth, as hath been fully proved unto them, as al≈øo upon the Atte≈øtation of Sir George Fleetwood and Sir James Harrington, concerning the Promi≈øe of the Councel of State to your Petitioner Tho. Violet, for the re≈øtoration to him his e≈øtate, or eleven thou≈øand pounds, all the≈øe Referrees report to his late Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver Lord Protector, that they humbly conceive upon the whole matter of Fact, that over and above the payment of eleven thou≈øand pounds: that there be ≈øome ≈øignal reward conferred on the Petitioner for this his eminent ≈øervice, that all other for the future may be encouraged to ≈øerve the intere≈øt of the Common-wealth, with that ≈øingular faithfulne≈øs and integrity, as the Petitioner hath done, and they all certifie that they finde, It proved that the Petitioner by his chargeable pro≈øecution of this bu≈øine≈øs in the Court of Admiralty, hath contracted debts, amounting unto the ≈øumme of ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds, which the Petitioner borrowed at intere≈øt, all his own e≈øtate being under ≈øeque≈øtration ever ≈øince 1643. be≈øides ≈øeveral other great ≈øummes of money your Petitioner borrowed at intere≈øt for his ≈øupport ever ≈øince his ≈øeque≈øtration, upon con≈øideration whereof they finde the Petitioners Engagements are very pre≈ø≈øing upon him, and they all humblie offer, that for the pre≈øent, le≈øt the Petitioner ≈øhould be thrown into pri≈øon, for the very moneys he hath expended in getting the Common-wealth this great trea≈øure of two hundred
≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds, the ju≈øt accompt thereof they had ≈øeen pre≈øented unto them by Col. Bark≈øtead.

That his Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver Lord Protector, in con≈øideration of all the Premi≈ø≈øes, would be plea≈øed pre≈øently to pay the Petitioner Tho. Violet, ≈øome con≈øiderable ≈øum of money to pay off his great engagements for the State, and for his ≈øupport for the future, according to his quality, and that the remainder of the money to make up the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds be paid unto him according to the Promi≈øe of the Councel of State, the Petitioner Tho. Violet, having ≈øerved the Common-wealth in this great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, with a great deal of re≈øolution, faithfulne≈øs and activity. This Report is at large ≈øigned and certified to his late Highne≈øs, Oliver Lord Protector, the fir≈øt of May 1658. by Col. Bark≈øtead Lieutenant of the Tower, Mr. Alderman Vyner, Gabriel Beck, John Limbery, Edward Denly, Henry Middleton, Maurice Thom≈øon, Trea≈øurer of the Ea≈øt-India Company, I≈øaac Dori≈ølaws, as appears by the original Certificate.

Your Petitioner petitioned the late Lord Protector Oliver 29. July 1658. and annexed the aforenamed Report of the Referrees, and petitioned to be paid the ≈øum of eleven thou≈øand pound. The Lord Protector Oliver, upon reading the afore≈øaid Petition, and the Report annexed, refers your Petitioner for ≈øatisfaction, together with the Report of Col. Bark≈øtead, Sir Tho Vyner, and others, for your Petitioners ≈øatisfaction unto his privy Councel, that they take con≈øideration of all the maters therein contained,
≈øo that the Petitioner may have and receive ≈øatisfaction according to Ju≈øtice and Equity for this ≈øervice 29. July 1658. but his death ≈øhortly following, nothing as yet hath been done for your Petitioners ≈øatisfaction.

Your Petitioner thereupon in Octob. 1658. petitioned the late Lord Protector Richard for his ≈øatisfaction, and annexed the afore≈øaid Reports and Petitions (upon his Highne≈ø≈øe peru≈øal of the ≈øame) he was plea≈øed to referre the ≈øame unto the con≈øideration of Francis Bacon late Ma≈øter of his Reque≈øts, and Gabriel Beck E≈øquires, Solicitor to the late Councel of State; They after many dayes meeting concerning this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, have certified accordingly, as Col. Bark≈øtead, and the former Referrees have done, viz. for the due paying your Petitioner the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and that they hold the Petitioner to be a per≈øon very fit and u≈øeful to be employed in removing the ob≈øtructions of the Mint, and that the Petitioner be employed for regulating the Manufacture of gold and ≈øilver Wyre and Lace, which Certificates are here to be produced to your Honours, ≈øigned by Francis Bacon and Gabriel Beck E≈øquires, 18 Jan. 1658.

Your Petitioner humbly prayes your Honours to take into con≈øideration the great and eminent advantages your Petitioner did this Common wealth in ≈øtaying this ≈øilver, at that juncture of time in Decemb. 1652. for had that ≈øilver come into the hands of the Dutch, they would have laid it all out in powder and ≈øhot agaiu≈øt this Common-wealth, as we employed it again≈øt them, as will
appear by Col. Bark≈øteads Accompts, which moneys under God was a principal mean to reduce the Dutch; what ≈øervice this trea≈øure did the Nation in that juncture of time, Chri≈øtendome knowes, the Dutch then our enemies felt, and this Common wealth at this day enjoys the happy fruit of it.

But had all advantages been home followed again≈øt the Dutch in the la≈øt War, we had grubbed up their greatne≈ø≈øe by the roots, and flayed his Zealand Lions skin, and broken their ≈øheaf of Arrows to ≈øhivers, making them unable for ever to trouble us, (but we only pared their nailes, and parted with them upon too gentle conditions, and made ≈øuch a peace with them, that at this time they carry all our Trade from our Merchants in a manner, and do us more damage by being our feined friends, then they could do being our open enemies, the due con≈øideration thereof is humbly hinted here to your Honours. And if your Honours require a more particular Accompt, I can demon≈øtrate it to you in many particulars.

p.hi:
The≈øe Certificats, though they doe declare the truth of your Petitioners ≈øervice really performed, by a great number of Witne≈ø≈øes, yet without further con≈øideration they pay not your Petitioners engagements, which were disbur≈øed by him for the accompli≈øhment of this ≈øervice; and tho≈øe Gentlemen that have lent their moneys reallie to your Petitioner, to enable him to do this ≈øervice, look for real payment in moneys, and not in words, your Petitioners engagement at this daie for this
bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of ≈øtaying of the ≈øilver, being above fifteen hundred pounds.

St. James ≈øaith what profit is it, if a Brother be naked or de≈øtitute of daily food, for one to ≈øay to him, be thou warmed, and bee thou filled, if he ≈øupply him not with food and raiment, ≈øo likewi≈øe a bare Certificate, without further ≈øupply, will neither pay debts, nor cloath, nor feed a man, many words will not fill a bagg, (it is Ju≈øtice that e≈øtabli≈øheth a Nation, and payment of money quits debts, and not words)

body.p:
What a ≈øhame would it bee to tho≈øe, that profe≈ø≈øe ≈øo much Ju≈øtice, and reformation, as this age doth, to have it left to po≈øterity and record, That your Petitioner that hath done this Common-wealth ≈øuch an eminent ≈øervice, in getting them more money then any man in this Nation ever did before, ≈øhould not be ju≈øtly rewarded, according to the promi≈øe and ingagements of the Council of State, which made your Petitioner undertake this chargable, difficult, and dangerous ≈øervice, your Petitioner might have had tenn thou≈øand pounds from the Claimers, to have held his peace and bin quiet, and to ≈øuffer the Judges of the Admiraltie, to let this Silver pa≈ø≈øe, the truth of this is certified under the hands of many per≈øons of quality, had your Petitioner taken this cour≈øe, to have bin bribed off, it had bin mo≈øt for his ea≈øe but le≈ø≈øe for his hone≈øty. The Common-wealths intere≈øt, and his own reputation, in making good his promi≈øe and ingagement to the Lord Brad≈øhaw and Council of State he valued more then his life; your Petitioner hath done his duty, and will leave the i≈ø≈øue to God. 'tis Solomon that ≈øaith a poor man delivered the City, yet no man remembred the poor man, when he had done his work. I humbly
hope that your Honours Ju≈øtice will prevent mee, that I may not have occa≈øion to ≈øay the ≈øame, that is true of this Age, or leave ≈øo ≈øad a memorandum of the ingratitude of the≈øe times. If the Rules of our Saviour were ob≈øerved by men of power in this Nation at this day, to do to all People, as they would be done unto, your Petitioner ≈øhould not have bin ≈øo long from time to time delayed with references, in ≈øo Ju≈øt and equitable Petition.

p.hi: If your Petitioner hath not this his dearly earned reward, it will remain to po≈øterity in print, to fright and terrifie all per≈øons, and make them wary how they ingage for the future, upon Engli≈øh States-mens promi≈øes, when they ≈øhall ≈øee and read the≈øe Tran≈øactions and Certificates, If your Petitioner hath not ≈øatisfaction according to Ju≈øtice, it would be a means to make other men to take money when it is offered, and not to tru≈øt to Engli≈øh States mens promi≈øes.

body.p: About the 20. of April 1659. your Petitioner did ingage an Honourable per≈øon, to pre≈øent to the Lord Richard Cromwell the late Protector the≈øe very Petitions and Certificates, which I now pre≈øent unto your Honours in print, I am credibly informed, upon his peru≈øal of them, hee was mo≈øt honourably plea≈øed to be verie ≈øen≈øible of your Petitioners ≈øad ≈øufferings, great expence, paines and fidelitie for the Common-wealth in this ≈øervice.

And that ≈øeeing all this Trea≈øure (which your Petitioner ≈øtopt in the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador and George) was imploied and ≈øpent in the defence of the Common-wealth, his late Highne≈ø≈øe was plea≈øed to declare, to an Honourable per≈øon that informed mee your Petitioner, his late Highne≈ø≈øe did think my
promi≈øed reward to be a ju≈øt debt, and that the Commonwealth ought to pay it, and had not the Government beene changed, I am a≈ø≈øured from ≈øeveral honourable per≈øons, his late Highne≈øs the Lord Richard Cromwell would have ≈øeen mee ju≈øtlie paid the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and given me an honourable reward and Imploiment over and above.

div.p: Your Petitioner implores your Honours to con≈øider of all his premi≈ø≈øes, and that as your Petitioner did this Nation the greate≈øt ≈øervice, that ever was done by any man of his condition, in ≈øaveing this Commonwealth two hundred ≈øeventie eight thou≈øand pounds, which was all imployed in defence of this Commonwealth.

Your Petitioners humble prayer is, after ≈øo long a delay of Ju≈øtice, he may have his dearly earned reward, the payment of the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, in ≈øuch wayes and in ≈øuch maner, as your Petitioner may be inabled to pay off the great ingagements he hath layd out in this ≈øervice, and to ≈øupport him≈øelf according to his quality, and that others ≈øeeing your Ju≈øtice, may for the future bee incouraged to ≈øerve the intere≈øt of the Nation, with that integrity, activity, and faithfullne≈ø≈øe as your Petitioner hath done, with the hazard of his life, and all that hee had dear in this world, your Petitioner having ingaged his Credit, and borrowed above fifteen hundred pounds which hee expended every penny in this ≈øervice, and in his attendance to ge ‚Ä¢ t ≈øatisfaction, and at this day oweth the ≈øumme at intere≈øt,
to ≈øave and gett the State this great Trea≈øure, be≈øides all his paines and hazard.

body.p: The≈øe ≈øeveral Services and Propo≈øals done by your Petitioner, for the honour and profit of the Common wealth, your Honours will ≈øee them certified under the hands of the Lord Brad≈øhaw, Sir James Harrington, Sir George Fleetwood, and Francis Allen E≈øquire, and that your Petitioner was faithfully promi≈øed the re≈øtoration of his e≈øtate, by divers members of Parliament and Councel of State, for ≈øeveral chargeable ≈øervices your Petitioner had done the Parliament ≈øome years before, from the year 1648 to 1652. before your Petitioner undertook to ≈øtay the ≈øilver in the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and this is clearly demon≈øtrated by the ≈øaid Certificates.

p.hi: But upon your Petitioners happy and ≈øucce≈ø≈øful ≈øtaying of this ≈øilver, and undertaking at his own charge to pro≈øecute this di≈øcogery in the Admiralty, upon the Promi≈øe of the Councel of State 1652 to pay your Petitioner the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds for this ≈øervice, in lieu of his ≈øeque≈øtred e≈øtate, which for ≈øo many yeares your Petitioner had ≈øolicited both the Councel of State and Parliament to have it.

body.p:
Sir James Harrington, and Sir George Fleetwood, fully and clearly certifie, that they think them≈øelves bound in honour and con≈øcience, to certifie the truth of their knowledge to his Highne≈ø≈øe Referrees, according to their Reque≈øt and De≈øire, concerning the Councel of States promi≈øes and engagements to pay your Petitioner the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, that ≈øo your Petitioner may have his dearly earned reward for this
great ≈øervice, and not labour for the State in vain; And that if the rule of the Go≈øpel were ob≈øerved to do to other men as they would be done unto, your Petitioner could not be many weeks without receiving eleven thou≈øand pounds, and over and above an honorable reward and memoriall from the State for this great ≈øervice, and that the State in Honour and Ju≈øtice, was obliged to pay your Petitioner the above ≈øaid ≈øumme, and that no doubt but ≈øo faithfull a ≈øervice, ≈øo carefully and painfully performed would have a happy i≈ø≈øue, and the Petitioners reward from the State would bee ≈øutable to the greatne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øervice, upon peru≈øal of Sir James Harrington, and Sir George Fleetwoods Certificates, your Honours will ≈øee this more fully ≈øet down and amplified; The Lord Brad≈øhawes Certificate for the ≈øub≈øtance is to the ≈øame effect, ≈øo is Francis Allens E≈øquire, who being a Gold≈ømith knew experimentally the great abilities in your Petitioner, to regulate and reforme the abu≈øes in the Mint, and the ≈øervices and overtures of your Petitioner. 1650. 1651. 1652. offered the Councel of State both to ≈øet the Mint on work, and to give a ≈øtop to the tran≈øporting of Trea≈øure, he certifies your Petitioner had taken great paines, and ≈øpent much money in this bu≈øine≈øs, (which had the humble advice and propo≈øition of your Petitioner then bin taken by the Parliament) you had filled the Nation at this day with Gold and Silver, and con≈øtantly imployed your Mint to the great honour and profit of the Nation, for all the Warr with Spain.

p.hi:
Your Petitioner at this day humbly offers to ≈øet the Mint on work ≈øo he may be imployed, and not labour for the State in vaine, for your Petitioner to take the paines and bee at
the Charge, and other per≈øons who have no ≈økill in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, to run away with the profit: Your Petitioner hath too often bin ≈øo ≈øerved by great men in power, and ≈øhall not do it againe for any ones plea≈øure who≈øoever.

body.p:
Thus have I humbly pre≈øented my ≈øervices done for the State, and the Councils ingagements and promi≈øe for your Petitioners ≈øatisfaction. It is a Rule ≈øet down by God and all Nations, Chri≈øtians, Turkes, and Jewes, that there are degrees of rewards for vertue, and degrees of puni≈øhments for vice, the degrees of Puni≈øhments and Rewards are in all well-regulated Kingdomes and Common wealths put down, and the people know them that ≈øo they may not offend; and there is no offence to be ju≈øtly puni≈øhed, either by Gods Law or Mans, before a Law be made to give men the Rule, for the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, I had not known ≈øin but by the Law. And that puni≈øhment that is inflicted on a man, before a Law made to prohibit or re≈øtrain a man from doing the ≈øame, let it be inflicted by what Power ≈øoever, (mu≈øt needs be a very great affliction and puni≈øhment ≈øent of God for a mans other ≈øins) and cannot as to men be ≈øaid to be regularly done, e≈øpecially where the offence is taken, and the puni≈øhment ≈øo heavy, as it ≈øhall deprive a man of all his e≈øtate, and keep a man almo≈øt foure yeares a Pri≈øoner, in which time your Petitioner ≈øpent eight hundred pounds for charges, whereof nine hundred twenty eight dayes of that time, he was kept a clo≈øe Pri≈øoner, without ever being brought to a legal Trial, according to the Fundamental Lawes of the Nation by a Jury, the birth-right of every Engli≈øhman rich or poor; but after a mans e≈øtate is ≈øquandred, di≈øpo≈øed, and given away to ≈øeveral Per≈øons and Committees, for particular mens profit, and
upon fal≈øe and untrue pretences, to the value of above eleven thou≈øand pounds, as your Petitioner for many yeares hath proued and pre≈øented to the Councel of State and Parliament, ever ≈øince the year 1648. being much about the time your Petitioner was turned out of the Tower, without any legal Trial or Rea≈øon given for his Commitment, or the taking away of his E≈øtate contrary to Magna Charta, and all the Laws of this Nation.

p.hi: God having given your Petitioner his freedom, your Petitioner pre≈øentlie, to ≈øhew that he was oppre≈ø≈øed, and the Parliament mi≈øinformed, and his e≈øtate unduly taken away, given and di≈øpo≈øed of upon fal≈øe and untrue pretences, for particular mens profit, to ≈øeveral Committees and others, the Petitioner did humblie addre≈ø≈øe him≈øelf for relief, to many honourable Members of Parliament and Councel of State, and pre≈øented them with the true e≈øtate of his ≈øufferings in Print.

body.p: The Cau≈øe of your Petitioners ≈øufferings was for bringing up a Letter from Oxford 1643. from the late King, who had then a de≈øire to emploie, and make your Petitioner Ma≈øter-worker of his Mint at Oxford; which place the King did give me there, and the Petitioner had an Order from the Hou≈øe of Parliament, and a Pa≈ø≈øe from the Lord General E≈ø≈øex, about the 28. of Decemb. 1643. to go to Oxford to the King, upon condition to put in ≈øecurity in a thou≈øand pounds, which ≈øecurity I did accordingly give, to make good my Exchange for one Mr. He≈øilrigge, and did accordingly bring up my Exchange to London, and left it with Sir Arthur He≈øilrigge, about the 3. of Jan. 1643.

And the late King Charles, upon my Exchange as afore≈øaid, commanded me to bring up a Letter from him to the Lord Mayor,
Court of Aldermen, and Common-Councel of the City of London. I do confe≈ø≈øe I honoured and loved the late King, for many benefits received from him, and it was my dutie to obey him as my King, though I had never received benefits from him; but had I known there had been any Act or Order of Parliament to prohibite me or any other to bring up the ≈øaid Letter at that time, or that the Parliament would have taken any offence again≈øt me for doing thereof, my principles at that time, and the whole cour≈øe of my Actions ≈øince, hath clearlie demon≈øtrated to your Honours and the World, that I would have humblie declined that emploiment; for I have ever been an Honourer of the Parliament and my Countrie, as this Narrative will demon≈øtrate to po≈øteritie.

The Tree is known by its fruit, and no man I humblie conceive in the Nation of my condition, hath yielded better fruit, or ever got the Common wealth two hundred ≈øeventie eight thou≈øand pounds in ≈øilver, but your Petitioner. At the ≈øame in≈øtant of time Van Trump was in the Downes with the Dutch Fleet, upon the clearing of the≈øe ≈øhips out of the Admiraltie, to have conveyed them to Holland. This was a real Plot, not a feined one, as appears by the Commi≈ø≈øions this day in the Court of Admiraltie, under the Great Seal of Holland, to De Weet and De Ruyter, their Vice-Admirals, to guard the≈øe ≈øhips from the Engli≈øh, upon the Petitions of the Merchants of Am≈øterdam. I pray God England never forgets this deliverance nor the Councel of State the Performance of their Promi≈øe to your Petitioner for this di≈øcovery, your Petitioner going in danger of his life by the Claimers for ≈øeveral yeares for doing of this ≈øervice.

body.head: To Our Trusty and Wel-beloved, Our Lord Mayor and Aldermen of Our City of London, and all other Our well-effected Subjects of that City.
body.p:
TRu≈øtie amd Well beloved, wee greet you well: When wee remember the many Acts of Grace and Favour Wee and Our Royal Predece≈ø≈øors have conferred upon that our Citie of London, and the many examples of eminent Duty and Loyaltie, for which that City hath been likwi≈øe famous; Wee are willing to believe (notwith≈øtanding the great defection wee have found in that place) That all men are not ≈øo farr degenerate from their affection to ∆≤s, and to the peace of the Kingdom, as to de≈øire a continuance of the mi≈øeries they now feel: And therefore beeing informed, That there is a de≈øire in ≈øome principal per≈øons of that City to pre≈øent a Petition to ∆≤s, which may tend to the procuring a good under≈øtanding between ∆≤s and that Our City, whereby the peace of the whole Kingdom may bee procured; Wee have thought fit to let you know, That wee are ready to receive any ≈øuch Petition, and the Per≈øons who ≈øhall bee appointed to pre≈øent the ≈øame to ∆≤s ≈øhall have a ≈øafe conduct: And you ≈øhall a≈ø≈øure all our good Subjects of that Our City (who≈øe hearts are touched with any ≈øen≈øe of Duty to ∆≤s, or of Love to the Religion and Laws e≈øtabli≈øhed; in
the quiet and peaceable fruition whereof, They and their Ance≈øtors have enjoyed ≈øo great Happine≈øs), That wee have neither pa≈ø≈øed any Act, nor made any Profe≈ø≈øion or Prote≈øtation for the maintenance and defence of the true Prote≈øtant Religion, and the Liberties of the Subject, which wee will not mo≈øt ≈øtrictly and religiou≈øly ob≈øerve; And for the which, wee will not bee alwaies ready to give them any ≈øecurity that can bee de≈øired: And of tho≈øe Our gracious Letters, Wee expect a ≈øpeedy An≈øwer from you. And ≈øo Wee bid you farewell.
