[I do mo≈øt humbly de≈øire the Common Council of the Citie of London, to certifie your Honours, if ever (among≈øt all their Records, ever ≈øince the foundation of their City) they find ≈øuch a ≈øad Pre≈øident as mine is; And whether that any Me≈ø≈øenger from any former King of England ≈øuffered the lo≈øs of his E≈øtate (to his damage at this day above twenty thou≈øand pound, for bringing them or any their Ance≈øtors the like Letter for peace, as I did from the late KING. And at that time (viz. in December 30. 1643.) there was ≈øent and came from Oxford the Writs weekly under the Great Seal of England without any Countermand: My hard u≈øage Afterages
will hardly believe, had I not Printed it to Po≈øterity, that it may ≈øerve as a warning to prevent other Per≈øons, from beeing got in the like Snares for the future.] For this cau≈øe

I Suffered Impri≈øonment in the Tower almo≈øt four years, for bringing up the afore≈øaid Letter from Oxford to the Lord Mayor and Common Council of the City of London in December 1643. although I had an Order from the Hou≈ø of Commons (as appears by their Journal Book) and a Pa≈øs from the Lord General E≈ø≈øex to go to Oxford; for an exchange for Mr. He≈øilrigge, Sir Arthur He≈øilrige his Brother, and I left my Exchange with Sir Arthur He≈øilrigge, about the 2. of January 1643. which were both procured for mee by Mr. Theophilus Ryley Scout-ma≈øter General of the City of London, who was authorized to execute that place by the Common Council of London; and I was authorized by the ≈øaid Mr. Ryley to do the ≈øame (Mr. Ryley being impowered by the Parliament and Common Council of London to hold Intelligence in any the Kings Quarters, as by his Orders hee ≈øhewed me:) Mr. Ryley was a man of a known & approved Integritie, and in great e≈øteem with the then Parliament and Citie of London at that time, and would not have acted any thing but what was Ju≈øt, and for the Parliaments ≈øervice, according to his Tru≈øt. (If hee had thought it otherwi≈øe, if hee might have gotten a hundred thou≈øand
pounds, upon my con≈øcience) and that made mee to act this Bu≈øine≈øs, to bring up the Kings Letter upon his Intreaty (as hee confe≈ø≈øed upon his Examination;) and I ju≈øtified my doing thereof by his Order, hee beeing a publick Mini≈øter, and impowered to do it, as hee told mee. And al≈øo the Committee of both Nations was made acquainted with my going to Oxford, for the bringing up the ≈øaid Letter which I brought from the late King (by Sir David Watkins Knight, I de≈øired him to make the Parliament acquainted therwith, before ever I went to Oxford, and to have their approbation;) which Sir David Watkins (after he had ≈øpoken with them) told mee, I had their approbation to go to Oxford: And all this was done before any Law or Ordinance was made or declared to forbid mee or any other to do the ≈øame (that ever I heard of:) or to this day can hear of, and I humbly ≈øay, That before a Law made, there is no tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, neither by Gods law nor Mans law. And I was not to que≈øtion Mr. Ryleys power, abilities and tru≈øt, con≈øidering hee acted as a publick Mini≈øter, but to act according to his direction, ≈øo long as hee was in the ≈øaid Office of Scout-ma≈øter, I having his Warrant and approbation for doing what I did. I have never read nor heard of ≈øo heavy a puni≈øhment as your Supplicant doth ≈øuffer under, before a Law made to give a man warning, to take heed how hee Tran≈øgre≈øs.

And by the Statutes of 9. Hen. 3. cap 29. 5 Edw. 3. cap. 9. and 28. Edw. 3. cap. 3. No per≈øon (of what
e≈øtate or condition ≈øoever hee bee) ≈øhall bee put out of Land or Tenement, nor taken, nor impri≈øoned, nor di≈øinherited, without being brought to an≈øwer by due proce≈øs of the Law; which I have Petitioned for, by a legal trial many years, but could never obtain the ≈øame.

May it plea≈ø your Honours, Had there been a Proclamation or Act of Parliament at that time to have prohibited mee, I ≈øhould have then been afraid; be≈øides, Mr. Ryley ≈øhould never have made mee act again≈øt a declared Law, nor the King neither.

Now, forasmuch as your humble Supplicant having ever ≈øince his Inlargement out of the Tower, made it his daily practice to ≈øtudy to ≈øerve the Commonwealth, and doing ≈øuch remarkable Services (as afore≈øaid) for the Common-welath, I do mo≈øt humbly implore your Honours mo≈øt gratious Order for the re≈øtoring mee to my afore≈øaid e≈øtate with damages, or the paying your Supplicant the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, according to the promi≈øe of the Council of State. 1652.

May it plea≈øe your Honours, If I would have betraied my Tru≈øt to the Common-wealth, about this Silver that was in the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, I could have had every penny of eleven thou≈øand pounds paid mee by the Claimers of the Silver in tho≈øe Ships; either in money here, or Bills of Exchange beyond
Seas: that money would have made mee live plentifully in any part of Chri≈øtendom. I do mo≈øt humbly implore your Honours, that I may have ≈øuch Justice by your Honours goodne≈øs and benignity, as I may have cau≈øe never to repent of my being faithfull to your Honours and the Commonwealths Intere≈øt in this particular, concerning the Silver Ships, their Silver and Lading.

I mo≈øt humbly here pre≈øent an Accompt of what hath been taken from me Tho. Violet; for which I mo≈øt humbly de≈øire ≈øatisfaction, with my damages, or the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, as was faithfully promi≈øed unto me by the mo≈øt Honourable Councel of State, in December and January 1652. for ≈øtaying the ≈øilver in the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and di≈øproving the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors Claim to this ≈øilver, which was above three hundred
thou≈øand pounds, my damages at this day by the taking my E≈øtate 1643. is above twenty thou≈øand pounds 25. May 1659. viz.

body.p: VVHen I was fir≈øt ≈øent unto the Tower the 6th. of January 1643. my mother had of mine good Bonds and Bills in her hands taken away from her at ≈øeveral times, to the value of one thou≈øand three hundred and odd pounds; Be≈øides many of my Papers and accompts of great concernment to the Common-welath; and as yet I cannot come to the knowledg who hath them: But this I am ≈øure of, If there had been any thing in them that could have made again≈øt mee, there had then u≈øe been made of them.

2. My mother had at another time a Privy Seal taken from her, wherein the late King acknowledged hee owed me (for my expences in di≈øcovering the Tran≈øporters of Gold and Silver) nineteen hundred three≈øcore and eight pounds, which money I laid every penny out of my own pur≈øe to do the late King and Common-wealth that ≈øervice: in pro≈øecuting the Tran≈øporters of Gold and Silver, in the Star chamber I cau≈øed them to be fined twenty fowre thou≈øand one hundred pounds, be≈øides ≈øeveral Merchants and others, who had their pardons from the late King, for tran≈øporting
Gold and Silver, and melting down the heavie≈øt Silver Coynes of England, viz. Alderman Wolla≈øton, and Alderman Gibbs, Mr. Peter Fountain and ≈øeveral other Merchants, the terror of which ≈øentence and puni≈øhment, for ≈øome yeers did give a ≈øtop to tran≈øporting of Gold and Silver, to the great ≈øervice and advantage of the Common-wealth, and if the Parliament plea≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe the Act again≈øt Tran≈øporting Gold and Silver which has twi≈øe this Parliament been read in the Hou≈øe, and ≈øeveral times Committed, and impower your Petitioner to ≈øee to the due execution thereof, your Petitioner will give a ≈øtop to the Tran≈øportation of Gold and Silver, and di≈øcover the Offendors, if a Commi≈ø≈øion be granted to make enquiry of the ≈øame, according to former Pre≈øidents in Richard the Seconds time, by Act of Parliament.

This Parliament was ≈øo careful to have the≈øe Offences pro≈øecuted, that they excepted them out of the general Pardon, being the de≈øire of the Committee of the Mint, as appears by this following Order.

AT a Committee of the Councel of State for the Mint, this inclo≈øed exception was pre≈øented to the Committee to have it in≈øerted in the generall Pardon. The Committee do hold it fit, for the benefit of the Common-wealth, to have this exception in≈øerted
in that Pardon, and doe recommend it to you accordingly.

p.hi: viz.

body.p: EXcept all offences done or committed by any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever, in tran≈øporting out of England any Gold or Silver, in coyne or in bullion without Licen≈øe, and all other offences in the unlawfull buying, ≈øelling, exchanging or melting down of any the current gold or ≈øilver coynes of England, or of any gold or ≈øilver bullion, again≈øt whom, or for which, any Information is now depending in the Court of Exchequer at We≈øtmin≈øter.

Ordered that Ma≈øter Thomas Violet attend M. Attorney Generall with this Order of the Committee, and al≈øo the Committee of Parliament for drawing the generall Pardon to have the≈øe offences excepted.

div.p: Your Petitioner did deliver this Order, to Mr. Attorney Generall, and this exception is put into the generall Pardon of this Parliament, as may bee ≈øeen upon peru≈øal.

3. The Committee of E≈ø≈øex put mee out of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Mannors of Battells and Patan-Hall in E≈ø≈øex, as appears by their Warrants. Of which Lands I had an Extent of One thou≈øand pounds, for the payment of five hundred: and one Mr. Elconhead received
my rents ever ≈øince 1643, and never paid the Committee of E≈ø≈øex any thing, for your Petitioners Extent of five hundred pounds, and the ≈øame Elconhead injoyes your Petitioners Lands in E≈ø≈øex to this very day, by colour of the Seque≈øtration of the Committee of E≈ø≈øex, to your Petitioners great damage.

4. The Committee of Shrop≈øhire ≈øeized, in my ≈øi≈øters hands, in London, three Bonds due to mee, in two thou≈øand pounds for the payment to mee Thomas Violet One thou≈øand pounds, by the Lady Anne Waad, Edmond Lenthal, Phillip Cage and Charles Mordent E≈øq's. 1643. which Bonds were carried to Shrewsbury.

5. I had the Lea≈ø and Extent of ten ≈øeverall Hou≈øes at the Po≈øterne in Little Moor-fields; and the Tennants owed mee, when I was committed to the Tower, in arrears for rent above one hundred pounds: And for the≈øe ≈øixteen years, I received no Rent of them. But one Mr. Elconhead hath received the Rents of them ever ≈øince, by colour of a Seque≈øtration of the Committee of Middle≈øex.

6. I had the Office of ≈øealing and ≈øurveying of all gold and ≈øilver Thread and Wyer: which prevented the making of all ≈øleight and adulterate gold and ≈øilver Thread, and Wyer, granted to mee under the Great Seal, for three Lives, from the Late King; which Office co≈øt mee Fifteen hundred pounds (to the Lord Trea≈øurer Juxon, L. Cottingon, Sir. John Cook: Secretary of State, and Sir John Bankes the late Kings Attourney. The nece≈ø≈øitie of keeping up that Office, to prevent the daily Cozenages and frauds of divers Silkmen,
Wyerdrawers and Refiners in their making Cour≈ø, ≈øleight and deceitfull Gold and Silver Wyer and Thread: Your Petitioner formerly pre≈øented unto your Honours, and can prove it that forty thou≈øand pounds a year in ≈øilver is wa≈øted, be≈øides the Wearers daily Cozened for want of a due Regulation of gold and ≈øilver Thread, and Lace.

And upon the Di≈øcovery of the≈øe notorious Cheats, 1635. (the late King and his Council appointed mee Surveyor and Sealer of the ≈øaid Manufacture) I cau≈øed all the abu≈øes to bee laid a≈øide: I indicted ≈øome offenders, impri≈øoned ≈øome, cau≈øed others to ≈øtand in the Pillory, and made many of them that wrought adulterate cour≈ø ≈øilver run away out of London: By which means I angred many Cheating Wyerdrawers, Silkmen and Refiners: and the late Kings Council and Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øetled ≈øuch Rules and Orders, during the Regulation of the Manufacture, as it was all made of good ≈øilver, and the Coin and Bullion of this Nation pre≈øerved; and your Supplicant was bound, to the late King, to warrant all the Manufactures either of gold or Silver, Wyer or Thread which hee ≈øealed, or ≈øurveyed in the Office, to bee good ≈øilver, and to make it good to any party grieved in the Nation; as appears by my Patent under the Great Seal of England. For which A≈ø≈øurance, Surveying and Sealing, I was allowed to demand and take an half penny for every ounce Troy, in Wyer, Spangles, Oes, &c. I ≈øurveyed; and 4 pence for every pound weight Venice, for all the Gold and Silver Thread I ≈øealed with the Seal of my Office, being the Ro≈øe and Crown. And all that time the gold and ≈øilver Lace, was as good Silver and as duly a≈ø≈øaied as the
Plate or Money of the Nation, and now it is made under no Rule nor Government, but the Wearers many of them cheated by cour≈øe and deceitfull Lace, Wyer, ≈øilver Thread, as I can demon≈øtrate.

7. I had a Grant from the late King, under his Signet, to bee Ma≈øter-worker of the Mint in the Tower of London for my life, with the Fee of five hundred pounds a year, for executing that place; which Grant was taken from my Mother, out of her Cu≈øtody, when I was ≈øent to the Tower.

8. I had one quarter part of the Lady Villers Farm at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, for the Importation of all gold and Silver Thread, Hatbands, Lace, and Copper, throughout England and Wales; which co≈øt mee, a little before I was ≈øeque≈øtred, above ≈øeven hundred pounds. And if the making gold and ≈øilver thread was put down in England, the Cu≈øtom of gold and ≈øilver thread imported would make a farr greater Revenew then now it doth by the Exci≈øe; and the Manufacture, if it bee made here, ought to bee kept to a ≈øtrict Regulation. Mr. Edwards and Mr. Tbornbury I imploied to Collect this duty at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈ø.

9. I ≈øpent in my Impri≈øonment in the Tower for almo≈øt four years about eight hundred pounds, reckoning my Fees and Expences, and could never get Ju≈øtice, though I petitioned to the Parliament as afore≈øaid, for many years to come to a legall Triall, knowing my ≈øelf to bee innocent both by God's Law and the Laws of the Land; and by the te≈øtimony of a good con≈øcience,
which hath ever ≈øupported mee in and thorow all the≈øe great troubles. All this E≈øtate was and is Seque≈øtred, to this day; (but my three afore≈øaid bonds, which I now have in my Cu≈øtody,) be≈øides my damage for my four years Impri≈øonment.

10. Since I came out of the Tower, by order of the Councel of State 1652. your Petitioner laid out (in the Pro≈øecution of the Silver Ships, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George) above the ≈øumme of ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds, I borrowed every penny of this money, paying Intere≈øt for it at this day. And by my Prote≈øt again≈øt the Di≈øcharge of the≈øe ≈øilver Ships, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and my Di≈øcoveries thereupon, by many good and legal Witne≈ø≈øes, Pa≈ø≈øengers and others in the≈øe Ships: I cau≈øed all the Silver to become the Commonwealths: All which ≈øervices I did (upon the faithfull promi≈øe of the Councel of State) in Decemb. 1652 to re≈øtore mee to all my E≈øtate, or the full value of eleven thou≈øand pounds.

body.p:
John Corbet E≈øquire, one of the Members of this pre≈øent Parliament at this day, and one of the Committee of Shrop≈øhire, meeting with your Petitioner in March 1655. was noblie plea≈øed to take notice of your Petitioners good endeavours to ≈øerve the Common-wealth; and ≈øeeing that your Petitioner had put out in Print, a Li≈øt of his particular damages, and the particular Bonds, Hou≈øes, Lands, Offices, ≈øet down, which had been taken from your Petitioner his Mother and Si≈øter, who had then a great part of his e≈øtate in their Cu≈øtody, at the time of his impri≈øonment
in the Tower, and were plundred of it during that time of my Impri≈øonment there, by the title and name of Seque≈øtration.

This Noble Gentleman Mr. Corbet, being very ≈øen≈øible of my ≈øufferings, and how your Petitioners e≈øtate had bin ≈øquandred away, was plea≈øed to tell your Petitioner he could do him a courte≈øie, in procuring to your Petitioner three Bonds taken from your Petitioner in two thou≈øand pounds, for the payment of your Petitioner one thou≈øand pounds 1644, which Bonds Mr. Corbet told me were at Shrewsbury in Shrop≈øhire, morgaged by that Committee for fourty pounds, which the Committee had laid out for publick u≈øe.

Your Petitioner was glad to hear where the≈øe Bonds were, and to know who had them, though they day in Lavender for fourty pounds, your Petitioner for many yeares making diligent enquiry after them, and had never got true information where they were, had not Mr. John Corbet told him, and it was a thou≈øand to one that the≈øe Bonds, being eleven yeares out of your Petitioners Cu≈øtodie, that your Petitioner ever heard of them; or got them again into his hands.

This Worthy Gentleman Mr. John Corbet advi≈øed me to make my Application by Petition to his late Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver Lord Protector, and to his Councel, for to have the≈øe Bonds re≈øtored, and that if his late Highne≈ø≈øe and his Councel would give him order to do it, he wi≈øhed me ≈øo well, be would procure your Petitioner the≈øe three Bonds ≈øafe and uncancelled, Provided your Petitioner would pay the Committee of Shrop≈øhire for them the ≈øumme of fourty pounds, which your Petitioner willingly offered to do, whereupon your Petitioner petitioned the late Lord Protector Oliver and his Councel for the afore≈øaid three
Bonds. And the Councel of State ordered John Corbet E≈øquire, ≈øhould attend them, to give them true information of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, which accordingly he did, and thereupon this Order following of the Councel of State was made, and your Petitioner paid his money to Mr. Corbet accordingly.

body.head: Friday, March 21. 1655 At the Coun≈øel at White-Hall.
body.p: UPon reading a Report from the Committee (to whom the Petition of Thomas Violet was referred) praying that certain Bonds ≈øeized upon by the Committee of Salop may be delivered unto him. Upon con≈øideration of the ≈øaid Report, and for that the ≈øaid Bonds are ingaged for forty pounds, which the ≈øaid Committee imploied for publique u≈øe, Ordered by his Highne≈ø≈øe the Lord Protector and his Coun≈øel, That upon the ≈øaid Thomas Violets paying unto the ≈øaid Committee the ≈øaid ≈øumme of forty pounds, for which the ≈øaid Bonds are ingaged, That the ≈øaid Committee bee required to deliver up the ≈øaid Bonds unto the ≈øaid Thomas Violet, and that hee bee at liberty to ≈øue the ≈øame and to take the benefit thereof as formerly hee might have done; and that it bee referred to John Corbet E≈øq. to ≈øee the ≈øaid Bonds delivered up accordingly upon payment of the ≈øaid forty pounds.

body.p: Mr. John Corbet I attended with this order; March 28. 1655. Hee was plea≈øed to tell mee hee was to go down into Shrop≈øhire, and would ≈øpeak with the Committee who were to receive the forty pounds, and then I ≈øhould know where to pay my money, for hee told mee hee had never received Publique monies, and hee was verie unwilling to receive any now. But upon his return, upon my earne≈øt intreaty and to ≈øave mee from further trouble, hee told mee hee would receive and keep this forty pounds in depo≈øito, for the u≈øe of the Committee till he had order from them for the di≈øpo≈øing of it. That tran≈øaction follows, viz.

MEmorandum, That the 24th of May 1656. In obedience to the Order of his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector and his Coun≈øel of the 21. of March 1655. I John Corbet E≈øq. have delivered unto Thomas Violet of London God-Smith, three Bonds: the fir≈øt bearing date the 6th of June 1638. of eight hundred pounds, for the payment of four hundred pounds within one year after the death of the Lady Anne Waad; in which Bond, the ≈øaid Lady Anne Waad, Charles Mordent, Philip Cage, and Edmund Lenthal E≈øquires ≈øtand bound to the ≈øaid Thomas Violet: and one other Bond of the 6th of June 1638. in ≈øix hundred pounds, for the payment of three hundred
pounds, within two years after the death of the ≈øaid Lady Anne Waad; in which the Per≈øons afore≈øaid ≈øtand bound to the ≈øaid Thomas Violet: and one other Bond (of the ≈øame date) of ≈øix hundred pounds, for the payment of three hundred pounds, within three years after the death of the ≈øaid Lady Anne Waad; in which Bond, the Per≈øons afore≈øaid ≈øtand bound to the ≈øaid Thomas Violet; The ≈øumme of forty pounds being paid by the ≈øaid Thomas Violet, according to the ≈øaid Order.

body.head: The Lady Anne Waad of Battels Hall in E≈ø≈øex died about May 1643. And the Bonds are due to mee Thomas Violet, at this day as above≈øaid.
body.p:
Your Petitioner may ju≈øtly ≈øay his E≈øtate was ≈øquandred away, when a thou≈øand pound of good Bonds of your Petitioners lay in lavender for eleven years for forty pounds, and your Petitioner had never known where they had bin, had not Mr. Corbet tould him, your Petitioners humble Prayer to your Honours is, that ≈øeeing your Petitioner hath paid Mr. Corbet the forty pounds according to the afore≈øaid Order, and hath
the≈øe Bonds ≈øafe and uncancelled now in his Cu≈øtody, and in con≈øideration of your Petitioner ≈øervices, in ≈øtaying this Silver, That your Honours would be plea≈øed in part of your Petitioners ≈øatisfaction of eleven thou≈øand pounds by your Honours Order, to Impower your Petitioner by Authority of Parliament, to ≈øhew and Implead the≈øe Bonds, notwith≈øtanding any Order of Parliament to ≈øeque≈øter the ≈øaid Bonds, and to Impower your Petitioner to take out Judgement and Execution thereupon, notwith≈øtanding any Order or Ordinance to the Committee of Shrop≈øhire, or any other Committee Touching or Concerning the≈øe Bonds.

And my mo≈øt humble Petition is to John Corbet E≈øquire, one of the Honourable members of this Parliament, that as hee received my money for the u≈øe of the Committee of Shrop≈øhire, and gave mee the fir≈øt notice and di≈øcovery in who≈øe Cu≈øtody the≈øe Bonds were, ≈øo hee would now bee plea≈øed out of his love to Ju≈øtice, to certifie his knowledge of the truth of this Bu≈øine≈øs; that ≈øo I may have Releif in this bu≈øine≈øs according to Ju≈øtice and equity.
Hereafter followeth your Petitioners Petition to Oliver Lord Protector, and his Reference thereupon to Col. Bark≈øtead, Alderman Viner, Capt. Iohn Limbery, Doctor VValker, &c.

body.head: TO HIS HIGHNESSE OLIVER LORD PROTECTOR Of the COMMON-WEALTH of England, Scotland, and Ireland, And the Dominions thereunto belonging.
The Humble Petition of Thomas Violet.
body.p: THat your Petitioner did about the 8th of Decemb. 1652. deliver unto the Council of State a written Paper wherein was di≈øcovered that at that pre≈øent time a practice and Combination, was ≈øet on foot by the then Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador Don Allon≈øo de Cardenas, with ≈øeveral other Merchants both Strangers and Natives, to deceive the State of a great quantity of Silver near fower hundred thou≈øand pounds, which was aboard the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, then riding at Eriffe.

Which Per≈øons before-named, had contrived by forged Bills of Lading, fal≈øe Claimes and Claimers, with other fraudulent pretences to get cleared the Court of Admiralty the afore≈øaid Silver and Ships, and for the effecting thereof there was no Cost ≈øpared nor Stone left unturned, as appeared by intercepted Letters of Mr James Steniere, a principal Actor to have this Silver cleared, which Letters cau≈øed the ≈øaid Mr. Steinere to be Commited to the Serjeant at Armes attending the Parliament, and by Mr. Pompey Callendrens Letter there was fifty in the hundred offered in Am≈øterdam, to en≈øure the ≈øaid Silver and Ships out of our hands.

Many of the Council of State did upon the intercepting the≈øe Letters concerning the Silver Ships, believe that the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador had, for a peece of money to be paid him, claimed this Silver as the King of Spaines Trea≈øure and his Subjects, colourably, but they knew not which way to di≈øcover it, and to prove the fraud, that ≈øo the State might have the Silver as Prize, (there lay the mi≈øtery) that then the Council could not fathom, and that made the Lord Brad≈øhawe and ≈øeverall of the Council of State to ingage your Supplicant in this ≈øervice, they telling your Petitioner that if this fraude was to be found out, they were a≈ø≈øured your Petitioner could do it, if your Petitioner would be true to the State, whereupon your Petitioner did faithfully promi≈øe the Council of State his uttermo≈øt endeavours to di≈øcover this fraud, and within three dayes after your Petitioner hearing the Parliament had made an Order upon the reque≈øt of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador, for the Judges of the Admiralty to proceed to a ≈øpeedy ≈øentence concerning the≈øe Ships and Silver, thereupon about 8th of Decemb 1652. your Petitioner
made the Lord Brad≈øhaw and Council acquainted, that hee had certain Intelligence and would prove it upon the perill of his Life by many credible Witne≈ø≈øes, that a great part of this Silver appertained to ≈øeverall Merchants of the united Provinces, and that the≈øe Ships having unfree Goods in them, were by the Civill Law forfeited to the State, and upon the afore≈øaid Paper which your Petitioner delivered into the Council of State, the Council of State ≈øent for Doctor Walker your Highne≈øs Advocate, who told the Council of State that if what was alleadged in that Paper could bee made good, the Ships ≈øhould bee ≈øtayed let the Judges ≈øay what they plea≈øed.

May it plea≈øe your Highne≈øs. The Judges of the Admiraltie appointed 16th Decemb. 1652. to give ≈øentence for the Clearing or Condemning the≈øe Ships, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and they ordered the Commi≈ø≈øioners for Dutch prize Goods to bee then in the Court, but the Commi≈ø≈øioners Mr. Hill and Mr. W ‚Ä¢ l≈øon declared unto your Supplicant the day before they were to attend in the Admiralty, that they were Merchants, and a great part of their Goods and E≈øtates in Spaine, and therefore they dur≈øt not for feare of having an Imbargo on their E≈øtates in Spaine bee ≈øeen in the Court of Admiralty to ≈øtopp the≈øe Silver Ships, but they earne≈øtly prayed and advi≈øed your Petitioner, that if hee knew any way to entitle the State to the Silver in tho≈øe Ships, hee ≈øhould doe the Common-wealth very great and acceptable ≈øervice, and ≈øave the State all the Silver, which otherwi≈øe would be di≈øcharged that morning; for then there was no other per≈øon appeared to ≈øtay the≈øe ≈øhips and ≈øilver, but your Supplicant, either at the Councel of State, or with Doctor VValker your Highne≈ø≈øe Advocate,
And this Doctor VValker knowes to be a truth.

In pur≈øuance of entituling the State to this ≈øilver in the afore≈øaid ≈øhips, your Supplicant received a Command from the Coun≈øel of State 13. Decemb. 1652. That if your Supplicant would undertake at his own peril to di≈øprove the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadours Claim, and to prove that great quantities of the ≈øilver in the afore≈øaid ≈øhips, appertained to Merchants of the united Provinces, and Am≈øterdam, by good and legal Witne≈ø≈øes, That then notwith≈øtanding the Order of Parliament, your Petitioner ≈øhould make his Prote≈øt in the Court of Admiraltie, again≈øt the di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid ≈øilver, till his Witne≈ø≈øes were examined. The Councel of State declaring, that if the Court of Admiralty committed your Petitioner for making his Prote≈øt then the Councel would pre≈øently hear, and take cognizance of the ≈øame bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. The Councel of State further declared, that if your Supplicant ≈øhould faile to make good what he had undertaken, he would be utterly undone, for that they would certifie your Petitioner to be an Incendiary, in pre≈øuming to contradict the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour, and Duke Leopoldus Agents, in affirming the ≈øilver belonged for a great part thereof to Merchants of Am≈øterdam, when the Amba≈ø≈øadour on his honour affirmed, it was all for his Catholick-Maje≈øtie, and his Subjects Accompts, and none other. But if your Petitioner was ≈øo a≈ø≈øured, as he would venture his life, liberty, and e≈øtate, to di≈øprove the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour, and Duke Leopoldus Agents claim, and prove great quantities thereof to appertain to the Dutch of the united Provinces then our enemies, by good and legal proof, and did perform this his undertaking, your Petitioner ≈øhould not only be re≈øtored to all his e≈øtate the Parliament had taken from
him, being about eleven thou≈øand pounds, for which ≈øumme your Petitioner had for ≈øeverall yeares before Petitioned the Parliament and Council of State) but al≈øo your Petitioner ≈øhould have both that E≈øtate and a good reward over and above for his good ≈øervice, and this Promi≈øe your Supplicant had from the Council of State and the Committee for forreign affaires, and that they would ≈øee your Supplicant ju≈øtly and truely ≈øatisfied, and upon this Honourable a≈ø≈øurance your Petitioner engaged and undertooke this great ≈øervice, and when your Supplicant Petitioned the Council of State, for an Order of the Council or Parliament in writing for the States ju≈øt performance, when hee had proved that great quantities of this Silver aboard the three afore≈øaid Ships appertained to the Dutch the Committee of forreign affaires, and the Lord Brad≈øhaw was much offended that your Supplicant ≈øhould ≈øcruple the Ju≈øtice of the State, as not to bee fully rewarded according to the greatne≈øs of the ≈øervice, Prote≈øting it could not enter into the heart of any hone≈øt man to ≈øcruple or ≈øu≈øpect the Council of State ≈øo ungratefull, as not to performe there promi≈øe ju≈øtly with your Petitioner, and had that Council of State continued in power, your Supplicant is a≈ø≈øured in his Con≈øcience that hee had reeeived every penny of the ≈øumme promi≈øed, being eleven thou≈øand pounds out of the monies as it was Coyned.

The rea≈øons that the Council of State did not give your Petitioner a written Order for the re≈øtoration of your Petitioners E≈øtate, or the value being eleven thou≈øand pounds, was that if it was done either by the Order of Parliament or Council of State, then the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador and other Nations would know,
that the Council of State had ≈øtayed that Silver contrary to an Order of Parliament, and had promi≈øed a reward to your Petitioner to make this di≈øcovery before the ≈øervice done, which the Lord Brad≈øhaw told your Supplicant at the Council-Board the Council would not (to get all the Silver in the Ships) bee knowne to make an agreement, to finde out Witne≈ø≈øes to have the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe done, but that your Supplicant might re≈øt a≈ø≈øured on ju≈øt and Honourable dealings, and the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate or eleven thou≈øand pounds, If your Petitioner did by good and legall Witne≈ø≈øes di≈øprove the Spaniards Claim to this Silver in the afore≈øaid Ships.

p.hi: Your Supplicant having proceeded ≈øo farre as to make his Prote≈øt in the Court of Admiraltie, again≈øt the di≈øcharge of the≈øe Ships and Silver, hee was nece≈ø≈øitated to proceed to make his di≈øcovery, or el≈øe the undertaking it had undone him for ever, and your Petitioner acquainted the Council that to proceed in this di≈øcovery would bee very Chargeable, and your Supplicant being under ≈øeque≈øtration, un≈øupportable, but no allowance of money could bee obtained till your Petitioner had intituled the State to the Silver; and this being done on your Supplicants part, the Council ≈øaid your Petitioner might re≈øt a≈ø≈øured of ju≈øt and Honourable performance, for the payment of your Petitioners eleven thou≈øand pounds or his E≈øtate.

body.p:
Your Petitioner being at or about that time, ≈øeverall times offered by ≈øome Merchants of Flanders, Claimers of great quantities of the Silver, That if your Petitioner would de≈øi≈øt and not pro≈øecute this bu≈øine≈øs in the Court of Admiraltie, hee ≈øhould have paid him downe the ≈øumme of ten thou≈øand pounds, either in money here, or in Bills of Exchange, upon
the di≈øcharge of the Ships and Silver, but your Petitioner refu≈øed the offers of the Merchants, and made the Lord Brad≈øhawe and the Council acquainted therewith, and valued more the ≈øafety and Honour of the Nation, and his own reputation in this undertaking, then the Spani≈øh Merchants money, relying wholly on the promi≈øe of the Council of State for his ju≈øt reward and ≈øatisfaction.

Your Supplicants Expence and Charges in the pro≈øecuting this bu≈øine≈øs, in one year and a halfs time amounted to above five hundred pouuds, be≈øides what ≈øummes of money your Supplicant hath ≈øince expended, hee having imployed con≈øtantly ten ≈øeverall per≈øons, ≈øome of them lived in Spaine and Holland, and ≈øeverall monthes your Petitioner imployed ≈øeverall Merchants and others in the Regi≈øtry of the Admiralty, to in≈øpect into all proceedings, Claimes, Exhibites, pleadings, Bills of Lading, and comparing many thou≈øand ≈øheetes of paper and writing, and tran≈ølating many Bills of Lading and other tran≈øactions, all which your Petitioner did by the Command of the Council of State, and upon Warrants and Orders of your Highne≈øs Advocate Doctor Walker; Your Supplicant al≈øo imployed ≈øeverall per≈øons about Eri≈øfe, Limehou≈øe, Blackwall, Wapping, and St. Katherines, to finde out where the Seamen and Pa≈ø≈øengers of the≈øe Ships lay, paying all charges of their meetings, boate-hire, writing and tran≈øcribing all the proceedings, and printing them for the Parliament, to vindicate the Ju≈øtice of the Nation in ≈øtaying this Silver and Ships, for it is proved out of the mouthes of ≈øeverall Pa≈ø≈øengers that came from Spaine that very Voyage. That va≈øt and great quantities of this Silver appertained to the Dutch, and was delivered
in Spaine aboard the≈øe Ships for the accompts of Marchants of Am≈øterdam, and by the Originall Letters under the States generall Seale to their vice Admiralls de Witt and de Rutter, remaining now in your Highne≈ø≈øe Court of Admiralty, commanding them to Convoy and guard the≈øe Ships from the Parliaments Forces, and the≈øe Commi≈ø≈øions or Letters were procured upon the Petition of the Merchants of Am≈øterdam, and by ≈øeverall advices remaining in the Court of Admiralty, the≈øe Ships and Silver were bound for Holland, It is proved that when the≈øe three Ships fir≈øt ≈øet Sale to go their Voyage, they went from Holland, and the Ports and Harbours of the united Provinces, al≈øo that ≈øeverall Merchants in London for their own proper accompts, had Silver Laden aboard the≈øe Ships this Voyage in Spain, which cleerely di≈øproves the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors Claime to all the Silver in the≈øe Ships, to bee only for his Ma≈øter and his Subjects accompts, for Merchants Natives of London are not the King of Spaines Subjects, It is al≈øo proved that ≈øeverall parcells of Silver aboard the≈øe Ships, were entered, and Bills made in feined names and colourably, to avoyd the taking and condemnation of the Silver and of the≈øe Ships, if they were taken by the Engli≈øh.

It is al≈øo proved, that although the Bills of Lading were for Oa≈øtend, yet the Silver was con≈øigned to Am≈øterdam. It is likewi≈øe proved by ≈øeverall Pa≈ø≈øengers, that when the≈øe Ships had bin ten dayes at Sea, and hearing of the Warrs betweene the Engli≈øh and the Dutch, the Ma≈øters Books were altered, and all the Hollanders and Zelanders names were put out, and other names put in their ≈øtead, and after three times
peru≈øall and examination of the names, the Bookes were written out ≈øaire (which were the Bookes produced in the Court of Admiraltie) And the originall blotted Bookes, which were the true Bookes, were not to bee found, but when the≈øe Ships came into the Downes, the Pur≈øer of the Ship Samp≈øon, tooke them and tyed them to an Iron Barr, and then threwe them into the Sea.

The≈øe particulers with many others, are the volontary confe≈ø≈øions of ≈øeverall Pa≈ø≈øengers in the≈øe Ships, being actors and parties in Spain, and privie to all the≈øe actions both in Spaine and on Shipboard, and the Confe≈ø≈øion of Dutch-men and Ea≈øterlings.

Your Petitioner hath humbly pre≈øented the≈øe proofes and Witne≈ø≈øes to ≈øhewe the greatne≈øs of your Supplicants ≈øervice, and the Ju≈øtice of the Nation in ≈øtaying and confi≈øcating this Silver, ≈øo that it now cleerely appeares, the Claime of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador to this Silver, was but a fraudulent practice in him to have cozened the State, and cheated them of all this great Trea≈øure.

p.hi: This bu≈øine≈øs your ≈øupplicant effected with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtanee of tenn other per≈øons, in a year and halfes con≈øtant attendance, ≈øitting up many daies and nights together when your Petitioner fir≈øt undertooke this ≈øervice, being daily threatned to bee murthered by the Claimers, and expending above five hundred pounds in this ≈øervice.

All which particulers of your Petitioners pro≈øecuting this bu≈øine≈øs, and the charges hee was at for doing the ≈øame, is atte≈øted upon the Oathes of four credible Witne≈ø≈øes, who were imployed in this ≈øervice, and were privie to your Petitioners expence.

body.p: Which five hundred pounds your Petitioner borrowed, and hath ever ≈øince continued at intere≈øt, and is now above ≈øeven hundred pounds; Severall Gentlemen lending the ≈øame to your Petitioner out of their good will to the Nation in generall, and that your Petitioner might bee re≈øtored to his E≈øtate againe, and had not your Petitioner borrowed this money to enable him to do this ≈øervice, your Highne≈ø≈øe and the Parliament had lo≈øt every penny of this Silver, being about three hundred thou≈øand pounds.
Never any man as yet, brovght and ≈øaved your Highne≈ø≈øe, and the Parliament ≈øo much money at one time in any age, as your Supplicant hath heard of; or read of.
Your Petitioner tru≈øts and hopes in God, and your Highne≈ø≈øe, that ≈øo great ≈øervice to your Highne≈ø≈øe and the Nation, ≈øhall not go unrequited.

What ≈øervice this Trea≈øure did your Highne≈ø≈øe, and the Nation at that conjuncture of time in 1653. Chri≈øtendom knows, the Dutch (then our Enemies felt) and this Nation (under your Highne≈ø≈øe government) do enjoy and have the happy fruit of at this day.

Your mo≈øt humble Petitioner prayes your Highne≈ø≈øe to take all the Premi≈ø≈øes into your Princely con≈øideration. And that your Petitioner may have his e≈øtate, or the value thereof re≈øtored to him, in recompence of his ≈øervices afore≈øaid.
body.closer: And your Petitioner ≈øhall ever pray, &c. THO. VIOLET.

div.p: Here followeth an Atte≈øtation of my Prote≈øting in the Court of Admiraltie again≈øt the Judges, clearing and di≈øcharging the ≈øaid Silver and Ships, and again≈øt the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors Claims, ju≈øt that Morning as they were di≈øcharging of the Ships and Silver, being the ≈øixteenth day of Decemb. 1652. as appears by the Certificate of the Officers of the Mint under their hands, viz.

body.p:
WE, who≈øe names are here under-written, hereby certifie all whom it may concern, that we were pre≈øent in the Court of Admiralty that day the
Judges of the Court were reported to proceed to a ≈øentence for the clearing or condemning of the ≈øhips Salvador, George, and Samp≈øon,) it being about the ≈øeventeenth of Decemb. 1652. And there we ≈øaw Mr. Thomas Violet, the ≈øame day in the Court pre≈øent a Paper unto the Judges, which he declared contained ≈øeveral Rea≈øons and Arguments to the Judges; for re≈øpiting their Judgment concerning the di≈øcharging of tho≈øe ≈øhips, and ≈øeveral other Prizes, till he had examined ≈øeveral Witne≈ø≈øes on the behalf of the State, to di≈øprove the Spani≈øh Claimes concerning the≈øe Ships, at which time the Silver was aboard the≈øe Ships: After ≈øome time ≈øpent in arguing the bu≈øine≈øs by Mr. Violet in behalf of the State, the Judges ≈øeeming to proceed to a ≈øentence concerning the ≈øaid Pri≈øe Ships, Mr. Thomas Violet made his Prote≈øt in the ≈øaid Court of Admiraltie agani≈øt the di≈øcharge of all or any of the≈øe Pri≈øes, declaring hee did it upon his owne accompt, till his Witne≈ø≈øes were examined in the behalf of the State: And that the Judges, if they ≈øhould proceed to the contrary, ≈øhould an≈øwer it to the Parliament and Council of State at their peril. Thereupon the Court de≈øi≈øted from proceeding in the ≈øaid Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; and the Judges thereof required Mr. Violet to attend the Councel of State that afternoon, about his carriage that day in the Court of Admiraltie, touching the≈øe ≈øhips.

The Affidavits follow; viz.

body.p:
JOhn Glover of London Merchant, aged about fourty years, maketh Oath, That Mr. Thomas Violet, having ≈øince December 1652. received ≈øeveral Orders and Warrants from his Highne≈ø≈øes Councel, and Doctor Walker (Advocate for the Common-wealth,) to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the behalf of the Common-wealth, again≈øt the Silver ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador. and George, and all their Silver and lading: In pur≈øuance of which ≈øervice the ≈øaid Mr. Violet hath con≈øtantly intreated his (this Deponents) a≈ø≈øi≈øtance,
(among≈øt ≈øeveral other per≈øons which he the ≈øaid Mr. Violet emploied) for making di≈øcovery of the ≈øeveral frauds and practices of the Ma≈øters of tho≈øe ≈øhips, and of ≈øeveral other Merchants, Claimers of the Silver and lading in the afore≈øaid ≈øhips, to deceive the State by their ≈øeveral Claims; And al≈øo of the ≈øeveral Bills of lading, and in ≈øeveral other particulars: in pur≈øuance of this ≈øervice for the Common-wealth, for ≈øeveral moneths this Deponent, with one Mr. Simon Baldwine a Merchant, who lived a long time at Cades and St. Lucars in Spain, and with Mr. Violet this Deponent and they two did veiw and examine all the Bills of lading, and the ≈øeveral pleas and Exhibits, Extracts, and all other writings and papers which were brought in, and remain in the Regi≈øtrie of the Admiraltie concerning the≈øe ≈øhips, ≈øilver and lading; the Regi≈øter declaring that they had ≈øeen all the Tran≈øactions that was then upon record in that bu≈øine≈øs, which were many thou≈øand ≈øheets; and that the ≈øaid Mr. Violet had ≈øeveral Warrants from Doctor Walker to the Regi≈øter and Examiners of the Admiralty, to require them, that the ≈øaid Mr. Violet, and all ≈øuch as he ≈øhould nominate under his hand to the ≈øaid Regi≈øter and Examiner, ≈øhould be impowered to make ≈øeveral Searches, which he this Deponent and the re≈øt did almo≈øt every day for about three moneths: And this Deponent further maketh Oath, That after he and the re≈øt had taken ≈øuch Ob≈øervations and Directions, as Mr. Thomas Violet had given order concerning the marks of ≈øeveral Bills of Lading, and ≈øeveral other particulars, both Mr. Simon
Baldwine and this Deponent delivered the Papers up to Mr. Violet, hee having imployed and contented us for our pains. This Bu≈øine≈øs concerning the ≈øhips and ≈øilver, this Deponent came to be ingaged in at the reque≈øt and entreaty of the ≈øaid Mr. Violet, hee having heard how nece≈ø≈øary and advantagious hee (this Deponent) ≈øhould bee, in making this di≈øcovery of the truth of this bu≈øine≈øs; For that this Deponent for many years was an Inhabitant and merchants in Rotterdam, and had Commerce and Trade with mo≈øt Townes in Holland, where Trading was ≈øtirring. And this Deponent know's many of the marks of the Bills of Lading of the≈øe Silver Ships, though they pretend to belong to Spaniards, Hamburgers and Flaunders, yet they are the ≈øame marks as divers Merchants of Holland give to their goods and Merchandize; And that ≈øince the War with Holland, divers Ships and their lading have been condemned in the Admiraltie, and made prize of, which had Silver and merchandize aboard them at the time of the condemning, with the ≈øame markes which are in the≈øe Ships (Samp≈øon Salvador and George); And this Deponent further depo≈øeth, That hee knoweth the ≈øaid Mr. Violet imployed (be≈øides Mr. Simon Baldwin,) ≈øeveral other people for the making the≈øe di≈øcoveries ever ≈øince Decemb. 1652. And this Deponent hath been imployed by the ≈øaid Mr. Violet in this bu≈øine≈øs for almo≈øt a year and a half in the finding out and ≈øearching this bu≈øine≈øs; and the ≈øaid Mr. Violet hath to his (this Deponents) knowledg, expended very great ≈øummes of monie in pro≈øecution thereof, to the value of above five hundred pounds, be≈øides all his pains, attendance and hazzard;
this Deponent having heard him ≈øeveral times threatned and in danger of his life by ≈øeveral Merchants and others, Claimers of the Silver in the≈øe Ships: they having declared in this Deponents pre≈øence, That by the ≈øaid Violets prote≈øting in the Court of Admiraltie again≈øt the di≈øcharge of the≈øe Ships and Silver in Decemb. 1652. the day the Judges appointed for di≈øcharging the Ships and Silver, (and by his further pro≈øecution again≈øt tho≈øe Ships and Silver ≈øince) hee hath been and is the onely cau≈øe of hindering them of their Silver and Ships; And that they had had their Silver long ≈øince, had not Thomas Violet undertaken the pro≈øecution of this Bu≈øine≈øs. And this, this Deponent hath heard affirmed ≈øeveral times by merchants and others, claimers, both at the Exchange and el≈øewhere. And this Deponent maketh Oath, That this Affidavit is for the affirming and ju≈øtifying of Mr. Violets pains, hazzard and ≈øervice in pro≈øecution of this Bu≈øine≈øs of the Silver ≈øhips and Lading.

body.head: A Coppie of my Letter ≈øent to the Lord Brad≈øhaw. 25th of March 1653.
body.p:
I Have left with Colonel Harbert Morley this day my Petition to the Council of State again≈øt Otho George: I humbly de≈øire your honour to take notice, if the Council of State do not take ≈øome pre≈øent order in it, to con≈øider what encouragement my ≈øelf or any man that ≈øerves the Commonwealth in the di≈øcovery of the Ships, ≈øilver and Merchandize now brought in as Dutch prize ≈øhall have when they ≈øhall bee a≈ø≈øaulted in the ≈øtreets with Stilettoes and Poniards from Cap: Otho George, for being in≈øtrumentall to do the State ≈øervice: I have been advi≈øed by ≈øeveral friends for this eight dayes, not to come to the Exchange or Admiraltie, lea≈øt I ≈øhould bee murthered for undertaking this bu≈øine≈øs, Mr. Joachim Pe≈øler Chirurg ‚Ä¢ on upon the Ship Samp≈øon, now riding at Eriff, of which Ship Otho George is Captaine, and Jacob Elaes Otho George his Cabbin Boy, hath di≈øcovered the Silver in the Ships, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, that a great part thereof belongs to the Dutch For when they had been ten daies at Sea, the Pur≈øer was ordered by the Captain to go into the Fore-Ca≈øtle, and take his Book and blot out all the names of the Hollanders and Zealanders, and, in their place, to in≈øert abundance of other names: for which di≈øcovery Captain Otho George did ≈øtab the Chirurgeon of the Ship. My humble prayer to your Honour is, That the examinations taken about

body.p:
WEE have a certaine di≈øcovery that a great quantity of Gold and Silver hath been ≈øtolne out of the Dutch prize ≈øhips that call them≈øelves Hamburgers, wee de≈øire, for the ≈øervice of the State, to have a Warrant to bring all the Bullion in the Dutch pri≈øe-≈øhips on ≈øhoare; Wee have here enclo≈øed ≈øent you Mr. Thomas Violets Letters to us, and his proofes taken in the Office; every houres delay of not taking the Silver a ≈øhoare is great lo≈ø≈øe to the State; Wee finde Mr. Violet the bearer hereof, very active and knowing to make the≈øe di≈øcoveries, and he hath done ≈øeveral good, and great ≈øervices for the State already in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, We

body.head: A Warrant of Doctor Walkers, to the Examiners Mr. How, and Mr. Arnold in the Court of Admiralty, December 1. 1653.
body.p:
MA≈øter How and Mr Arnold, in the bu≈øine≈øs of the three ≈øhips, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and the Silver and Lading in tho≈øe ≈øhips, Mr Violet was ordered to contribute and yield his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, to bring in Evidence on the behalf of the Common-wealth. I did heretofore ≈øigne a Warrant, that all the Proceedings might be ≈øhewed him: He now de≈øires, that the names of all the Witne≈ø≈øes already produced on the behalf of the State, as al≈øo the Allegations and Matter upon which they were produced: as likewi≈øe, the names of all Witne≈ø≈øes produced on the behalf of the Claimers; and every one of them particularly, and the Allegations and Interrogatories upon which they have been produced, might be ≈øhewen to him.
I pray your Honours to con≈øider, whether I could employ men in this Di≈øcovery for two yeares, and not to pay them for their paines, and yet I have not had one penny for this ≈øervice.
Doctor Walker knew that I employed many people every day in the≈øe Di≈øcoveries, ≈øeveral of the≈øe being often with me, both at the Admiralty, and at his chamber; and he knew, I imployed none in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe but credible per≈øons, as appears here under his hand.
And could Doctor Walker have made this Di≈øcovery, or known the tricks of the≈øe Merchants, Ma≈øters of ≈øhips, and Pur≈øers, by forged bills, and many other ≈øubtilties of Trade, which is not in his Law-books, but is common among≈øt the Dutch Merchants in the≈øe times. Dr Walker would have ≈øaved me the labour and charge for employing people to make this Di≈øcovery, or from making my Prote≈øt in the Admiralty, and would have had the credit and thanks from the State for this Service and Di≈øcovery to him≈øelf. But this I dare ≈øay, though he be a great Lawyer, yet for the making of this Di≈øcovery, he was then 16. Decemb. 1652. utterlie ignorant of the way to do it, this being a ≈øubtilty among≈øt a few Merchants, and not to be read in the Civil Law-books, and had I not had all my Intelligence from their own creatures, and plowed with their Hei≈øer, I could not have done this ≈øervice, or made this Di≈øcovery.
And upon examination of this bu≈øine≈øs at the Councel of State, Doctor Walker confe≈ø≈øed that it was not his ≈øtudy nor his place to ≈øeek up and down to procure Witne≈ø≈øes, or to finde out waies to entitle the State to this Silver; and except I could bring legal Witne≈ø≈øe, the State mu≈øt lo≈øe this Trea≈øure: this hee declared ≈øeveral times before the Councel of State.
But if the Pa≈ø≈øengers did confe≈ø≈øe this Silver to be loaden, a great part of it for the accompt of Merchants of An≈øterdam, as I had undertaken they would do, then hee would improve that Te≈øtimony to the uttermo≈øt for the States advantage, which indeed Doctor Walker did.
And I proved the≈øe frauds by the te≈øtimony of about ten of the Pa≈ø≈øengers, being all Dutchmen, Hamburgers and Lubeccars, and other Han≈ø-towns men; and I had above four≈øcore witne≈ø≈øes the Pa≈ø≈øengers and Merchants more to examine in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, many of them were after packed away by the Claimers, being Dutch marriners, and had money given them that they ≈øhould keep out of the way and not be examined, and ≈øeveral Witne≈ø≈øes waited many daies to be examined in the Admiralty and could not.
Spani≈øh Gold and Silver was plentifully be≈øtowed on ≈øome in the Admiralty, and they loved it well. The Claimers had their In≈øtruments almo≈øt every night that ≈øtole ≈øilver out of the≈øe ≈øhips, to the value of many ≈øcore thou≈øand pounds, which I di≈øcovered to the Councel of State, as appeared by ≈øeveral papers which I pre≈øented to them.
I imployed ≈øeveral men who ≈øpake the Dutch Language at my own charge, and gave them money to go on ≈øhip-board, and to drink freely with the Dutch marriners, and in their cups to fi≈øh out the ≈øecrets of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and when I had once got the end of the ≈øtring, I would by other engines and in≈øtruments clo≈øely follow and never give it over till I knew the whole bottom of the Flemmi≈øh and Spani≈øh cheats which they intended to put upon the Nation.
The≈øe men that I imployed on ≈øhip-board for to make this Di≈øcovery for mee never appeared to mee in the Admiralty, le≈øt the Spani≈øh and Dutch Merchants and marriners ≈øhould have di≈øcovered them to have been my ≈øpies. And to deal clearly with your Honours, they were none of them Book-men, Civilians, nor Lawyers, but ≈øuch per≈øons as be-skellom'd mee ≈øoundly in their cups with the Dutch marriners; and though I paid for the Brandey-wine, ≈øtrong beer, Mum, and Spruce beere, pickle Herrings and Holland chee≈øe, yet I never ex≈øpected from them good word or peny of money for all this charge and pains.
If I were to do the like ≈øervice again for the State, I would never look in any Books of the Civil Law, but con≈øult with ≈øuch per≈øons as know how to humour a Dutch Skipper or marriner, and fi≈øh out his ≈øecrets. Thus have I clearly told you the waies and in≈øtruments I u≈øed to do the Common-wealth this great ≈øervice. I now humbly ex≈øpect according to the Councel of States promi≈øe the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds for this ≈øervice. And had I not undertaken it the Common-wealth had lo≈øt this Silver, which was to the value of two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds. This that he de≈øires being just, I de≈øire that you would not put him off, but let it be done forthwith unto him≈øelf, and all ≈øuch others as he under his hand ≈øhall nominate; for he employes others under him in ≈øearching into this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. He will nominate none but ≈øuch as may be tru≈øted in it. And I de≈øire you in your ≈øeveral places to give him, and all that he ≈øhall employ, all ready di≈øpatch and encouragement, that the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the Common-wealth may finde no ob≈øtacle. Where there is publication, you may likewi≈øe ≈øhew him the Depo≈øitions and (I pray) let nothing that is ju≈øt be denied him.

closer.signed: Walter Walker.

body.head: 3 September, 1653.
body.p:
MA≈øter Dori≈ølaus and M. Bud are now again de≈øired to deliver unto Mr. Violet a Copie of the Specifications given in by the Ma≈øters and Commanders of the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George: as likewi≈øe, Copies of all the Pleadings Articulate Exhibited and admitted on the part of the Claimers of the Silver in any of the≈øe ≈øhips: And they are to go with him to the Regi≈øter, and Examiners Offices; and to procure him a view of all the Bills of Lading, Extracts and Exhibites, either brought into the Office, or exhibited by any Claymers: And whatever Papers are, or ≈øhall bee exhibited by any Claymers: And whatever Papers are, or ≈øhall bee exhibited by any Claimers in the three Ships. I do, as Advocate for the Common-wealth, de≈øire Mr. Dori≈ølaus to yeild all his endeavours and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and al≈øo the Regi≈øter, Examiner, and Deputy-Regi≈øter in the Admiraltie from time to time to give Mr, Violet free admittance and view of all Acts, Bills of Lading, and Pleas Exhibited, and Extracts and Papers remaining in the Regi≈øtry, or which ≈øhall come in: And to it readily and effectually; the ≈øame tending to the ≈øervice of the Common-wealth; and being in order for preparing the Evidence fit to be produced for the Commonwealth.
I am in this Letter, by order of the Councel of State to Doctor Walker, entreated to make this Di≈øcovery, but now I have done the States-work with the hazard of my life, and va≈øt expence, I cannot by Petitions, Certificates, or Prayers, and many yeares attendance, get to be paid my mo≈øt dearly earned reward which the Councel promi≈øed me, being eleven thou≈øand pounds; had I thought of this u≈øage, I could have bin paid by the Claimers.
If this di≈øcovery had bin ≈øo ea≈øily made, and had bin every bodies work to have found out the Spaniards Frauds, I ≈øhould not have had the≈øe earne≈øt Entreaties from Dr. Walker, according to the Orders of the Councel of State, of the 1. of Septemb. 1653. The Commi≈ø≈øioners for Prize-Goods, have certified to Mr Secretary Thurloe, how active and knowing they found me to make the≈øe Di≈øcoveries; and had I not been ≈øo, the Nation had lo≈øt every peny of this great Trea≈øure, amounting to above two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds. And I do, according to the Order of the Councel of State of the Fir≈øt of September, 1653, earne≈øtly de≈øire and Entreat Mr. Violet, and al≈øo the Commi≈ø≈øioners for Prize goods, and their Sollicitors
and Agents; as al≈øo, the Proctor and Silicitors for the State, and every one of them, with all convenient ≈øpeed, ≈øeverally to ≈øet down in Writing all the Informations that they re≈øpectively know of, or can finde: And all the Evidences and Proofs that may be di≈øcerned or produced on the part of the Common-wealth; That ≈øo a full Plea and Articulate Allegation may be prepared, and the Proofs brought in for the Common-wealth: And no Default bee done, ≈øuffered, or Committed

closer.signed: Walter Walker.

div.p: Here follows the Referrees Letter, with their de≈øires to my Lord Brad≈øhaw.

body.p: WHereas by an Order of Reference from his Highne≈ø≈øe the Lord Protector, dated the 13th. of July 1657. the Petition of Mr. Thomas Violet, (concerning his ≈øtaying the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and therein the Dutch ≈øilver) is referred to the con≈øideration of Sir Thomas Vyner, and Sir John Bark≈øtead Knights, Captain John Limbrey, Doctor Walker, Gabriel Beck, Maurice Thom≈øon, Edward Dendy, Henry Middleton, and I≈øaac Dori≈ølaus E≈øquires, or any three or more of them, who according to the ≈øaid Order of Reference, are to examine, ≈øtate and certifie the premi≈ø≈øes, contained in the ≈øaid Petition to his Highne≈ø≈øe, together with their opinion upon the whole matter. And whereas upon reading the ≈øaid Petition, of the ≈øaid Mr. Thomas Violet, there are many particulars of ≈øervice alledged by the Petitioner, which he affirms the Lord Brad≈øhaw to have knowledge of; It is therefore de≈øired, in order to a ≈øpeedy and effectual proceeding upon the ≈øaid Petition, That Gabriel Beck E≈øquire, Mr. Serjeant Dendy, or either of them, will take the paines to wait upon the Lord Brad≈øhaw, and in the names of the above-≈øaid Referrees, to Pre≈øent the Petition and Reference relating to the ≈øaid Thomas Violet, with the de≈øire of the ≈øaid Referrees, That his Lord≈øhip upon peru≈øal of the ≈øame, will be plea≈øed to certifie his knowledge of the premi≈ø≈øes, dated the one and twentieth day of Augu≈øt 1657.

div.p: This ≈øame Letter, which the≈øe afore≈øaid Referrees writ to the Lord Brad≈øhaw, the Referrees out of their love to Ju≈øtice, and to know the Truth; were plea≈øed to write to Sir James Harrington, Sir George Fleetwood, and Francis Allen E≈øquire, and ≈øent them Copies of your Petitioners Petition and Reference, ≈øub≈øcribed by the afore≈øaid Referrees, that ≈øo the≈øe Honourable Gentlemen, upon the peru≈øal of your Petitioners Petition, and the Reference, thereupon would al≈øo be plea≈øed to certifie their knowledge of the Premi≈ø≈øes to the afore≈øaid Referrees, which they all of them were honourably plea≈øed to certifie accordingly.

For which Ju≈øtice of theirs I am bound to pray for every one of them, the like great Obligations your Petitioner owes to the following Referrees, let the i≈ø≈øue of this Bu≈øine≈øs be what God plea≈øe, I have learned to ≈øubmit unto his Providence, I am as clay in the Potters hands.

And though I was very unwilling to print the≈øe Certificates and the Referrees report to their late Highne≈ø≈øes Oliver and Richard, knowing the≈øe Honourable Gentlemen love to do the oppre≈ø≈øed right for con≈øcience ≈øake, without blowing a Trumpet not looking for thanks from men, that ≈øo God may reward them openly.

Yet the pre≈øent po≈øture of my bu≈øine≈øs is ≈øuch, that to demon≈øtrate the many ≈øervices your Petitioner hath done this Common-wealth, your Honours ≈øhall ≈øee it certified under the hands of twenty four Honourable and Credible per≈øons, the Originalls I have ready to produce, I humbly crave pardon of the≈øe Honourable
Gentlemen for doing thereof without acquainting them therewith, it is both by the Lawes of God and this Nation, that out of the mouth of two VVitne≈ø≈øes every thing, ≈øhall bee e≈øtabli≈øhed, both for mens E≈øtates and Lifes by the Laws of this Land a Jury of twelve per≈øons either quit or condemn all per≈øons of what degree ≈øoever.

For your Honours Information, your Honours upon the peru≈øal of the≈øe Certificates would ≈øee a concatenation of faithfull and difficult ≈øervice, which your Petitioner at his great expence, charge, trouble, and lo≈ø≈øe of time, from the very houre your Petitioner was di≈øcharged out of the Tower; viz. 1647 to the year 1651. the year before your Petitioner undertooke this great ≈øervice of ≈øtaying the Silver in the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George.

In con≈øideration of which ≈øervice done as afore≈øaid, many of the Council of State and members of this Parliament, did promi≈øe your Petitioner the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, and they watched but for an opportunity to acquaint the Parliament therewith, that ≈øo his E≈øtate may bee re≈øtored unto him againe, all the≈øe ≈øervices and promi≈øes made by the Council in the year 1651. before ever this Silver was brought into the River, or the State had ≈øea≈øed on it.

May it plea≈øe your Honours, in Decemb. 1652. before your Petitioner would undertake to make his di≈øcovery of the Spani≈øh and Flemi≈øh fraudulent Claimes, to cozen the State of this Trea≈øure, and to be at the
charge of pro≈øecuting the ≈øame in the Admiralty, your Petitioner was nece≈ø≈øitated to come to a certain agreement about his e≈øtate with the Councel of State, and how he ≈øhould be paid for this ≈øervice, or el≈øe it had been a thing impo≈ø≈øible for your Petitioner to have undertaken this task, or to have gone through with it, in re≈øpect the Councel of State would not advance any money to your Petitioner, but would rather have let this ≈øilver go in the Admiraltie, as it had gone, had not your Petitioner in the very minute of time ≈øtayed it, as is atte≈øted under the hands of the Officers of the Mint, whereupon your Petioner was forced to borrow great ≈øummes of money, to enable him to employ in≈øtruments to finde out the bottom of this fraud.

Several Gentlemen lent your Petitioner ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds at intere≈øt, every penny ≈øpent in this ≈øervice; the rea≈øon that both made your Petitioner undertake this difficult bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and made the≈øe Gentlemen lend your Petitioner this money, was upon the credit and faith of the Councel of States promi≈øe to your Petitioner, that if this ≈øilver was forfeited to the State, your Petitioner ≈øhould faithfullie be paid out of the ≈øame the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, in lieu of his e≈øtate, and this you will ≈øee clearly proved, and my friends knew me ≈øo well, that I would not to fail of your Petitioners undertaking, and for that your Petitioner was and is ready to prove to the Councel of State, his damage is far greater by his Seque≈øtration and Impri≈øonment then eleven thou≈øand pounds, the Councel of State did faithfully promi≈øe
1652. that over and above the paying of your Petitioner the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, for this ≈øervice of getting and ≈øtaying this ≈øilver, your Petitioner ≈øhould have an Honourable Reward and Memorial left to po≈øterity for the ≈øame, and it was upon this ≈øcore of getting my e≈øtate again off Seque≈øtration, or eleven thou≈øand pounds ≈øatisfaction, that I ever acted in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the ≈øilver, or in any other publick bu≈øine≈ø≈øe from the year 1647. to 1651. or ≈øince 1652. to this time, for had I not been a≈ø≈øured faithfully of my e≈øtate from the Councel of State, and relied on ju≈øt performance; or had I had the lea≈øt thought of ≈øuch u≈øage, and putting off from day to day with References and Reports now my work is done; when my bu≈øine≈øs, and what I de≈øerve is as well known (as the begger knows his di≈øh, or a man knows his right hand from his left.) I do humblie declare reallie to all the world, (I would have remembred that ≈øaying, a man may be over ju≈øt) or el≈øe I would have taken more con≈øideration then I have done of my own pre≈øervation, when I was offered ten thou≈øand pounds by the Claimers for to have conniv'd and let the State be cozened of the ≈øilver in the Admiraltie, as they were at the time of many Dutch prize ≈øhips and goods. It could not enter into your Petitioners heart to ex≈øpect ≈øuch delaies by references and old Court tricks; had I thought of ≈øuch dealings, I had known a waie to paie my ≈øelf. Had your Petitioner ≈øpent his ≈øpirits, time and e≈øtate to have ≈øtudied di≈øturbance and malignancie, as much as hee hath ≈øtudied the honour, peace, profit and welfare of this Common-wealth,
the ≈øilver in the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador and George had never been coined in the Tower, being two hundred ≈øeventie eight thou≈øand pounds, but by the treachery of ≈øome Merchants and others in the Admiraltie, had been cleared out of the Nation and ≈øent to the Dutch. Had your Petitioner December 16. 1652. at nine of the clock in the morning in the Court of Admiraltie been po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with the dumb ≈øpirit of malignancie, your Judges of the Admiraltie that verie daie and hour had cleared the afore≈øaid ≈øilver, the Admiral Van-Trump then lying on the Downes to have wa≈øted the ≈øilver to Holland; which had not your Petitioner prevented by ≈øea≈øonable applications to the Councel of State, might have prov'd of ≈øad con≈øequence, and have co≈øt many thou≈øand Engli≈øh mens lives, and God knowes what other dammages to this Nation, ≈øuch an over-≈øight in the Court of Admiraltie might have brought upon this Nation.

Here followeth the Lord Brad≈øhawes CERTIFICATE upon the De≈øire and Reque≈øt to him, of Sir Thomas Viner, Sir Iohn Barke≈øtead, Iohn Limbery, Maurice Thomp≈øon E≈øquires, Authori≈øed by his late Highne≈øs Oliver, to be Commi≈ø≈øioners to Examine this Bu≈øine≈øs.

body.head: The Lord Brad≈øhawes CERTIFICATE.

p.hi: I Have peru≈øed the Petition and con≈øidered of the de≈øires mentioned in the annexed Paper, and in compliance therewith ≈øo farr as my memory ≈øerves mee, which hath bin a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the view of ≈øeveral Orders, Certificates, Depo≈øitions and memorialls formerly made in the Petitioners Ca≈øe, and now ≈øhewed unto mee, I ≈øignifie and declare as followeth.

body.p: That although I may not take mee to make a narrative of Mr. Violets Ca≈øe, much le≈ø≈øe to give a punctuall accompte, after ≈øo many years, of what pa≈ø≈øed at the Council, relating to that engagement of theirs a≈ø≈øerted in the Petition (which to be in the manner therein ≈øet down) I can neither knowingly affirme nor deny, yet the Petitioners addre≈ø≈øes in the time of the Warr with the Dutche, concerning the ≈øtay of the Ships which had the Silver in them being very remarkable, I can for the ≈øub≈øtance te≈øtifie, and do well call to minde the Petitioners tenders and intimations to the Council, and undertaking the ≈øervice touching the Silver ≈øpecified in his Petition, and that upon good deliberation taken of the matter (the probability of his allegations being al≈øo much ≈øtrengthened by the concurrant circum≈øtances of ≈øome Letters about that time intercepted) he had thereupon very good encouragement given him by the Council, that (performing h ‚Ä¢ s di≈øcovery) his paines, co≈øt and care, ≈øhould bee throughly con≈øidered, and he honourably rewarded, or was told or promi≈øed to that effect.

Whereupon hee was Authori≈øed and appointed by the Council
to ≈øollivite and a≈ø≈øi≈øt in that whole bu≈øine≈øs as by their Orders appeareth, and while≈øt that Council ≈øatt, was taken notice of as the maine Agent in the whole conduct thereof, as the proceedings of tho≈øe times will ≈øhewe, what the beneficiall con≈øequence of that imployment, and what fruite thereof hath been to the State may bee better manife≈øted, by others who have been at the Heline of Affaires ≈øince the 20th of Aprill 1653. the day of the di≈ømi≈ø≈øion of the Parliament and old Council.

But if I may offer my ≈øence of the man and his actings, which I apprehend to be in part expected, my opinion was and is, that his ≈øea≈øonable interpo≈øition and prote≈øt in the Admiralty, applications to the Council, and di≈øcovery of the Dutch and Spani≈øh frauds touching the Silver Conte≈øted for, the≈øe actions accompanied al≈øo with great Charge, hazzard, and trouble on his part, as hee offers to Demon≈øtrate, and affirmes to bee well knowne, adjoyning thereto for the legall part, the con≈øtant a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the learned Advocate for the Common wealth, were the maine occa≈øion (if not the cau≈øa ≈øine qua non) of the after benefit received by the State upon conver≈øion of that Silver, the Petitioner being looked upon as the great Wheele that ≈øett all on work, as I believe it would bee te≈øtified for him by others, who had the honour to ≈øerve the Common-wealth in Council, when this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe was fir≈øt began, and afterwards untill the clo≈øe of the ≈øame if they were con≈øulted herein.
His lo≈ø≈øes Anno 1643. and his disbur≈øtments aboute the Silver, for which hee prayes ≈øatisfaction and indemnity, I mu≈øt leave to his own Evidencinge, and it ≈øeemes hee is ready for it.

p.hi:
The Councils Ingagements and Intentions to him-wards, at
his fir≈øt a≈ø≈øuming the employment, were not without good rea≈øon uncommitted to writing for avoiding of all mi≈øconstruction, they propo≈øing on the one hand a faire and ju≈øt proceeding, and on the other all due encouragement to that per≈øon who≈øe di≈øqui≈øition and effectual pro≈øecution for making good the claime they knew mu≈øt needs be very expen≈øive, and liable to many difficulties and hazards from the multitude of the contrary intere≈ø≈øed parties, and their many and powerful abettors: So as any one in rea≈øon may conclude, that without ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance of the part of the Councel, and relying upon it on the Petitioners part, the whole bu≈øine≈øs had mi≈øcarried, as left, un-undertaken, and undone.

The Petitioners ≈øore task and merit of the State in this particular: I ≈øhall not further meddle with; or take upon me to divine or determine what the i≈ø≈øue will, or ≈øhould be as to his ju≈øt recompence and compen≈øation.

body.p: His zeale, re≈øolution, activity, and ability to promote the publick intere≈øt in divers re≈øpects, being known to me heretofore in good mea≈øure, as I formerly held my ≈øelf obliged to cheri≈øh, and ≈øo much as in me was to improve for the States advantage: So upon the occa≈øion now offered, wherein the honour and ju≈øtice of the State, and their profit al≈øo, as I conceive, is mainly involved; I am very free to render him according to my be≈øt ob≈øervation of him and his actings, this due and de≈øerved Te≈øtimony. Septemb. 5. 1657.

closer.signed: John Brad≈øhaw.

I Have received an intimation from you as referrees by vertue of an order from his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector referring to a Petition of Mr. Thomas Violet concerning his ≈øtaying the Ships Sam≈øon, Salvador and George: And the ≈øilver therein contained, That I would te≈øtifie my knowledge in writing concerning the ≈øame, or what el≈øe is contained in the afore≈øaid Petition, in a ready compliance with what is ≈øo intimated, I do in the fir≈øt place ≈øay, That I had not the particular knowledge of tho≈øe affairs, as they re≈øpect Ma≈øter Violets actings in them, which other Honourable Per≈øons had, and therefore cannot te≈øtifie ≈øo particularly concerning tho≈øe tran≈øactions as others may ≈øee ju≈øt cau≈øe to do, on Mr. Violets behalf only, Thus much in general I can and do freely te≈øtifie, from my own ob≈øervation and knowledge, that Mr. Violet did engage in that concernment of the ≈øtaying the ≈øhips Sam≈øon Salvador and George; and in di≈øcovering the fraudes endeavoured to be put upon the State touching the ≈øilver in
