body.head: Sir George Fleetwoods Report and Certificate upon the de≈øire and reque≈øt to him of Sir Thomas ∆≤iner, Sir John Barke≈øtead, John Limbrey, Maurice Thom≈øon, E≈øquires.
body.p: MR. Thomas Violet ≈øhewing me his Petition to his Highne≈øs, and his Highne≈øs, and his de≈øires mentioned in the annexed Papers, and reque≈øting me to certifie my knowledge of his ≈øervices for the Common-wealth, I finde my ≈øelf bound, as I am a lover of Ju≈øtice and Truth, that would to the uttermo≈øt of my abilities have vice puni≈øhed, and vertue rewarded, in pur≈øuance whereof I do ≈øignifie,

That I have known Mr. Violet for many years, he having daily recour≈øe to my ∆≤nele Watkins, during the time he had the office of head Searcher of the Port of London; They
advi≈øing together to get an Act pa≈øs again≈øt tran≈øporting gold and ≈øilver, and the Bill being brought by Mr. Violet into the Parliament, there was ≈øeveral references to the Committee of the Navy, Officers of the Mint, and Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Cu≈øtomes to certifie their opinions: and they all centured and agreed in this, that the Parliament, (if they would have the Mint ≈øet on Work, and the gold of the Nation pre≈øerved) the Act again≈øt tran≈øporting gold and ≈øilver then depending in the Hou≈øe ≈øhould be pa≈ø≈øed, this was Anno 1647. as appeares by the original Orders.

The≈øe actings of Mr. Violet for the Publick, together with ≈øeveral propo≈øals of Mr. Violets for the advancement of the Trade of the Nation, and Mr. Violets con≈øtant attendance for many years both at the Council of State and Parliament, and Council of Trade, to procure the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate: Cau≈øed many of the Members of the Hou≈øe and Council of Trade, and my ≈øelf among≈øt the re≈øt to take e≈øpecial notice of the Man, and ≈øuch of the Council and Parliament as were plea≈øed to make u≈øe of him found in Mr. Violet a deep and profound in≈øight into Mint-Bu≈øines, and Merchants affaires.

And this good opinion of Mr. Violet procured him this benefit in 1651. that many of the Council of State, and Parliament, waited an opportunity for to move in the Hou≈øe for Mr. Violets indemnity, and for the full re≈øtoratiln of his e≈øtate being about eleven thou≈øand pounds.

And this was promi≈øed to Mr. Violet 1651. a yeare before his undertaking this great ≈øervice of ≈øtaying the Silver mentioned in Mr. Violets Petition, and I am confident ‚ñ™ if Mr. Violet will take the paines to wait upon ≈øome of the Members
of Parliament and Council of State, he will have many honourable te≈øtimonies of this that I ≈øay be≈øides my ≈øelf.

And this was the true ground, and original of Mr. Violets being taking notice of by the State of his abilities to make di≈øcoveries of the fraudulent Claims of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador to the Silver in the Ships, mentioned in Mr. Violets Petition, all which Silver Mr. Violet by his ≈øea≈øonable di≈øcovery to the State, and by his prote≈øting in the Court of Admiralty in Decemb. 1652. was the only cau≈øe of getting the State this great Trea≈øure mentioned in the afore≈øaid Petition of Mr. Violet, being three hundred thou≈øand pounds, and the Parliament, and Council of State in 1652. impo≈øed upon Mr. Violet the whole care of the management of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the Court of Admiralty as to the di≈øcovering part of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors fraudulent claimes, as appeares unto me by the view of ≈øeveral Orders and Warrants.

It is mo≈øt apparent in the whole proceeding in this difficult ≈øervice, Mr. Violet had alwayes in his eye the re≈øtoration of his e≈øtate, or the value of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and the particular of Mr. Violets demands to the Parliament in 1651. was about eleven thou≈øand pounds, and had he not had a real a≈ø≈øurance from the Council of State in Decemb. 1652. for the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, or the value, this great Bu≈øine≈øs had been lo≈øt and left un undertaken by Mr. Violet, had he not had both ≈øuch a promi≈øe, (and al≈øo he relied on the ≈øame) for ju≈øt performance, for Mr. Violet in this his high undertaking ventured all his E≈øtate, Life, Liberty, and expended in this ≈øervice above five hundred pounds, as I finde by the depo≈øitions of foure per≈øons employed in this ≈øervice.
I remember well the appearing of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador in the Parliament 1652. in December, demanding the Ships, Sam≈øon Salvador, and George, with their ≈øilver and lading.

It is very remarkable, the courage of Mr. Violet, in giving the Amba≈ø≈øador of Spaine ≈øo high a charge in 1652, 1653. concerning his undue practices to defraud the Nation of this ≈øilver: And yet the Amba≈ø≈øador never to vindicate his reputation, nor to de≈øire reparation, he being here above a yeare after: This ≈øhews apparently there was a de≈øign ≈øet on foot by the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador to defraud the Nation in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the ≈øilver Pri≈øes, for when I ≈øee the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador make no Addre≈ø≈øes to the Parliament for reparation, I was a≈ø≈øured Mr. Violet would make him let go his hold and claime of this ≈øilver mentioned in his Papers, which he delivered into the Hou≈øe.

∆≤pon peru≈øal of Mr. Violets Papers I ob≈øerved, that though the Parliament was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed 1653. the 20. of April, yet Mr. Violets ≈øore task continued on him ≈øtill, he being by that pre≈øent Council looked upon as the great wheel that ≈øet all on working, as to the di≈øcovering part, and this appeares under the hand of Doctor Walker in ≈øeveral Letters writing to Mr. Dore≈ølaws, Mr. Bud the States Proctor, Mr. Arnold, Mr. How, to require them all in their ≈øeveral places to let Mr. Violet, and all ≈øuch as he employs under him have the full view and in≈øpection of all proceedings in the Regi≈øter of the Admiralty, and to require Mr. Violets attendance, he paying ≈øeveral per≈øons, and expending in this bu≈øine≈øs above five hundred pounds, as I finde it ≈øworne by ≈øeveral per≈øons.

It is true for ≈øome rea≈øons of State Mr. Violets a≈ø≈øurance and reward was uncommitted to writing to avoid claimers, and
mi≈øcon≈øtruction of lewd tongues, and to carry an even hand both in re≈øpect of the claimers, and the Spani≈øh Amba≈øsador: But this omi≈ø≈øion was not to fru≈øtrate Mr. Violet of his dearly earned reward, the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate; many of the then Council of State, if they be attended by Mr. Violet, will ≈øay this could never enter into their thoughts.

To ≈øet a man ≈øo ≈øore a task; and ≈øtrictly to impo≈øe on him his daily attendance, and to enable him to undergo this great and heavy weight to be a≈ø≈øi≈øted by ten ≈øeveral per≈øons, foure of them ≈øwear Mr. Violet expended, be≈øides all his pains, hazard, and labour, five hundred pounds in this ≈øervice.

And I am per≈øwaded had not Mr. Violet undertaken this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in that very nick of time he did 13. of Decemb. 1652. and con≈øtantly and vigilantly followed, and agitated in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, both at the Council of State, and Admiralty; this great quantity of ≈øilver had been lo≈øt, and the State deluded with pretended claimes, and how ≈øea≈øonable a ≈øervice this was at that conjuncture of time, and the happy fruit and effect ≈øo great a trea≈øure brought to the Nation, is vi≈øibly to all men.

My opinion is that for the Honour (and I may ≈øay profit of this Nation, to encourage all men for the future to be faithful to the Common-wealth, and to expo≈øe their Per≈øons, and expend both their ≈øpirits and pur≈øes for the Honour and ≈øafety of the publick, as Mr. Violet hath done in this great undertaking, and brought it to a happy i≈ø≈øue.

That as the ≈øum of money was the greate≈øt that ever (I think) at one time was ≈øaved to this Nation by any one mans di≈øcovery, ≈øo his reward ≈øhould be ≈øutable, not only to have the ful re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, which was faithfully, to my knowledg,
promi≈øed to him, both by many of the Council of State and Parliament before ever Mr. Violets undertaking this ≈øervice mentioned in his Petition. But this ≈øervice being fini≈øhed, Crowns all his former undertakings, and in my opinion he not only de≈øerves the full re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, but to have an honourable memorial left to po≈øterity of his ≈øea≈øonable and faithful di≈øcoveries and ≈øervices concerning the afore≈øaid ≈øilver, That ≈øo all others may be encouraged to tru≈øt to the faithful promi≈øes of the Council of State, when they ≈øhall ≈øee the States promi≈øes faithfully performed in ≈øuch a conjuncture of time, as when the Government was changed.

And I think I am bound in my con≈øcience, that taking notice of ≈øuch high propo≈øals as were propounded either in Parliament or Council of State, during the time I had the honour to ≈øerve the Publick (among≈øt which I have and do hold this ≈øervice mentioned in Mr. Violets Petition to be one of the fir≈øt rank that was ever pre≈øented in Parliament or Council of State, when the work is fini≈øhed,) I hold my ≈øelf obliged, both in honour and con≈øcience to give the undertaker, ≈øuch as Mr. Violet, that hath in this bu≈øine≈øs laboured all along to the perfecting of the work, The State having gotten by this di≈øcovery and undertaking, about three hundred thou≈øands pounds (as M. Violet affirms to me ≈øo much money coined) he having fini≈øhed his ≈øore task, I think I am bound in ju≈øtice to help him what I can, that ≈øo after ≈øo great paines and hazard Mr. Violet might not work in vain.

And upon this account I make this certificate, whereof one part is upon my own knowledge and experience I have had of Mr. Violet, the other Part I refer to the Orders of Parliament, Council of State, Doctor Walkers warrants, and the Certificates of the Officers of the Mint.

And I wi≈øh for the due encouragement of all active Per≈øons that ≈øhall hereafter venture upon great and high undertakings for the profit, honour, and ≈øafety of this State and Common-wealth, that Mr. Violets reward and compen≈øation for this great ≈øervice may alwayes be had in remembrance, for no doubt ≈øo great and faithful a ≈øervice di≈øcovered ≈øo ≈øea≈øonably, will have a happy i≈ø≈øue, and the reward from the State will be ≈øutable to the greatne≈ø≈øe of the Service.

closer.signed: G. Fleetwood.

postscript.p: This is a true Copy of Sir George Fleetwoods certificate on the behalf of Mr. Thomas Violet,

closer.signed: examined by me Thomas Hewet, John Rimmer.

body.head: Doctor WALKERS CERTIFICATE.
body.p:
I Can truly, and do certifie, That when the Ca≈øes of and touching the Silver in the three ≈øhips, the Samp≈øon, Salvadore and St. George, were depending in the Court of Admiralty, touching the ≈øame being Prize. And before the Argument touching the ca≈øting the Onus probandi thereupon in that Court were made; Mr. Thomas Violet did repair to the ≈øaid Court of Admiraltie, and to my ≈øelf, being Advocate to the then Parliament, and did produce from the then Council of
State, one order bearing date the 13. of Decemb. 1652. And al≈øo ≈øome other Orders of the then Council of State, whereby he the ≈øaid Mr. Violet was ordered to repair to the ≈øaid Court of Admiralty, and al≈øo to my ≈øelf as Advocate for the then Parliament; And to look after and take care of tho≈øe ≈øaid bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, touching the ≈øaid Silver in the ≈øaid three Ships or to ≈øuch effect, and accordingly hee the ≈øaid Mr. Violet was therein very carefull, and indu≈øtrious, and did by him≈øelfe and others imployed by him, and at his owne charge take great paines in following the ≈øaid bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and in ≈øearching after, and examination of the ≈øaid Ships, Papers, and Bookes, and writings, and other matters that were exhibited into the Regi≈øters of the Admiraltie, and in making his ob≈øervations thereupon, and collecting thereout what might make for the State, and looking after ≈øuch other evidences as hee could finde out, (wherein hee was noe way remi≈øs or negligent) and the ≈øaid Mr. Violet did openly owne the ≈øame bu≈øine≈øs in Court, and moved therein on behalf of the Parliament, and that earne≈øtly and with zeal, and made or declared ≈øome Prote≈øt therein in the ≈øaid Court of Admiraltie. And did not only particularly apply him≈øelf to me, but did al≈øo in my hearing privately pre≈øs it to ≈øome of the then Judges of the Admiralty. And I did finde that the ≈øaid Mr. Violet, by his much publick owning and appearing therein in the behalfe of the Parliament and then Council of State, did contract much envy and ran great hazards of his per≈øon, and it cannot bee but that he did lay out and expend much money to ≈øuch as he imployed therin.

closer.signed: Wal. Walker.

div.p:
I ≈øhall humbly de≈øire your Honours to ob≈øerve that Doctor Walker
if hee had plea≈øed, could have certified in this his Certificate, the day of the moneth I made my Prote≈øt again≈øt the Judges of the Court of Admiraltie, being the 16. Decemb. 1652. again≈øt their di≈øcharging this Silver, and the great Conte≈øt I had with them about it before I could get the Judges to Re≈øpite their Judgment, and that to his knowledge the Judges of the Admiraltie complained of mee to the Council of State that very day in the afternoone for doing this ≈øervice, and that had it not bin for your Petitioner, the State had bin cozened of all this Silver. But becau≈øe I printed the li≈øt of the Dutch prizes, and di≈øcovered the abu≈øes and cheates put on the Nation by ≈øome Officers in the Admiralty, (no doubt but this bu≈øine≈øs ≈øtuck in his ≈øtomack, and to gratifie ≈øome guilty per≈øons that had cozened the State) and that made him to certifie my bu≈øine≈øs by halfs, and but part of his knowledge.

But it matters not as long as your Petitioner hath his ≈øervices fully certified concerning this Silver bu≈øine≈øs, under the hands of Sir James Harrington, Sir George Flettwood, and the Officers of the Mint.

This memoriall I put down to let Doctor Walker know, that though hee could forget mee and certifie his knowledge by halfes, It may 'one' day Ile in my lot not to forget him, but to certifie my knowledge of him fully, when I finde a convenient time.

If Doctor Walker could have made this di≈øcovery without mee, hee would never have intreated mee to doe it, as appears by his Orders and Letters to Mr. Dori≈ølaws, Mr. Bud, Mr. How, and Mr. Arnold, Officers in the Court of Admiraltie. vid. fol. 69. 70. 71. 72. 73.

body.head: Sir. James Harringtons Report and Certificate upon the de≈øire and reque≈øt to him of Sir Thomas Viner, Sir John Barkstead, Iohn Limbery, Maurice Thom≈øon E≈øquires.
body.p:
I Have read Mr Thomas Violets Petition, and his de≈øires mentioned in the annexed Paper, as al≈øo the de≈øires of the Referrees, and in compliance of his ≈øad reque≈øt,
≈øo farr as my memory ≈øerves mee, which hath been refre≈øhed by the veiw of ≈øeverall Orders of Parliament, Council of State, Certificates, Depo≈øitions, and memorialls formerly tran≈øacted in the Petitioners bu≈øine≈øs, both concerning the Silver mentioned in the Petition, and ≈øeverall other of Mr. Violets faithfull ≈øervices done by him for this Common-wealth.

I do ≈øignifie and declare, that from the yeare 1649. to the year 1653. being the time I had acquaintance with Mr. Violet, I ob≈øerved that hee had a deepe profound judgement and in≈øight into the ≈øecrets of our Mint in England, & knew the mi≈øtery and ≈øecrets of other Mints in forreign parts, and the ≈øeverall Arts, mi≈øteries, and waies forreign Nations u≈øed to induce and draw Bullion both gold and ≈øilver to their ≈øeveral Mints and Countries, and the Lawes and ordinances forreign Nations made for hindering the exportation in every re≈øpective Countrey.

And that both my ≈øelfe and others, my A≈ø≈øociates of the Council of State, in bu≈øine≈øs of high and great concernments as to the Civil part, e≈øpecially concerning the Mint and Trade made u≈øe of him in many perticular ≈øervices for the Publique.

And indeed for my ≈øelfe I mu≈øt give him this ju≈øt and due Commendations, that for all the time I knew him at the Council of State, hee was very diligent to advance the publique ≈øervice, as will appeare by the Acts of the Council in tho≈øe times, if recour≈øe be thereunto had.

Which actings of his, and his diligent attendance at
the Council of State, was in pro≈øecution for many years to obtain his e≈øtate which was taken from him by the Parliament, as hee con≈øtantly affirmed both to my ≈øelfe and others, my a≈ø≈øociates of the Council of State, when wee imployed him in many great bu≈øine≈ø≈øes for the Common wealth, and this dilligent and vigilant carriage of his, pre≈øented him both to the Parliament and Council of State, as a man who≈øe abilities, activity, re≈øolution and fideliry, was very nece≈ø≈øary and ≈øerviceable for the benefit of the State, and great u≈øe was made of him in tho≈øe times by the State, as appeares by the Silver bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, mentioned in his Petition.

And that to tho≈øe that knew him both in Parliament and Council of State, his tru≈øt and faithfullne≈ø≈øe was held in very good e≈øtemee, and his ≈øervices were eminently taken notice of both by my ≈øelfe and divers others, both in the Parliament and Council of State, for ≈øeverall years before Mr. Violet ingaged in this great undertaking of ≈øtaying the Dutch Silver in December 1652. mentioned in his Petition.

And truly I mu≈øt atte≈øt that both my ≈øelfe and ≈øeverall others of the Parliament and Council, looked upon Mr. Violet in this great undertaking of ≈øtaying the Silver mentioned in his Petition, in the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, That Mr. Violet was the great wheele of the worke that got the State this great Trea≈øure, for hee both di≈øcovered to the Council of State, the fraude of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour, and the fraudes
of the Dutch and Spani≈øh Claimers to the Silver, which ≈øea≈øonable di≈øcovery of his at the Council ≈øtayed it, together with his Prote≈øt in the Court of Admiraltie, being by him faithfully, and actively performed, the true Atte≈øtation whereof was examined at the Council of State, and now ≈øhewed mee under the handes of the Officers of the Mint.

By all which proceedings it appeares to mee that Mr. Violets engagements in this ≈øervice, was not only the in≈øtrumentall occa≈øion of getting the State this great Trea≈øure mentioned in his Petition, but the only cau≈øe, and without him and his Prote≈øting in the Court of Admiraltie at that very in≈øtant nicke of time 16. Decemb. 1652. this great Trea≈øure being about three hundred thou≈øand pounds (as Mr. Violet affirmes to mee there was ≈øo much money taken out of the Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George) had bin all let go out of the Nation, and bin di≈øcharged by the Court of Admiraltie, and of what prejudiciall and dangerous con≈øequence, ≈øuch an over≈øight in the Court of Admiraltie might have produced to this Common-wealth at that conjuncture of time, when Van Trumpe the Dutch Generall was in the Downes, is obvious to all men to conjecture, as al≈øo the contrary, the great advantage and benefit that hath accrued to this Nation by Mr. Violets happie and ≈øuccesfull Prote≈øting in the Admiraltie again≈øt the di≈øcharge of this Silver, and oppo≈øing the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador, and all their numerous intere≈ø≈øed parties and Claimers, and their powerfull abettors joyned with it, the hard and voluntary
taske hee impo≈øed upon him≈øelfe (as I finde it ≈øworne by ≈øeverall Witne≈ø≈øes) and that be≈øides all his paines and hazards, hee expended in this ≈øervice above five hundred pounds.

And I finde by Doctor Walkers Warrants directed to Mr. Dori≈ølaus, Mr. Bud, Mr. Arnold, and Mr. Howe, the States Officers, and mini≈øters in the Court of Admiraltie, and by Orders of the Council of State, that ≈øince the 20th of Aprill 1653. Mr. Violet was required and enjoyned not only to contribute his own endeavours, but al≈øo at his own charge to imploy many others in makeing this di≈øcovery, which I finde to be atte≈øted under Doctor Walkers hand, and by the Depo≈øitions of ≈øeverall Per≈øons imployed by Mr. Violet, for that although the Parliament and Council of State were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the 20th day of Aprill 1653 yet Mr. Violets fore taske, expen≈øive, and dangerous imployment was impo≈øed and continued on him till the State had gotten the Silver, and this appears by Warrants from his Highne≈ø≈øe Council, and Doctor Walker of a later date ready to bee produced, which I have ≈øeen.
The≈øe actings of his, accompanied with great charge, hazard, and trouble, ≈øhewes to all the world Mr. Violets faithfull ≈øervice, con≈øtant fidelity, and love to his Country.

Upon due con≈øideration of all the premi≈ø≈øes, I am very willing to te≈øtifie my knowledge of Mr. Violet, according to that true worth and great abilities I know in the man, with his readines to ≈øerve his Countrey,
and I do it the rather becau≈øe hee had ≈øeverall times my faithfull promi≈øe (when I was a Councellor of State) that I would te≈øtifie his ≈øeveral ≈øervices done to the Parliament, by which I conceive hee merited the indempnity and re≈øtoration of his e≈øtate before this great undertaking, mentioned in his Petition about the Silver in Decemb. 1652 but doing this ≈øervice ≈øucce≈øsfully in ≈øtaying this Silver, I thinke my ≈øelfe therefore now much more bound in honour and con≈øcience, after ≈øo longe a tryall of this mans patience, con≈øtancy, and fidelity, and his love to his Country, to give you my true ob≈øervation of the man, both in his acting this and other great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and this I atte≈øt upon my knowledge and experience of the man, and not upon hear-≈øay.

And if the rule of the Go≈øpel be ob≈øerved, viv. that all men do to others as they would be done to them≈øelves, Mr. Violet cannot be many weekes without a full re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate or the value, and if Mr. Violet hath had ≈øuch mea≈øure as he hath pre≈øented to the world in print, ≈øurely I mu≈øt ≈øay he hath had hard mea≈øure, but I wi≈øh him not only his E≈øtate, but al≈øo an honourable memoriall to be left to Po≈øterity of his great ≈øervice, according to former engagements to him by ≈øome of the then Council of State, for this particuler ≈øervice of the Silver mentioned in his Petition, this ju≈øt due and de≈øerved Te≈øtimony, I do give him this fir≈øt of October 1657.

closer.signed: James Harrington.
This is a true Copy, Examined by us Thomas Hewet, John Rimmer, John Symes.

div.p: WHen I brought the≈øe afore≈øaid Certificates to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, to whom the Examination of my ≈øervices touching this Silver, was referred by the late Lord Protector Oliver, I offered to bring them the Te≈øtimonialls of ≈øeveral others of the Council of State, to affirme and atte≈øt to the ≈øame effect as the≈øe honourable Gentlemen had don.

But the Referrees were plea≈øed to ≈øay they had ≈øeen enough, and to forbid mee the troubling any others for conformation of what I had alleadged in my Petition, they declaring that the≈øe Certificates afore≈øaid had given them full and ample ≈øatisfaction, and that they were ≈øorry I ≈øhould bee ≈øo dealt with, and that they did ≈øee my ≈øad ≈øufferings, and would fully and effectually certifie the true State of my bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to his Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver what I had merrited from the State, they not doubting but I ≈øhould have not only the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds paid mee for this di≈øcovery and great ≈øervice but al≈øo ≈øhould receive an honourable reward over and above for the ≈øame.
To Incourage others for the future to relie and tru≈øt to the Promi≈øes of the Council of State, and to be faithfull in the tru≈øt that was impo≈øed on them by the State.

The Referrees telling your Petitioner, that in Ju≈øtice, Prudence, Honour, and Policie, the States must pay mee, and that they could not expect but the end of my labours would come to a happy i≈ø≈øue, and thereupon the afore≈øaid Referrees
were plea≈øed to give mee this honourable Certificate following, concerning the true State of my ≈øervices, and the Council of States ingagements to pay mee the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and an honourable reward over and above. viz.

body.p: WHereas by your Highne≈øs order of the 13th of July la≈øt, your Highne≈øs was plea≈øed to referr unto us or any three of us Mr. Thomas Violets Petition hereunto annexed, whereby wee are directed to examine the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øugge≈øted therein, and to ≈øtate and certifie the Ca≈øe to your Highne≈ø≈øe, together with our opinions upon the whole matter.

In obedience whereunto wee having peru≈øed the ≈øaid Petition, and finding many perticular ≈øervices which the Petitioner thereby affirmeth were done by him and well knowne to the Lord Brad≈øhawe, and many others of the late Council of State, and hee having named to us Sir James Harrington, Sir George Fleetewood, and Francis Allen E≈øquires, who (among≈øt other of the Council) knew the Petitioners great ≈øervice done concerning the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, their Silver and Lading mentioned in his ≈øaid Petition, and the Council of States intentions and engagements to him, when hee undertooke
to di≈øprove the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador, and Spani≈øh and Flemi≈øh Claimers thereunto in the yeares 1652. and 1653.

For the clearing of the truth of the Petitioners allegations ≈øugge≈øted in his ≈øaid Petition, wee held it nece≈ø≈øary to acquaint the Lord Brad≈øhawe, and the ≈øaid Sir James Harrington, Sir George Fleetwood, and Francis Allen E≈øquires, with your Highne≈ø≈øe ≈øaid Referrence, and ≈øent them Copies thereof with the ≈øaid Petition, and with our de≈øires that they would certifie their particular knowledges therein, that ≈øo wee might the better returne to your Highne≈ø≈øe the true ≈øtate of the Petitioners Ca≈øe.

And wee have accordingly received Certificates from all the afore≈øaid Per≈øons, which wee have hereunto annexed, together with the ≈øaid Petition and Referrence for your Highne≈ø≈øe gracious peru≈øeall, all which Te≈øtimonialls and Certificates ≈øet forth the great ≈øervices done by the Petitioner, by his ≈øea≈øonably di≈øcovery of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors, and Claimers fraudulent endeavors to deceive the Common-wealth in December. 1652.

Wee have likewi≈øe peru≈øed ≈øeverall Orders of Parliament and Council of State, that ≈øet forth the intended fraudes and Practices of Don Alon≈øo de Cardenas, in coming in his owne Per≈øon to the Parliament and to the Council of State with ≈øeverall other Merchants, and their Claiming the Dutch Silver then aboard the ≈øaid Ships. And wee finde Mr. James Stenere committed by the Parliament for tampering
in this bu≈øine≈øs; Wee finde it atte≈øted under the hands of Mr. George Brett, James Hoare, and Thomas Birch, all Offieers of your Highne≈ø≈øe Mint (they being then in the Court of Admiraltie the 16th of Decemb. 1652.) that the Petitioner by his active, faithfull, and ≈øea≈øonable Prote≈øt in the ≈øaid Court (at that very in≈øtant nicke of time, and the very hower the Ships and Silver were in judgement before the Judges there, and upon di≈øcharge) the Petitioner by his Prote≈øt ≈øtayed the Silver mentioned in the Petition, being to the value of above two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds in Silver, taken out of the afore≈øaid Ships and Coyned in your Highne≈ø≈øe Mint, as the Petitioner hath proved to us upon the ≈øight of ≈øome accomptes.

And wee finde by ≈øeverall Orders of the Council of State, and Orders from Doctor Walker the Common-wealth's Advocate, and by ≈øeverall Depo≈øitions and Certificates that the whole weight of that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe was impo≈øed on the Petitioner by the Council of State in 1652. and 1653. as to the di≈øcovering part, and the Petitioner was required to pro≈øecute this ≈øervice after the di≈ø≈øolving of the long Parliament, by the Council of State then being.

The Heads of the Lord Brad≈øhaws Certificate. Wee al≈øo finde it atte≈øted by the Lord Brad≈øhawe, that the ≈øea≈øonable interpo≈øition of the Petitioner, and his Prote≈øting in the Admiralty, applications to the Council, and di≈øcovery of the fraudes, both of the Spani≈øh, and Dutch, touching the ≈øaid Silver, tho≈øe actions of the Petitioner accompanied al≈øo with great charge, hazard, and trouble,
were the maine occa≈øion if not the cau≈øa, ≈øine qua non, of the after benefit received by the State upon conver≈øion of that Silver, the Petitioner being looked upon by the then Council of State as the great wheele that ≈øet all on work, when this bu≈øine≈øs fir≈øt began and after til the clo≈øe of the ≈øame; The Councels engagements and intentions to him wards at his fir≈øt a≈ø≈øuming the imployment, were not without good rea≈øon uncommitted to writing for avoyding all mi≈øcon≈øtruction, they propo≈øing on the one hand a faire and ju≈øt proceeding, and on the other all due incouragement to that Per≈øon who≈øe di≈øqui≈øition and effectuall pro≈øecution for making good the claime, they knew mu≈øt needes bee very expen≈øive, and liable to many difficulties, and hazards, from the multitude of the contrary intere≈ø≈øed parties, and the many and powerfull abettors, ≈øo as any one in rea≈øon may conclude, that without ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance on the part of the Council, and relying upon it on the Petitioners part, the whole bu≈øine≈øs had mi≈øcarried, as left unundertaken and undone.

The Petitioners ≈øore task and merrit of the State, hee ≈øaith hee will not further meddle with; The Petitioners zeale, re≈øolution, and ability, to promote the publique intere≈øt in divers re≈øpects being knowne to him in good mea≈øure, as hee formerly held him≈øelf obliged to cheri≈øh and (≈øo much as in him was) to improve for the States advantage, ≈øo upon this occa≈øion offered wherein the honour and ju≈øtice of the State and their profit (as hee conceived) is mainely inv olved; Hee ≈øaith hee is very free to render the Petitioner according to his be≈øt
ob≈øervations of him and his actings, this due and de≈øerved Te≈øtimony. Dated the 5th of September, 1657.

The Heads of Sir James Harringtons Certificate. Sir James Harrington al≈øo certifies us, that the Petitioner was the great wheele of the worke which got the State this great Trea≈øure, for he both di≈øcovered to the Council of State, the fraudes of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador, and the Dutch and Spani≈øh Claimers to the Silver, which ≈øea≈øonable di≈øcovery ≈øtayed it at the Council, together with his Prote≈øt in the Court of Admiralty, being by him faithfully, and actively performed, the true atte≈øtation thereof was examined at the Council of State, and the Petitioner imployed ≈øeveral per≈øons at his own charge in the pro≈øecution of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, being required by the Council of State to do it, by all which proceedings he ≈øaith it appea ‚Ä¢ s that the Petitioners ingagements in that ≈øervice, was not only the in≈øtrumentall occa≈øion of getting the State that great Trea≈øure mentioned in the Petition, but the only cau≈øe and without him, and his Prote≈øting in the Court of Admiraltie, at that very in≈øtant nicke of time the 16th of Decemb. 1652. this great Trea≈øure (being about three hundred thou≈øand pounds) had bin all let go, and further ≈øaith, that the Councll of State did not only promi≈øe the Petitioner, the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, for this particular ≈øervice of the Silver, but al≈øo an honourable memoriall, and that both him≈øelf, and others of his a≈ø≈øociates of the Council of State, in bu≈øine≈øs of great and high concernment (as to the Civil part) e≈øpecially as to the Mint and Trade, made u≈øe of him in
many particulers for the Publique, and that he did ob≈øerve that all the time he knew the Petitioner, which was from 1649 to 1653. the Petitioner was very dilligent to advance the Publique Intere≈øt. The≈øe actings of the Petitioner accompanied with great charge, hazard, and trouble, ≈øhewes forch to all the world the Petitioners faithfull ≈øervices, con≈øtant fidelity, and love to his Country, this Te≈øtimony concerning the Petitioner, beares date under Sir James Harringtons hand the fir≈øt day of October 1657.

The Heads of Francis Allen E≈øq. his Certificate Mr. Francis Allen certifies, that the Petitioner did engage in that concernment of ≈øtaying the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, the Silver and Lading, and in di≈øcovering the fraudes endeavored to be put upon the State, touching the Silver in them conteyned with a great deale of Indu≈øtry, courage, and unweariedne≈øs, and indeed he conceives to his very great charge and expence, be≈øides his freequent attending the Committee for the Mint in ≈øeverall affaires referring thereunto, which could not but be expen≈øive to him al≈øo. This Certificate beares date the 27th of October 1657.

The Heads of Sir George Fleetwood his Certificate. Sir George Fleetwood likewi≈øe certifies, that the Petitioner by his ≈øea≈øonable di≈øcovery to the State of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour, and Claimers fraudes as to the Silver mentioned, and his Prote≈øting in the Court of Admiralty in December 1652. was the only cau≈øe of geting this great Trea≈øure mentioned in the afore≈øaid Petition, and that the Council of State in 1652 and 1653. impo≈øed upon the Petitioner the whole care of the management of this bu≈øine≈øs in the Court of Admiraltie as to the di≈øcovering
part, and that the Petitioner was ≈øeveral times imployed by the Council of State, and members of Parliament, and ≈øuch of the Council for the State or Parliament, as were plea≈øed to make u≈øe of him, found in the Petitioner a deep and profound in≈øight into the mi≈øteries of the Mint bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and Marchant affaires.

And the ≈øaid Sir George Fleetwood further ≈øaith, that it is mo≈øt apparent in the whole proceedings of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, that the Petitioner had alwaies in his eye the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, or the value of eleven thou≈øand pounds, which was the ≈øumme of Mr. Violets demand to the Parliament in 1651. which was promi≈øed the Petitioner by ≈øeverall members of the Council and Parliament for ≈øervice done before this great undertaking, and had not the Petitioner had a reall a≈ø≈øurance from the Council of State in Decemb. 1652. for the re≈øtoring to him his E≈øtate, or eleven thou≈øand pounds for this ≈øervice of the Silver, the whole bu≈øine≈øs had bin lo≈øt, and left un-undertaken by the Petitioner, had he not had ≈øuch a promi≈øe, and al≈øo relyed on the ≈øame for ju≈øt performance, and he ≈øaith it is true that for ≈øome Rea≈øons of State, Mr. Violets a≈ø≈øurance and reward was uncommitted to writing, to avoyd claymor, and mi≈øcon≈øtructions of lewde Tongues, but this omi≈ø≈øion was not to fru≈øtrate the Petitioner of his dearly earned reward, the re≈øtoration of his E≈øtate, as many of the late Council of State (if attended on by the Petitioner) would ≈øay this could never enter into their thoughts. This atte≈øtation under the hand of Sir George Fleetwood beares date 22th September 1657.

The≈øe Certificates with the former Atte≈øtations are briefly reported. The Originals ≈øpecifying the Petitioners particular ≈ø ‚Ä¢ rvices, in this and other his undertakings, more at large are hereunto annexed.

And whereas the Petitioner alledgeth in his Petition, that had he de≈øi≈øted the pro≈øecution of the ≈øaid bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in your Highne≈ø≈øe Court of Admiralty, and betrayed the Tru≈øt the Councel ‚Ä¢ f Sta ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ epo≈øed in him, he was ≈øeveral times offered, and might have received in the yeares 1652. and 1653. from ≈øeveral Merchants of Flanders then in London, the ≈øumme of ten thou≈øand pounds. Upon examination of this Allegation, we finde that the Merchants Claimers did ≈øeveral times offer the Petitioner ten thou≈øand pounds, to have de≈øerted this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of pro≈øecuting again≈øt the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador and Claimers concerning this Silver. And this was confe≈ø≈øed by the Merchants Solicitor to be true, as appeareth by two ≈øeveral per≈øons Affidavits, viz. Mr. Thomas Hewet, and Mr. William Savill, taken before William Gla≈øcock E≈øq. one of the Ma≈øters in Chancery.

And whereas the Petitioner alledgeth, That in the pro≈øecution of this great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, for the ≈øpace of about two years he was at the ≈øole charge him≈øelf thereof, and paid ten ≈øeveral per≈øons whom at that time he employed in this ≈øervice, as he hath proved by Affidavit of foure Witne≈ø≈øes, viz John Glover and Symon Baldwin Merchants, Thomas Ley and John Gerrell Citizens of London, Sworn before John Page and Robert Kelloway E≈øquires, Ma≈øters in Chancery, in 1654. That the Petitioner to their
knowledge expended above five hundred pounds in this ≈øervice in 1652. and 1653.

We finde the Petitioners debts and engagements contracted in the pro≈øecution of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the Silver Ships to be very great, amounting unto the ≈øumme of ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds, and upwards, which the Petitioner oweth at intere≈øt at this day. And he hath pre≈øented us a particular Li≈øt of the ≈øeveral mens names, of whom the Petitioner borrowed the ≈øaid money to do this ≈øervice, the truth of which appears unto us by the Affidavit of the ≈øaid Mr. Violet, ≈øworn before Doctor Harrington, one of the Ma≈øters of your Highne≈ø≈øe Court of Chancery, be≈øides ≈øeveral other great ≈øummes of money, which the Petitioner affirmes to us to have taken up at intere≈øt, for his nece≈ø≈øary ≈øupport and maintenanee ever ≈øince the Seque≈øtration of his e≈øtate in 1643.

May it plea≈øe your Highne≈ø≈øe, upon this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the Petitioner we have had many meetings. And being by your Highne≈ø≈øe Reference required not only to ≈ølate the Petitioners Ca≈øe, but to certifie our opinions upon the whole matter; We do accordingly in all faithfulne≈ø≈øe and humility certifie to your Highne≈ø≈øe, That upon due con≈øideration had of the great travel, charge and hazard, which the Petitioner hath undergone in the pro≈øecuting of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as hath been proved unto us as afore≈øaid. As al≈øo upon the Atte≈øtation of Sir George Fleetwood, and Sir James Harrington, concerning the Promi≈øe of the Councel of State to Mr. Violet, for the re≈øtoration of his e≈øtate, or eleven thou≈øand pounds.

Upon the whole matter, we do in all humble manner certifie your Highne≈ø≈øe, that we finde the Petitioner is a per≈øon, who not only de≈øerves the making good the Councel of States Promi≈øe to him as above≈øaid. But al≈øo by your Highne≈ø≈øe goodne≈øs, bounty and favour, that there be ≈øome ≈øignal Reward conferr'd upon him for this his eminent ≈øervice, according to the Promi≈øe of the ≈øaid Councel, as by the Certificates of Sir George Fleetwood, and Sir James Harrington, hath been atte≈øted unto us, That ≈øo all others for the future, may be encouraged to ≈øerve the intere≈øt of your Highne≈øs and the Common-wealth with all faithfulne≈øs, as it appeareth to us the Petitioner hath done.

We have al≈øo con≈øidered of the Petitioners debts and expences contracted in this ≈øervice, and for his ≈øupport ≈øince 1643. and beleeve the Petitioners engagements at this pre≈øent are very great and pre≈ø≈øing upon him. Wherefore being ordered by your Highne≈øs to certifie our opinions upon the whole matter, We humbly offer unto your Highne≈øs, That for the pre≈øent, (left the Petitioner ≈øhould be thrown into pri≈øon, and thereby utterly ruined for the very moneys he hath expended in this ≈øervice,) That ≈øome con≈øiderable ≈øumm of money in part may ≈øpeedily by your Highne≈øs be a≈ø≈øign'd unto him, for the paying of his debts contracted in this great ≈øervice for the publick. And al≈øo that care be taken for his ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, according to his quality. And that the remainder of the money promi≈øed him by the late Councel of State as afore≈øaid, may be paid unto him, a≈ø≈øoon as your Highne≈øs,
and the great affaires of the Common-wealth can permit, he having eminently and ≈øignally ≈øhewed his zeal, re≈øolution and forwardne≈øs, with the hazard of his life in this ≈øervice for his Countrey.

div.p: WHen your Petitioner after much paines, patience, and attendance, had gotten all the≈øe afore≈øaid honourable Gentlemens Certificates, and Te≈øtimonialls afore≈øaid in May 1658. I ca≈øt about how I ≈øhould bring my bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to have it come to a good i≈ø≈øue, that after ≈øo much delay I might have Ju≈øtice.

Thereupon your Petitioner, Petitioned Oliver Lord Protector, ≈øetting forth my former ≈øervices, and backing the ≈øame with ≈øo many bulwarks, and Certificates, that in ju≈øtice nor honour, I thought he could not delay me longer of my dearly earned reward, for I knew he could not deny a tittle in my Petition, but what I alledged I had fully proved, and that your Petitioner might be dealing with him for ≈øomething to get ≈øome imployment till he paid me the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds.

I did offer in part of my ≈øatisfaction of eleven thou≈øand pounds, to except of the imployment of Regulating the manufacture of gold and ≈øilver thread, with the fees I formerly had received, and I humbly offered to accept of this office at the value of two thou≈øand pounds, this office being a part of my own E≈øtate, for which I paid formerly 1500l.

And had I not bin di≈øturbed in the due execution, by ≈øome damorous cheating Silkmen, and Wyer drawers and Refiners who make it their common trade to cozen the wearers of gold and ≈øilver lace, and have melted down within this twenty yeares of the Plate and heavy ≈øilver Coynes of the Nation to the value of a million of money, to the wi≈øpeakable lo≈ø≈øe of the Common-wealth, by wa≈øting of the blood and ≈øinews of this Nations money, which ought to bee kept in peoples pur≈øes to maintaine Trade and Commerce, and not to be put upon Womens Petticoats to be bur≈øt and wa≈øted away.

For to induce his Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver to grant me the ≈øaid imployment, I annexed to my Petition and Papers a Report of the Committee of Parliament for Trade, Dated June 16. 1657. the original Report I have readie to produce to your Honours, which Report certifies that they have had it fully proved before them upon many dayes Examination, the great abu≈øes daily practi≈øed in the culling and melting down the currant ≈øilver coines of this Nation; for the expen≈øive making Gold and Silver Lace, Wyre and Thread. They certifie under their hands the dailie abu≈øes and cheats is put on the Wearers by the deceitful making Gold and Silver Thread and Lace, and al≈øo by ≈øeveral fraudulent practices in the making Gold and Silver Thread, that there is w ‚Ä¢ ≈øted of the ≈øtock of Silver in this Nation, about
thirty thou≈øand pounds a year. And that at this day there is no Rule nor Order for regulating the Work-ma≈øters, nor the Workers, but every one is 'e≈øt to cozentle Common-wealth, and they have certified it by what ≈øeveral wayes they do it; as will appear upon your Honours Peru≈øal of the Certificate of the Committee for Trade.

And the Committee for Trade finding this to be a great abu≈øe and cheat put on the Nation, have upon many dayes con≈øideration pre≈øented to that Parliament a Report of a Model and Way for the due Regulation of all the≈øe abu≈øes, and recommend in their Certificate your Petitioner for the execution of that ≈øervice, to be appointed the ≈øworn Officer, and to take the fees for doing that ≈øervice as formerly your Petitioner did, and that your Petitioner for the future put in ≈øecurity in the Exchequer, to warrant all the≈øe Manufactures of Gold and Silver Lace, Wyre and Thread to be good ≈øilver, that is drawn, a≈ø≈øayed, marked or ≈øealed at the Office.

And to warrant the ≈øame to be ≈øterling ≈øilver according to the Standard at the lea≈øt, or to pay all damage to the Party or Parties grieved, and that all Gold and Silver Thread ≈øhall be duly ≈øpun, with a due proportion of Silver to Silk, to the end that the Silver may not be bru≈øhed and rubbed, of Lace, Buttons, and other ≈øorts of works in Gold and Silver Thread, as it daily is, to the quantity, as hath bin proved to the Committee for Trade, of thirty thou≈øand pounds a year.

Whereupon his Highne≈ø≈øe refers this Petition July 13. 1658. and all the afore≈øaid Reports, together with a Report of the Councel of Trade, for the regulating the Manufacture
of Gold and Silver Thread, to the con≈øiderations of the Privie Councel, to take all the premi≈ø≈øes into their con≈øideration, and to ≈øee your Petitioner paid for the≈øe ≈øervices in ≈øtaying the Silver, and for his former lo≈øses according to Equity and Ju≈øtice.

And that if the Councel conceived it fit, I ≈øhould have the emploiment to ≈øee to the due regulating the manufacture of Gold and Silver Wyre and Lace, and to prevent the melting down heavy Engli≈øh money, as I de≈øired, but the Protector ≈øoon after died before I could get the Councel of State to meet, and ≈øo I renewed my Petition to the late Lord Protector Richard, who ≈øigned this Order to Gabriel Beck, and Francis Bacon E≈øquires, viz.

WHereas wee are informed that Thomas Violet of London Gold≈ømith, hath formerly done our mo≈øt dear Father of famous memory and this Nation ≈øeverall great ≈øervices, and that the ≈øaid Thomas Violet hath made his addre≈ø≈øes unto you, and in many particulars hath acquainted you with his humble de≈øires and good affections to our ≈øervice, and ≈øhewed you ≈øeverall tran≈øactions which ought to be taken into our con≈øiderations, being (as wee are informed) both for our ≈øervice, and the profit,

body.p:
IN obedience to your Highne≈ø≈øe Order of Referrence dated 28. October la≈øt hereunto annexed, wee have ≈øeveral times mett, and finde that Thomas Violet Petitioned your Highne≈ø≈øe royall Father for his promi≈øed reward, which Petition his late Highne≈ø≈øe 13 July 1657. referred to the Lord Bark≈øtead, Sir Thomas Viner, and ≈øeverall other Per≈øons, and their
Report thereupon is hereunto annexed, which Report we have peru≈øed, and al≈øo ≈øeverall Certificates of the Lord Brad≈øhawe, Lord George Fleetewood of the Vache, Sir James Hanington, and Francis Allen E≈øquires, and ≈øeverall other Certificates of the Officers of the Mint, as al≈øo the Orders of the late Council of State, Depo≈øitions, and Orders of the Court of Admiraltie, whereby it appears to us that the ≈øaid Thomas Violet by his ≈øea≈øonable interpo≈øition, and Prote≈øt in the Admiraltie 17. December 1652. his application to the then Council of State, and his di≈øcovery of the Spani≈øh and Dutch fraudes, touching the Silver in the Ships Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, being neere three hundred thou≈øand pounds, this his di≈øcovery and pro≈øecution in the Admiraltie, in all probabillity ≈øaved the State this great Trea≈øure, or el≈øe the State had been cozened thereof, as appeares to us at large by all the afore≈øaid Certificates ready to bee produced to your Highne≈ø≈øe.

Wee finde it proved and certified, that Thomas Violet expended ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds in the pro≈øecution of this ≈øervice, be≈øides all his time and hazard, which monies appeares to us he tooke up at interest, for which he ≈øtands indebted to ≈øeverall per≈øons, and he hath proved to us he is every day in danger to be taken in execution, for the very monies hee expendded in this ≈øervice, to get the State this great Trea≈øure.

And wee finde it atte≈øted unto your Highne≈ø≈øe royall Father, by the Certificates of all the afore≈øaid Referrees, that the State did promi≈øe unto Thomas Violet, upon his undertaking at his own charge to do this ≈øervice, to pay him the ≈øum of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and ≈øome other rewards for this ≈øervice, in ≈øtopping the afore≈øaid Silver.

And we finde that the Lord Bark≈øtead, Sir Thomas Viner and all the other Referrees humbly propounded to your Highne≈ø≈øe royall father as very fit and ju≈øt, that a con≈øiderable ≈øumme of money bee pre≈øently paid unto Thomas Violet, for to di≈øcharge his debts, and for his ≈øupport, le≈øt otherwi≈øe hee ≈øhould bee throwne into Pri≈øon and utterly ruined for the very money he hath expended in this ≈øervice, and that care be taken for the future for Thomas Violets ≈øub≈øi≈øtence according to his quality, and that the remainder of the money to make it up the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, promi≈øed to him by the State for this ≈øervice, may be paid unto Thomas Violet as ≈øoone as the great occa≈øions of the State can permit. This Certificate is hereunto annexed and ≈øigned by all the afore≈øaid Referrees 1. May 1658. to your Highne≈ø≈øe royall Father.

And wee humbly offer it as our opinions, that it is both ju≈øt, and fit for the honour of the State, that the monies Thomas Violet hath expended in this ≈øervice, and a due con≈øideration for his ≈øupport for the future be ≈øpeedily paid unto him, to pre≈øerve him from a pre≈øent ruine, and the remainder of the afore≈øaid ≈øum to be paid him as ≈øoone as the great occa≈øions of the Commonwealth will permit

And the Referrees do bold Thomas Violet to be a per≈øon very fit and u≈øefull for imployment either in your Highne≈ø≈øe Mint, or in the Office for the due Regulation of gold and ≈øilver wyer,
and Lace, &c. and in ≈øeveral other emploiments, as appears by ≈øeveral Certificates. And Violet him≈øelf hath made ≈øeveral Propo≈øals unto us in writing for his ≈øatisfaction, which we have hereunto annexed for your Highne≈ø≈øe gracious peru≈øal, In ≈øome of the≈øe Propo≈øals we do humblie apprehend Thomas Violet may be u≈øeful for your Highne≈ø≈øe and the publick ≈øervice. All which we humblie ≈øubmit to your Highne≈ø≈øe con≈øideration.

div.p: ABout the middle of April 1659. the late Lord Protector Richard, receiving the≈øe Certificates and this following Petition, blamed ≈øome per≈øons whom he had intere≈ø≈øed to give him a true Account of my ≈øufferings, and of my abilities and willingne≈ø≈øe to ≈øerve the Common-wealth, that they had not done it before, but to ≈øhew that his late Highne≈ø≈øe put a great value of my ≈øervices and ≈øufferings, and of my abilities to ≈øerve the Nation, (as ≈øome Honourable Gentlemen told me he did) he was plea≈øed upon the Reading this following Petition; to give me and ≈øome other Gentlemen which I had nominated in tru≈øt for my u≈øe, this en≈øuing Warrant for the making of a publick farthing for the u≈øe of England, Scotland, and Ireland, referring the Approbation and Confirmation thereof to the Parliament, to provide ≈øuch Orders and Rules as they thought be≈øt for the good of the People

I u≈øed the name of Edward John≈øon E≈øq. and ≈øome other Names for my u≈øe, and here followeth my Petition and Reference from his late Highne≈øs. And if the Parliament plea≈øe to employ me in this ≈øervice, and to grant me for thirty one years the entire and whole management of this Office, for making a common farthing. I will thankfully accept of the emploiment, and humbly and thankfully allow it as five thou≈øand pounds paid unto your Petitioner from the Common-wealth, in part of his due debt of eleven thou≈øand pounds for ≈øtaying the afore≈øaid ≈øilver. And your Petitioner will be tied to pay the maimed ≈øouldiers, during the time of this Grant, twelve-pence upon every twenty two ≈øhillings in farthings, which ≈øhall be uttered by me or my A≈ø≈øignes, in England, Scotland, and Ireland, which will be a con≈øtant revenue, and I will pay it in monethly to the Trea≈øurers for the maimed ≈øouldiers.

p.hi: And if the State plea≈øe to have farthings made of a ≈ømaller proportion, I will allow the ≈øouldiers five ≈øhillings for every twenty two ≈øhillings, and yet the≈øe Copper farthings ≈øhall be above as heavy again do the ordinarie farthings that now pa≈ø≈øe among us.

body.head: To his Highne≈ø≈øe RICHARD LORD PROTECTOR of England, Scotland, and Ireland. And the Dominions and Territories thereunto belonging.

p.hi: THat there are many fraudes and deceits daily practiced by diver≈øe petty Retayling Trade≈ømen, Chapmen and others, in makeing and uttering farthing tokens of their own ≈øtamping, almo≈øt every petty Retayling Trade≈øman putting forth a ≈øeverall farthing token not valueable without any Licence, ≈øome of Pewter, Tinn, Lead, Bra≈øs, and ≈øome of Copper, according to every mans fancy that makes their own farthing tokens.

Great numbers of the≈øe Retayling Trade≈ømen breake, others remove them≈øelves from one place to another, and many of them die in≈øolvant, and their farthing tokens thus unduly uttered beiug not valueable, one of them not being worth in value the ≈øixth part of a farthing, and ≈øome of their farthing tokens not worth the twentieth part of a farthing, the people of this Nation (e≈øpecially the poorer ≈øort) are daily cheated and cozened by the≈øe indirect practices.

body.p: To prevent the≈øe abu≈øes for the future, your Petitioners humbly pray your Highne≈ø≈øe that a common valueable farthing may be made of fine Ro≈øe Copper of a valueable weight (that is to ≈øay) of the weight of about halfe a quarter of an ounce Haver du poys to a farthing, and twenty two Shillings by tail, to weigh eight pounds Haver du poys, with the remedy of ≈øix pence under or over to pa≈øs currant within your Highne≈ø≈øe Dominions of England, Scotland, and Ireland, for all ≈øuch per≈øons as will make u≈øe of them for their nece≈ø≈øity of change, and to prohibit all other farthing tokens now made, or to be made or uttered within your, Highne≈ø≈øe Dominions afore≈øaid

That to have a valueable common farthing to be made, to pa≈øs currant within your Highne≈ø≈øe ≈øaid Dominions, is ≈øo needfull a thing in the Common-wealth, and of ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øity for change, that the making of the ≈øame will relieve and accommodate many thou≈øands of petty Trade≈ømen and poore people, as will plainly appeare unto your Highne≈ø≈øe, in our mo≈øt humble Rea≈øons and motives hereunto annexed, to which wee do mo≈øt humbly Referr.

Your Petitioners mo≈øt humbly pray your Highne≈ø≈øe, in re≈øpect of the great charge, and trouble they ≈øhall undergo in performing this ≈øervice for the good of the Common wealth, to grant unto them and their A≈ø≈øignes and Deputies, the ≈øole making and uttering of the afore≈øaid Common farthing for one and thirty yeares, and to prohibite all other farthings, and the making and counterfeiting of this farthing by any other, upon paine and lo≈ø≈øe of E≈øtate and
impri≈øonment during your Highne≈ø≈øe plea≈øure, and in con≈øideration thereof, your Petitioners will ≈øerve your Highne≈ø≈øe Dominions with valueable farthings of the goodne≈ø≈øe and weight afore≈øaid, and al≈øo pay unto your Highne≈ø≈øe Exchequer to your Highne≈ø≈øe u≈øe, twelve pence for every two and twenty ≈øhillings in farthings, which ≈øhall be vented and uttered by your Petitioners, their Deputie, or Deputies in England, Scotland, and Ireland, which will bee certaine revenew to your Highne≈ø≈øe of many hundred pounds a yeare, and a great accommodation and benefit to the poore of all your Highne≈ø≈øe Dominions.

WEE have peru≈øed the Petition of Edward John≈øon Junior E≈øquire, &c. together with the rea≈øons hereunto annexed, and our will and plea≈øure is, that our Sollicitor Generall prepare a booke fit for our ≈øignature, for the erecting of an Office for the ≈øole making, venting, and uttering of a Common farthing, to go currant in England, Scotland, Ireland, and Wales, according to the weight, proportions, and propo≈øitions, in their Petition, conteined with ≈øuch Rules to be ob≈øerved
by the Petitioners, or their A≈ø≈øignes, for the ≈øtamps, figures, and Arms of the ≈øaid farthings, as wee and our Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhall appoint, and for the granting the ≈øame to the ≈øaid Edw. John≈øon Junior E≈øq; &c. and their A≈ø≈øignes and Deputies for one and thirty yeares. Re≈øerving to us and our Succe≈ø≈øors twelve pence for every two and twenty Shillings of the ≈øaid farthings, ≈øo vented and uttered. And our Solicitor Generall is to attend and acquaint the Parliament with this Petition, together with the rea≈øons thereunto annexed, and with this our Warrant. VVho are de≈øired to Ordaine and appoint ≈øuch Rules, Prohibitions, and Penalties, for the effectuall and better management of this ≈øervice, the preventing of all former abu≈øes, and re≈øtrayning of the Counterfeiting, and importation of any the ≈øaid farthings from the parts beyond the Seas, as they ≈øhall thinke fit and nece≈ø≈øary for the carrying on of this Service for the good of the Common-wealth. Given at Whitehall the 19th day of Aprill 1659.
