div.p:
TO you of all others I am mo≈øt obliged to give a particular account of this bu≈øine≈øs, touching my ≈øtaying this ≈øilver, mentioned in this Book, becau≈øe, I could not have done this great ≈øervice of ≈øtaying the Shipps, Samp≈øon, Salvador, and George, and pro≈øecuting that bu≈øine≈øs in the Admiraltie, but that I had the money to do it from you, and I owe it you at this day about 1500 l. I have formerly ≈øhewed unto mo≈øt of you the Orders of Parliament touching this bu≈øine≈øs, and what endeavours were acted by Mr James Steneer, and ≈øeverall other Merchants, to cozen the State of all this great trea≈øure: All the printed Tran≈øactions mo≈øt of you have ≈øeen formerly, But the orders that mentions ≈øeaven ≈øeverall Letters of Mr. James
Steneres, and ≈øeverall other Merchants Letters which were read in Parliament. Mr. James Steneer writes to his Corre≈øpondents beyond Seas concerning the geting them this Silver out of the Admiraltie, (wee, meaning him≈øelfe and the re≈øt of his confederates, have made a great many friends among the great ones to ≈øpeake for us in the bu≈øine≈øs when it comes before them, (a wi≈øe man may gue≈øs who tho≈øe great ones were, and what great ones made a trade by cozining the Common-wealth in their Prizes) the Claimers of the ≈øilver at that time having ≈øtollen ≈øeveral ≈øcores of thou≈øand poundes out of the≈øe Ships, ≈øo that they weree full of money and they could bribe any Per≈øon in power that would be corrupted, in another of Mr Steneres Letter that was read in the Parliament Hou≈øe, Mr. Stenere writes to his Corre≈øpondents beyond Seas, that he mu≈øt have a care what hee did write to them touching this Silver bu≈øine≈øs, left his Letters ≈øhould be opened, when he was brought to the Parliament Barr the fir≈øt of December 1652. he rather cho≈øe to act the part of a foole, and a lyer, rather then to ≈øerve the Common-wealth to di≈øcover this de≈øign, for which tampering of his the Parliament committed him from the Barr to the Serjeant at Armes the fir≈øt of December 1652. as appeares by the journals of the Parliament, at that time Van Trumpe the Dutch Admirall was in the Downes, and no doubt but his mouth watered after this Silver, there is a Commi≈ø≈øion under the great Seal of Holland, and the originall orders of the States Generall. Upon the petition of the Merchants of Am≈øterdam, to guard the≈øe ≈øhips and ≈øilver from the Parliaments forces, which will remain to po≈øteritie to ≈øhow the ju≈øtice of this Nation in ≈øtaying this ≈øilver for Dutch ≈øilver, the truth of this being al≈øo confe≈øt in the Admiraltie by many of the
marriners and pa≈ø≈øengers which came that Voyage from Spain, and that the Pur≈øers books and many of the Bills of Lading were forged and altered at ≈øea after that they had heard certainly by ≈øome ≈øhips that the Dutch were at warrs with England.

The Parliaments Agent at Cades gave advice here to Mr Wil≈øon his kin≈øman, the day that the≈øe ≈øhips ≈øet ≈øaile from Cades, and though they gave out there that they were to go for Dunkirk, yet their de≈øigned Port was Am≈øterdam, they being loaden for the greate≈øt part upon the account of the Dutch, and the ≈øame was confe≈øt in the Admiraltie by many of the Pa≈øsengers and others.

Decemb. 14. 1652. The Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador Don Alon≈øo de Cardenas, Emba≈ø≈øador extraordinary for the King of Spain, came in per≈øon to the Parliament, and made an Oration in the Hou≈øe, claiming all this ≈øilver in the≈øe three ≈øhips to belong to his Ma≈øter and for his Ma≈øters ≈øubjects account; which Speech hee al≈øo at the ≈øame time pre≈øented to the Parliament in writing both in Spani≈øh and Engli≈øh, together with two bundles of papers touching this ≈øilver, which hee referred to the con≈øideration of the Hou≈øe: And for ≈øeveral daies hee made his appearance at the Council of State, and put in the like claimes for this ≈øilver, hee ingaging his Honour that no part of it did belong to the Dutch, as will appear by the proceedings and the records of the Council of State, and Mr Stenier was bayled, and his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe never called on to this day.

While the≈øe bu≈øine≈ø≈øes were tran≈øacted at the Parliament, Councel of State, and Admiraltie, I made the Lord Brad≈øhaw and many of the Council of State acquainted with the whole practice and fraud that was intended to be put on them by the afore≈øaid
parties, and that if they had not a ≈øpecial care, the Judges in the Admiraltie would di≈øcharge this ≈øilver, and the Dutch had rather it ≈øhould be in the bottom of the ≈øea than wee ≈øhould have it. Upon this Information the Council of State commanded mee to attend carefully the motions of the Court of Admiraltie and the Merchants touching this Silver, and from time to time to give the Council an account what was done in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

Whereupon, December 15. 1652. I made the Council acquainted, That the Judges of the Admiraltie had appointed to bring the≈øe ≈øhips, Samp≈øon, Salvador and George, their ≈øilver and lading to a judgment the next day, being Decemb. 16. in the Admiraltie; And that I did believe the Judges would cleare the ≈øhips, the Lord Brad≈øhaw and ≈øome others of the Council askt mee what rea≈øon I had to ≈øay ≈øo or to ≈øu≈øpect ≈øo: Whereupon I told them, the Commi≈øsioners of Dutch prize Goods had given me a warrant to go aboard the≈øe Dutch prize ≈øhips when I pleas'd, and to imploie whom I thought good to get acquaintance with the ≈øeamen aboard the≈øe ≈øhips. And I had certain intelligence, that Otho George, Captain of the Samp≈øon, had commanded all his men to be in readine≈ø≈øe and had taken in fre≈øh victualling and biskets, and that in a few daies they ≈øhould be at Dunkirk, declaring that Van Tromp would do them no hurt though hee were on the Downes.

Upon this di≈øcovery, many of the Council of State did apprehend the great dammage and danger the Nation was in if this great trea≈øure ≈øhould fall into the hands; of the Dutch, and after much debate I was commanded by the Council to attend in the Court of Admiraltie, Decemb. 16. all the while the Court ≈øate, and if the Judges did go about to clear the ≈øilver, then I
≈øhould make my Prote≈øt again≈øt their proceedings, till my Witne≈ø≈øes were examined that ≈øhould di≈øcover the fraud: And the Councel likewi≈øe charged mee, That if the Judges askt mee by what authoritie I made my Prote≈øt, I ≈øhould deny I had any order from the Councel of State but I ≈øhould do it upon my owne peril and account, if I were certain I could di≈øprove the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador, and if I did prove that there was ≈øilver aboard the≈øe ≈øhips belonging to the Dutch, out of the first hundred thou≈øand pounds that was coined of this ≈øilver, I ≈øhould be paid eleven thou≈øand pounds, being in lieu of my e≈øtate that I had for many yeares petitioned for, whereupon I told the Council the e≈øtate the Parliament took from me, endamaged me above ≈øixteen thou≈øand pounds, many of the Councel replying (Perform you what you have undertaken, which we believe you are never able to do) and you ≈øhall have an honourable reward for this ≈øervice, over and above eleven thou≈øand pounds which you claim for your e≈øtate. I have done this ≈øervice, and two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds the State hath had, and employed it for the de≈øence of the Common-wealth, in paying the Army and Navy, as will appear by the Accounts of Coll. Bark≈øtead; yet to this day the Council of State hath not performed their faithful Promi≈øe to me, to pay me eleven thou≈øand pounds, and to give me an honourable reward over and above for this ≈øervice.

It is very remarkable, that there was a de≈øigne laid among≈øt ≈øome of Mr Steniers great ones to cozen the State of this Trea≈øure; and would I have been Knave, I might have been one of his great ones, and have taken ten thou≈øand pounds to let the ≈øilver go, as in this Book is cortifiedby many honourable per≈øons might have had.

And that to ≈øome in the Admiralty, my appearing in that Court to ≈øtay this ≈øilver was mo≈øt di≈øta≈øtfull and unex≈øpected, and ≈øpoiled ≈øome peoples markets both in the Admiraltie and other places too; for ≈øome of the Judges in the Admiralty, (Exton and Stevens) Decem. 16. 1652. were ≈øo farre from giving mee thanks for my di≈øcovery, and for making my Prote≈øt in the behalf of the State to ≈øave this ≈øilver (which had not their intere≈øt and profit layen another way they ought to have done) but they contrariwi≈øe openly in the Court before many hundreds of merchants have reviled mee and would of di≈øcharged this ≈øilver.

And had I not received a command from the Council of State the day before to act in that manner, to be ≈øure to keep the Judges from di≈øcharging the ≈øilver, let the Judges ≈øay what they plea≈øed, the Iudges would that morning have di≈øcharged the ≈øilver, and con≈øulted together to commit mee; they di≈øputed the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe ≈øo lowd, that I and many others heard it: And the Iudges bid Wyeen the then Regi≈øter of the Admiralty call on the ≈øhips Samp≈øon, Salvador and George, not minding what I ≈øaid: this can be proved by many merchants, and is fully certified by the Officers of the Mint.

Whereupon I told Mr Wyeen the Regi≈øter, that if he and the Iudges did di≈øcharge the ≈øilver in the≈øe ≈øhips, and did not forbear their ≈øentence till my Witne≈ø≈øes were examined, I would make it the deare≈øt daies work they ever did in their lives or to that effect. And I undertook before the Iudges in the Admiralty upon the peril of my life to di≈øprove
the Sani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador and Flemmi≈øh Claimes to this ≈øilver. Whereupon Mon≈øieur Motett (the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors Secretary) hearing mee ≈øay ≈øo to the Iudges, was in a very great rage, and ≈øo were all the re≈øt of the Claimers.

Whereupon I told the Iudges, that if they would clear the ≈øilver, notwith≈øtanding my Prote≈øt, before my witne≈ø≈øes were examined, it was mo≈øt apparent the Common-wealth was betrayed, and bribes given and taken by ≈øome great ones to cozen the Common-wealth of this ≈øilver, but it ≈øhould not be in their power to do it, for I would prevent them.

And that if the Iudges did proceed to di≈øcharge this ≈øilver, and that this ≈øilver come into the hands of the Dutch, the Iudges lives and e≈øtates could not make the Common-wealth ≈øatisfaction; for that Van Tromp the Dutch General was then on the Downer, and an ha≈øtie Iudgment, before the truth of this plot was di≈øcovered, would put this ≈øilver into the Dutch mens power, which might be of ≈øad con≈øequence to this Nation, and may co≈øt many thou≈øand Engli≈øh men their lives. VVhereupon all the Spani≈øh and Flemmi≈øh Claimers were in a great rage, heat and di≈øcontent.

Two of the Iudges (Exton and Stevens) told mee I had undone my ≈øelfe for ever, in making my Prote≈øt again≈øt the di≈øcharge of the ≈øilver, and by my other actions and words that day in the Admiralty; and ≈øo the Iudges commanded mee to attend the Council of State that afternoon: And ≈øo the Court broke up, the Spaniards and
Flemmings cur≈øing mee bitterly, and I ex≈øpected every minute to be murdered by them.

The Iudges of the Admiralty prophe≈øied truer then Lilly hitherto; for they told mee the ≈øtaying of this ≈øilver would undo mee: for if the Council of State do not pay mee the eleven thou≈øand pounds they promi≈øed mee, I have by my faithfulne≈øs, hone≈øty and integrity to my Countrey in the prote≈øting again≈øt the di≈øcharge of this ≈øilver in the Admiralty, and by my con≈øtant, chargeable and dangerous pro≈øecution thereof, in getting the State two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pound, in refu≈øing the Claimers money, when they offered mee ten thou≈øand pounds to be ≈øilent and let the State be cozened of the ≈øilver: VVould I have been a knave I might have been reckoned among Mr Stenieers great ones, but my faithfulne≈øs to my Countrey in this particular ≈øervice (if the State be not ju≈øt to mee in their promi≈øe) will undo mee for ever.

Gentlemen, I have formerly delivered a particular of ≈øome of your names, and the ≈øummes of money I borrowed of you to to enable me to do this great ≈øervice, all my owne E≈øtate being under a ≈øeque≈øtration, unto the Commi≈ø≈øioners that were appointed to examine this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

Mo≈øt of you knew when you lent me this monies, I was to lay it out in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the Admiraltie, and tenn honourable Gentlemen have Certified, I borrowed of you and ≈øpent in this ≈øervice ≈øeven hundred ≈øixty five pounds, be≈øides ≈øeverall great ≈øummes of money
I payd ≈øome of you for Intere≈øt of this money ever ≈øince the year 1652. and great ≈øummes of money I have borrowed to do the Council of State other ≈øervices, as you may finde in this booke, Fol. 107. 108.

I owe unto you all this 25th of May 1659. the ≈øumme of fifteen hundred fourtie and odde pounds, currant money of England, which ≈øums I have laid out and a great deal more, in doing of this Common wealths ≈øervice. Gentlemen, I have printed this Letter to acquaint the Councel of State, that ≈øome of you have commenced Suits, and I look every daie for your Executions to be ≈øerved on me, for the very money I laid out to ≈øave the lives of thou≈øands of this Nation.

I ≈øhall humblie leave it to the con≈øideration of the Parliament, Councel of State, and all true Engli≈øhmen that are Lovers of their Countrey, and re≈øpect the credit of the Nation, when they ≈øhall reade what I have done in this ≈øervice, ≈øo clearly proved.

Fir≈øt, what the State and Common-wealth hath got, and the conjuncture of time when Van Tiumpe the Dutch Generall with the Dutch Fleets was in the Downes, and at that very time I was offered by the Claimers of this Silver, great Merchants of Flanders who was then in London to get this Silver out of the States hands, I have proved that the≈øe very Claimers ≈øeverall times offered me the ≈øumme of ten thou≈øand pounds, to have ≈øuffered the State to be cozened of this Silver in the Admiraltie, and had I not e≈øteem'd and valued, the peace and pro≈øperity of this Nation above my life, I would have
taken this money without any further trouble, and gone and lived in another Country, where I could have bin imployed in ≈øome Common wealths and States, and have bin honourablie and thankfully rewarded.

I ≈øhall humbly de≈øire the Parliament and Council of State to con≈øider how many ≈øuch malignants there is in the three Nations England, Scotland, and Ireland, if the Parliament could but finde a covee of ten ≈øuch malignants in England, Scotland, Ireland, and the Dominions of Wales, to bring them in two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds every one of them as I have done, ≈øuch a ≈øumme of money would pay the debts of the Publique, if they can finde none of the breed but my ≈øelf, I humbly de≈øire then to pre≈øerve me for a Phenix, and to pay me eleven thou≈øand pounds which I have ≈øo cleerly proved they owe me, and give me a Commi≈ø≈øion to go a Kite-catching for the Common-wealth, I ≈øhall humbly pre≈øent them with a great number of pretended godly Buzzards, who ≈øince the year 1640. have cozened the Common-wealth of many hundred thou≈øand pounds, I ≈øhall humblie ≈øhew them the wayes how they have done this, and finde out the men who from the bottome of ba≈øene≈ø≈øe and beggerie, have by unju≈øt waies accumulated to them≈øelves va≈øt e≈øtates, in the≈øe di≈øtracted and trouble ≈øome times, to the ruine of many thou≈øands of families, who≈øe cries for their oppre≈ø≈øions have a≈øcended up unto Heaven, and no doubt but is the principal cau≈øe of the≈øe ≈øad di≈øtractions and divi≈øions that are now among≈øt us.

If one Achan could trouble all I≈ørael for ≈øtealing a golden wedge, and a Babyloni≈øh Garment, what di≈øturbance will a thou≈øand Achans do, who have cozened the Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland; for my part I humblie ≈øay clearly, that I never ≈øtayed this Silver in 1652. for any of the then Councel of States particular profit, I never minded either Oliver or Rowland, I did it for the ≈øervice of the Commonwealth, and Honour of the Nation, as I was a true Engli≈øhman, without re≈øpecting private per≈øons; and let who will have the Government, or Supreme Power, I ≈øhall humbly demand it, as it is my right and due, my dearlie earned reward of eleven thou≈øand pounds for this ≈øervice.

S. Paul ≈øaith, hee ≈øought with bea≈øts at Ephe≈øus; I am ≈øure of it, in this bu≈øine≈øs, in ≈øtaying this Silver, I was fain to encounter with bea≈øts in the Admiraltie, at the Exchange, a ≈øhip-board, to make my ≈øelf all things to all men, to ≈øpend my ≈øpirits, my money, make u≈øe of my Credit, engage ≈øeverall of you Gentlemen to borrow great ≈øumms of money for mee, to get the State this great Trea≈øure: and when I ex≈øpect my reward, to bee delayed with Referrees, and Reports, and Certificates, and to trouble all the≈øe honourable Gentlemen to ≈øpend their time for ≈øeveral daies in taking the Proofs and Collections, and as yet not to receive one dramm of ju≈øtice, or one peny of Reward; to bee u≈øed as children are that look into a Fortune-book, to be directed from one ≈øpirit to another: how honourable this u≈øage will bee for the Common-wealth, to have this recorded to po≈øteritie, I leave it to you, and all ju≈øt men to judg.

So contrary to all humane ex≈øpectation hath Gods dealings been with mee in this bu≈øine≈øs, that where my greate≈øt fear was, I had no need to fear, and where my greate≈øt confidence was, there I am mi≈øerably di≈øappointed.

For I feared the Spaniards and the Claimers would kill me for ≈øtaying this Silver, but that was a needle≈ø≈øe fear, for God hath kept me, I put my tru≈øt in man and thought a≈ø≈øuredly, that it could never enter into the hearts of Gentlemen, and an Engli≈øh Council of State, but thankfully and honourablie to pay me what they had promi≈øed faithfully, and I ≈øo dearly earned, which was for getting them two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds.

The State to pay me in liew of my E≈øtate taken from me, to my damage twenty thou≈øand pounds, for which the Council of State agreed to pay me as afore≈øaid the ≈øum of eleven thou≈øand pounds, be≈øides an honourable reward.

Had I ≈øerved my God with that integrity, and broke ≈øo many nights ≈øleep to ≈øtudy to plea≈øe him, as I did to plea≈øe the Council of State and man, God would not have left, nor di≈øappointed me as man doth. Had the Council of State an intention never to have paied me when I undertook their work, they had done both you and me a Courte≈øie to have chopped of my head, and ea≈øed me out of a trouble≈øom world.

Then I had not cozened you of your money, which I mu≈øt be forced to do if the Council do not pay me, mo≈øt of you know I could not pay you, till the State payed me,
and this ≈øome of you will atte≈øt, when required to be true, be≈øides it grieves me to the Soule more for ≈øome of you, who out of good will to the Nation, borrowed great ≈øummes of money for me, and at this day are ≈øued for the ≈øame and mu≈øt pay it, that I ≈øhould be made an in≈øtrument to Trappan you or any hone≈øt man for your good will to your Countrey, to cozen you of your money.
It is true my body is at your ≈øervice to impri≈øon in a Goal, but it is money that you expect, and not my fle≈øh or bones.

How ≈øhamefull a thing would it bee, that it ≈øhould be left to po≈øterity, that Thomas Violet that ≈øaved this Nation two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds, all imploied in the defence of the Nation, at ≈øuch a time the Common-wealth was in Jeopardie, and in great ≈øtreights for money, di≈øcovering this Plot the ≈øame day the Judges in the Admiraltie would have di≈øcharged the Silver, and then it had bin pre≈øently conveyed to our enemies the Dutch.

For which ≈øervice and undertaking the Council of State faithfully promi≈øed him the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and an honourable reward, Thomas Violet having gott the Common-wealth all this Silver as afore≈øaid, but no performance, no promi≈øe, nor word kept.
That Thomas Violet might have had ten thou≈øand pounds from the Claimers to have de≈øerted this Tru≈øt, and to have conniv'd and let this Silver go, but he would not be fal≈øe to the Common-wealth.

p.hi: But con≈øtantly for two years being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by ten other per≈øons that followed this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the Admiraltie, a Shipboard, and at the Exchange, and in ≈øeverall other places, and with much Trouble, Charge, and Expence, to get the State the afore≈øaid great Trea≈øure, borrowing fifteen hundred pounds of ≈øeverall of his dear and loveing friends to do this ≈øervice, who upon the Councils of State not performing with me, in paying me my dearly earned reward, were all cozened of their money, for I cannot pay you before the State pay mee, and if this ≈øhould fall out to be true, would not all good men ≈øay, both you and I have had hard mea≈øure for our good will and fidelity for getting the State this great Trea≈øure, and make other men for the future to take money when it is offered them.
And not to play an after-game as I now do, to Petition for my due ≈øatisfaction.

I pray God for the honour of this Nation, and of this Po≈øterity, that the Council of State take order for my ≈øatisfaction, and indeed I am per≈øwaded in my Con≈øcience, when the Council ≈øees the≈øe Tran≈øactions atte≈øted by a multitude of honourable Witne≈ø≈øes, and my ≈øervices ≈øo great, that never any man of my quality had the like Conte≈øt with mightie men, and brought it to ≈øo happie ≈øucce≈øs as I have don, that I ≈øhall be truly paid eleven thou≈øand pounds, and the Damages will be con≈øidered for the forbearance of my dearly earned reward ≈øo long from 1653 to 1659.

div.p:
Gentlemen, I have pre≈øented to you the harde≈øt u≈øage that you or I can expect, and if I be not ju≈øtly and honourably dealt with, let fortune doe her wor≈øt, I will tru≈øt and wait on Gods Providance, and tide out the≈øe trouble≈øom times, ever keeping this rule where I receive Protection there will I pay obedience, let it be to
Oliver, or Rowland, and no longer then I can have Protection will I owe obedience, but I will ≈øtudy the happine≈ø≈øe and Honour of my Countrey ≈øo long as I live and breath, and let what will come this hath and ≈øhall be my rule to walke by.

I now think it convenient to give you an accompt, by what waies I humbly propound to be paid by the Parliament and Council of State this ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and to take no money from them, but to bring them in greater ≈øummes of money, and al≈øo advantage the Nation many ≈øcores of thou≈øand pounds, and fill the Nation with great Trea≈øure of gold and ≈øilver, the Soldiers delight, and the Merchants darling, being that which is the mea≈øure of all things.
Upon the peru≈øeall of this narative, you will ≈øee a Watch taken in pieces, and to your eye you ≈øee the wheeles and ≈øprings that makes the motions and the parties imployed.
A Painter may ≈øhew you the Colours before he workes, but the craft is in mixing and grinding them, and handling the pencel that makes the Picture.

There is not one man of a hundred thou≈øand that could, or can go through with this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, but the undertaking of it would brake his neck. It was God that inabled me, and kept up my ≈øpirits, and ≈øo he doth at this day, or el≈øe it had bin impo≈ø≈øible but I ≈øhould have ≈øunke under the weight of ≈øo much oppre≈ø≈øion.
The ≈øhewing you a Watch, and painting, inables you not to make either, without long ≈øtudy, Tooles and materialls.
Here you ≈øee both the Theorick, and the practick part, that I have and can ≈øerve my Countrey.

And me thinkes that rule in common Ju≈øtice ≈øhould be allowed
to me, that haveing made my proofe-piece as it is among≈øt mo≈øt Lawyers or Trade≈ømen as a reading ≈øhews a man well ver≈øt in the Law, an excellent Picture once fini≈øhed makes a man an approved Painter, and ≈øeverall prizes ≈økilfully played approves a man ma≈øter of defence.

I humbly pre≈øent unto the Parliament and Nation, my getting the Common wealth this two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds to be my proof-piece, to ≈øhew to po≈øterity, that the Garden of England hath too few ≈øuch malignant Violets, that would voluntarily venture life, credit, and what is above life, have morgaged all my well-being for the future for fifteen hundred pounds to ≈øave this Nation, and refu≈øed ten thou≈øand pounds when I was offered to be bribed.
Let any ju≈øt man con≈øider of what I have done, and no man can deny me this reward of eleven thou≈øand pounds, that hath hone≈øty, honour, or Con≈øcience.

When they remember Chri≈øts rule, do as thou would≈øt be done unto, (I mu≈øt put the number of ≈øuch ungratefull per≈øons, if the ≈øad fate of State have left any of the breed in the Council of State not into the number of Engli≈øh States men, but they are of the breed of Machiavel,) and I hope not to finde one of them in our Engli≈øh Council of State, that profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtianity and would offer wor≈øe mea≈øure to their fellow Countrey-men, and Prote≈øtants, then Turks would u≈øe to Chri≈øtians.

God deliver all good hone≈øt minded men from ≈øuch Machiavel-villains, but I hope better things that St. James his rule ≈øhall be remembred, ≈øhew me thy faith by thy workes, that I that have worked in the Vinyard of this Common-wealth all my time, ≈øo ≈øuccesfully for the profit and honour of the Nation
from the year 1648. to 1659. now I have gotten the State this Trea≈øure as I have fully proved it (both the money the State promi≈øed being eleven thou≈øand pounds, and an honourable reward.) the honour and Ju≈øtice of the Nation being ≈øo highly concerned to ≈øee mee Ju≈øtly ≈øatisfied.

To conclude, have you but patience till the next Term, and ≈øuch of you as have commenced your ≈øuits go no further, put not your ≈øelfe and me to expence and trouble, till I get the Council of States An≈øwer to this booke, I here promi≈øe you all, ≈øuch of you that will have my per≈øon, next Terme willingly to ≈øubmitt to your Executions, and if the Council of State will ≈øuffer me to be buried in a pri≈øon alive, for the money I expended to get the State two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds, and at that time ventured my life in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, ≈øuch oppre≈ø≈øions will ≈øtinke in the no≈øtrills of all good and ju≈øt men, but I hope better things, and tru≈øt the Council of State will be more carefull of the credit, and faith of the Nation.

closer.signed: Your Bond-man for the States ≈øervice, and would ≈øain ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelf my own Freeman to do yon ≈øervice. THOMAS VIOLET.

div.head: THE POSTCRIPT. The Wayes I humbly propound to the State to pay me this debt, are the≈øe, in which Emploiment the Common wealth will get twenty times more advantage then I, as appears, Viz.
div.p: 1. I Have at this time three Bonds in my Cu≈øtody, which were out of my po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion twelve yeares in the Committee of Shrop≈øhires hands at Shrewsbury, which bonds are in two thou≈øand pounds for the payment of me one thou≈øand pounds, and taken from my Si≈øter Anno. 1643. who kept them for me, the≈øe bonds were due in 1644. I paid John Corbet E≈øquire a member of this pre≈øent Parliament forty pound, to have the≈øe Bonds delivered to me by the Committee of Salop, which money I paid by command of the Council of State, as appeares in this book Fol. 27. 28. 29.

I only humbly de≈øire and pray for an Order, or Ordinance of Parliament to confirme the ≈øaid Order of the Council of State, and that I be impowered by Order of Parliament to ≈øue and to implead the ≈øaid Bonds, as formerly I might have done, notwith≈øtanding any Order, or Ordinance of Parliament to the Committee of Shrop≈øhire, or any other Committee touching or concerning the≈øe Bonds, in regard I have paid the Committee of Salop forty pounds for them as afore≈øaid.

And I ≈øhall thankfully allow and accept of the≈øe three Bonds for two thou≈øand pounds in part of payment of the ≈øumme of eleven thou≈øand pounds the Council of State promi≈øed me. Gentlemen, for your Comfort the≈øe Bonds are good Bonds, and the men Solvant that owe me the money, and the money is doubled at ≈øix in the hundred at this day, and I have men of fifteen hundred a yeare tyed for the payment of me of the≈øe Bonds at long running, though now they keep out of the way, they ≈øhall pay me.

2. Wheras I had an Office for Regulating gold and ≈øilver thread, as appeares in this Book, Fol. 110. 111. 112. and had I not bin di≈øturbed in the due Execution of the ≈øaid Office by ≈øeverall Clamorous cheating Silkemen, Wyerdrawers, and Refiners, who I have proved to the Parliament make it a common Trade to cozen the wearers of gold and ≈øilver Lace, as I can atte≈øt it under the hands of Mr. Alexander Jack≈øon ≈øworne a≈ø≈øay Ma≈øter of Gold≈ømiths Hall, and other per≈øons in a hundred parcells.

The Refiners and Wyer drawers of gold and ≈øilver within this twenty yeares, have culled and melted down the heavie≈øt coines of Shillings, Sixpences, halfe Crownes, and Plate of this Nation, to above the value of a million of Silver, to the great weakening of the Stock of currant Silver money, the great decay of Trade, and un≈øpeakable lo≈ø≈øe to the Common-wealth.

I have, and can produce to the Parliament a Certificate of the Committee of Trade dated the 16th of January 1657. upon many days examination of all the≈øe abu≈øes, I have it
certified to the Parliament the ≈øeverall daily cheats of Wier-drawers put on the Nation, and the Committee for Trade recommended me Thomas Violet to the Parliament to be re≈øtored to my Office with ≈øuch fees as I received formerly, and certifie the great mi≈øcheifes which is daily practi≈øed for want of this Office.

And that I ≈øhould be ordered to put in ≈øecurity in the Exchequer in ≈øuch ≈øummes as the Parliament plea≈øe to appoint me, to warrant all gold and ≈øilver Wyer that ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øayd at the Office to be fine Silver, and not under ≈øterling, and all gold and ≈øilver Thread to be ju≈øtly and duly made, with a due proportion of Silke, and Thomas Violet to pay the damages to any per≈øon greiv'd or wrong'd, that buy gold or ≈øilver Thread, or Lace ≈øurveyd as afore≈øaid.

And to prohibit all Refiners, and other per≈øons the melting down the currant Silver coines, or Plate of the Nation, for any of the≈øe manufactures upon ≈øevere penalties, the Committee recommend me to the Parliament, I ≈øhould have the power as formerly to make ≈øearches, and deface all adulterate gold and ≈øilver Thread and Wyer, and the Committee Certifies this Regulation of the re≈øtoring me to my Office, would increa≈øe the ≈øtock of Silver in the Nation above thirty thou≈øand pounds a yeare, the original Order I have ready to produce.

And if the Parliament by their Order impower me to Execute that Office again, and confirme me in it for two lifes, which co≈øt me fifteen hundred pounds before I could get the grant under the great Seale from the late
King, (which money I paid to the Lord Trea≈øurer Juck≈øon, Lord Cottington, Secretary Cook, Mr Atturney General Banks,) if I have this Office againe, I will increa≈øe the ≈øtock of Trea≈øure every yeare above ≈øeventy thou≈øand pounds a year, whereas now as this manufacture is made, without a Rule, it wa≈øtes the ≈øtock of Trea≈øure thirty thou≈øand pounds a year, and this I will maintaine, prove, and demon≈øtrate it to your Honours to be true, this manufacture being under no Rule and Government as it is at this day, is one of the back doors that hath brought ≈øuch a ≈øcar≈øity and want of currant Silver money on the Nation, and had it ever come to Examination in Parliament as now I de≈øire it may, I will prove it is more profitable to the Nation to keep money in peoples pur≈øes, then vainly to bru≈øh and lo≈øe thirty thou≈øand pounds a year of men and womens cloaths, as is Certified by a Committee of Parliament it now doth.

I will demon≈øtrate this Nation had better have given at this day one hundred thou≈øand pounds to me to have kept up this Office to a due Regulation, then have put down my Office, by the doing thereof they have had a million of money le≈øs in the ≈øtock of the Nation then they ≈øhould have had, had my Office continued, if the Parliament plea≈øe to impower me to Regulate this manufacture, and to receive the fees I took formerly, I humbly will accept of it for two thou≈øand pounds ≈øo I may have it for two li≈øes, in part of payment of the eleven thou≈øand pounds which the State owes me.

3. I have for many years attended the Committee of the
Mint about Regulating their Mint, as is well knowne to many members of the Council of State what charge and time I ≈øpent in this ≈øervice, I complained of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe eleven yeares ago, and for your further ≈øatisfaction I recommend you to Fol. 11. 12. 13. 14. in this book, there you will ≈øee the true Rea≈øons ≈øet down how it comes about that no ≈øilver and gold is coyned in the Tower.

And that the Parliament, I will Ju≈øtifie, had been better to have given the two Doctors Gourdon, and St. John, forty thou≈øand pounds for a Pention, then have imployed them in their Mint, that it is not in the power or ≈økil of Doctors or Apothecaries ever to ≈øet the Mint at work as I have demon≈øtrated: that had I not ≈øtayed two hundred ≈øeventy eight thou≈øand pounds which was coyned by my pro≈øecution, this ≈øum was as much money as hath bin coined in ≈øome ≈øeven yeares in the Tower, ≈øince the Ma≈øter-worker and Warden had that imploiment, I have humbly offered if the Parliament plea≈øe to command me and pay mee for my paines, that I will make the Mint cor≈øtantly go, and cau≈øe every year ≈øome hundred of thou≈øands of pounds to be coined, to the honour of the Nation, and increa≈øe of the ≈øtock of the Nation.

Provided I may have the place of Ma≈øter-worker and Melter, with the u≈øuall fees formerly allowed to them ≈øetled under the great Seale, and that I may be impowered by Orders and Warrants from the Council of State from time to time for to ≈øee the due execution of my place, for the inabling me to do this ≈øervice. This bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to effect is very trouble≈øom and chargable.

And will be of mighty concernment to the State, for their ≈øervice, as you will ≈øee in this booke, by filling the Nation with Trea≈øure and money, the blood and ≈øinews of Commcrce and Warr, what makes ≈øo generall a complaint of want of Trade, but want of money, and people have not monies to pay the ordinary and nece≈ø≈øary charges, and if the State do not look to ≈øettle this bu≈øine≈øs ≈øuddenly, this mi≈øcheif for this many years I have foretold to the Parliament in Print, and I knew would ≈øuddenly come upon us.

It is a certain Maxime, Not any private per≈øon, or a Common-wealth can ever be capable of effecting any great bu≈øine≈ø≈øe that is not rich in monies, or cannot command great ≈øummes of money, either of his own, or upon his Credit.

I pray read and con≈øider what I have ≈øaid concerning this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in this book, Fol 11. 12. 13 14. if the State imploy me here in the Mint, I will remove all the≈øe ob≈øtructions, and ≈øet the Mint a working, and this imployment if I have it for my life, I will humbly accept of it at the value of two thou≈øand pounds, in part of payment of my ≈øatisfaction of eleven thou≈øand pounds, and by my indu≈øtry and care will increa≈øe the States Stock every year ≈øome hundred of thou≈øand of pounds of Silver, which now comes in, and is ≈øtollen out.

I would never undertake to do this diffiult bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, were I not a≈ø≈øured there is none in the Nation can do it but my ≈øelf, and till the State imploy me, this work will never be done effectually.

Three of you Gentlemen are great mints men and Gold ≈ømiths, and know the difficultie of this undertaking, and I dare affirme before you, none of you will trouble your ≈øelves to finde out the bottom of the≈øe difficult waies that mu≈øt be u≈øed to do this ≈øervice, not for ten times the profit I ≈øhall receive by this Emploiment.

Therefore I humbly de≈øire to have an act to injoy the place of Ma≈øter-worker and Melter for my life, provided I do this ≈øervice within three moneths after my grant, this mi≈øcheif is come to a gangrene, and the Council of State mu≈øt make ≈øharp and ≈øtrict Orders in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, or el≈øe this mi≈øcheif cannot be remedied, a great deal of care mu≈øt be u≈øed to put the≈øe Laws in Execution, el≈øe there wil be a perpetual con≈øumption of the Stock of the Nation in the Silver coines, as it is come already on the Gold coines, you ≈øhall not receive in a thou≈øand pounds one twenty-≈øhillings-peece in Gold, and in few years there wil be the like defect in the Silver, not ≈øo much as will maintain Commerce, and Trade, pay Rents and Taxes, nor to go to Market.

The fir≈øt Sluce-gate that mu≈øt be ≈øtopped, is the forbidding the melting of gold and Silver currant coins of the Nation, for gold and ≈øilver thread it is true there is a Law again≈øt it, but who looks after the Execution, Execution is that that gives life to the Law.
The like cour≈øe mu≈øt be taken again≈øt the Tran≈øporting gold & ≈øilver out of the Nation, it is true old Laws forbid it, but who makes it their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to di≈øcover the offenders

Had the Act pa≈ø≈øed in the Hou≈øe which I pro≈øecuted
again≈øt Tran≈øporting Gold and Silver, and I impowered and imployed as I humbly propounded ten years ago, this Nation had had at this day millions of Silver which is now Tran≈øported, to the great damage of the Nation.

This Act hath bin twice read in the Hou≈øe, ten times Committed, Referred to the Committee of the Navies, Officers of the Mint, Officers of the Cu≈øtomes, all their Reports and Certificates certifie that if the Parliament will not pa≈ø≈øe this Act, and appoint able skilfull per≈øons to make it their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to hinder the Tran≈øporting Gold and Silver, the ≈øtock of Gold and Silver in the Nation would be all Tran≈øported, and this Nation expo≈øed to very great inconveniences by not preventing it, who can or could ≈øay more then the≈øe Certificates ≈øay.

If the Parliament plea≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe this Act, I will ≈øpend my time and paines, and in that ≈øervice, take the≈øe Tran≈øporters in the nick of their action, and confi≈øcate the monies, had I Warrants and did ≈øet my ≈øpringes I would catch the≈øe Woodcocks, my experience would be of great advantage, for an old Dear ≈øtealer is the be≈øt keeper of the Park, and it is not unknown to ≈øome of you that almo≈øt thirty yeares ago I was que≈øtioned about Tran≈øporting Gold and Silver, I di≈øcovered a ne≈øt of Tran≈øporters of Gold, and the King ingaged me to do that ≈øervice, I cau≈øed them to be fined twenty foure thou≈øand one hundred pounds, in the year 1635. in the Starr Chamber, as appears by the Records, and made Alderman Gibbs, and Sir John Wolla≈øton, glad to Petition and pay well to the late King for their Pardons, for
